paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Oh, for a muse of fire that would ascend$NEWLINE$The brightest heaven of invention!$NEWLINE$A kingdom for a stage, princes to act,$NEWLINE$And monarchs to behold the swelling scene!$NEWLINE$Then should the warlike Harry, like himself,$NEWLINE$Assume the port of Mars, and at his heels,$NEWLINE$Leashed in like hounds, should famine, sword, and fire$NEWLINE$Crouch for employment. But pardon, gentles all,$NEWLINE$The flat unraisèd spirits that hath dared$NEWLINE$On this unworthy scaffold to bring forth$NEWLINE$So great an object. Can this cockpit hold$NEWLINE$The vasty fields of France? Or may we cram$NEWLINE$Within this wooden O the very casques$NEWLINE$O$NEWLINE$That did affright the air at Agincourt?$NEWLINE$O pardon, since a crookèd figure may$NEWLINE$Attest in little place a million,$NEWLINE$And let us, ciphers to this great account,$NEWLINE$On your imaginary forces work.$NEWLINE$Suppose within the girdle of these walls$NEWLINE$Are now confined two mighty monarchies$NEWLINE$Whose high uprearèd and abutting fronts$NEWLINE$The perilous narrow ocean parts asunder.$NEWLINE$Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts.$NEWLINE$Into a thousand parts divide one man,$NEWLINE$And make imaginary puissance.$NEWLINE$Think, when we talk of horses, that you see them$NEWLINE$Printing their proud hoofs i' th' receiving earth,$NEWLINE$For ’tis your thoughts that now must deck our kings,$NEWLINE$Carry them here and there, jumping o'er times,
paragraphs.translated: CHORUS$NEWLINE$If only we had divine inspiration, our play might rise to the highest level of imagination. If we had a stage as big as a kingdom, real kings and queens to act the part of kings and queens, and royalty to also witness the glorious spectacle, then it would be as it really was. Then valiant King Harry would resemble the god of war, as he did in life, and famine, sword, and fire would sit like dogs at his feet, waiting to be unleashed.$NEWLINE$But, ladies and gentlemen, since that’s not the case, you must forgive us plain, ordinary men who dare to act out so great a story on this humble stage. Can this theater seem to contain the sweeping fields of France? Could we even squeeze into this little theater the helmets that looked so frightening at Agincourt? Hardly! But, pardon us, because just as a few strokes of a pen, a few zeros, can signify a huge number, we, who are zeros in this great story, can work on your imagination. Pretend that within the confines of this theater sit two great kingdoms divided by a narrow but perilous ocean. Let your thoughts make up for our imperfections. Divide each man into a thousand, and there you will have an imaginary army. Imagine, when we talk of horses, that you see them planting their proud hooves in the soft earth. Because now it is your thoughts that must dress up our kings and transport them from place to place. Your thoughts must leap over huge spans of time, turning the events of many

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Turning th' accomplishment of many years$NEWLINE$Into an hour-glass; for the which supply,$NEWLINE$Admit me chorus to this history;$NEWLINE$Who, prologue-like, your humble patience pray$NEWLINE$Gently to hear, kindly to judge our play.
paragraphs.translated: years into the space of a few hours. To that end, consider me a sort of chorus, here to help tell the story. And, as the speaker of any prologue should, I ask you to hear our play courteously and to judge it kindly.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the Archbishop of CANTERBURY and the Bishop of ELY$NEWLINE$CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$ELY
paragraphs.translated: The Archbishop of CANTERBURY and the Bishop of ELY enter.$NEWLINE$CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$ELY

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$My lord, I’ll tell you that self bill is urged$NEWLINE$Which in th' eleventh year of the last king’s reign$NEWLINE$Was like, and had indeed against us passed$NEWLINE$But that the scambling and unquiet time$NEWLINE$Did push it out of farther question.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$My lord, this bill that’s being proposed is the same one that was proposed in the eleventh year of old King Henry’s reign. Everyone thought it would pass then, and it probably would have had it not been for the great civil unrest and uncertainty of the time, which required the matter to be put off.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$But how, my lord, shall we resist it now?
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$But how will we keep it from being passed now, my lord?

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$It must be thought on. If it pass against us,$NEWLINE$We lose the better half of our possession,$NEWLINE$For all the temporal lands which men devout$NEWLINE$By testament have given to the Church$NEWLINE$Would they strip from us, being valued thus:$NEWLINE$“As much as would maintain, to the King’s honor,$NEWLINE$Full fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights,$NEWLINE$Six thousand and two hundred good esquires;$NEWLINE$And, to relief of lazars and weak age$NEWLINE$Of indigent faint souls past corporal toil,$NEWLINE$A hundred almshouses right well supplied;$NEWLINE$And to the coffers of the King besides,$NEWLINE$A thousand pounds by th' year.” Thus runs the bill.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$We have to think about that. If it does pass, the Church will lose more than half of what it possesses, because the bill would strip us of enough real estate left to the church by wealthy, pious men in their wills to support fifteen earls and fifteen hundred knights, six thousand two hundred squires, and a hundred well-supplied almshouses for the relief of lepers, old-age pensioners, the poor, and those too weak or sick to work. Add to that a yearly sum of a thousand pounds to go directly into the king’s coffers. That’s what the bill says.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$This would drink deep.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$That would be quite a drain.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$'Twould drink the cup and all.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$It would drain us dry.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$But what prevention?
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$But what can be done to prevent it?

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$The king is full of grace and fair regard.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$The king is virtuous and kind.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$And a true lover of the holy Church.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$And a true lover of the holy Church.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$The courses of his youth promised it not.$NEWLINE$The breath no sooner left his father’s body$NEWLINE$But that his wildness, mortified in him,$NEWLINE$Seemed to die too. Yea, at that very moment$NEWLINE$Consideration like an angel came$NEWLINE$And whipped th' offending Adam out of him,$NEWLINE$Leaving his body as a paradise$NEWLINE$T' envelop and contain celestial spirits.$NEWLINE$Never was such a sudden scholar made,$NEWLINE$Never came reformation in a flood$NEWLINE$With such a heady currance scouring faults,$NEWLINE$Nor never Hydra-headed willfulness$NEWLINE$So soon did lose his seat, and all at once,$NEWLINE$As in this king.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$You wouldn’t have expected it based on how he acted as a youth. But no sooner had his father stopped breathing than the prince’s wildness died too. Really, at that precise moment he gained a capacity for reflection, which appeared like an angel to chase away the sinful part of him, leaving his body like a paradise, fit to house only lofty thoughts and feelings. You never saw anyone become serious and studious so quickly. You never saw such a total transformation, as though a wild river, rushing through, had swept away his faults. Such a collection of stubborn character flaws was never banished from one place so suddenly as in the case of this king.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$We are blessèd in the change.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$We are fortunate in the change.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Hear him but reason in divinity$NEWLINE$And, all-admiring, with an inward wish,$NEWLINE$You would desire the King were made a prelate.$NEWLINE$Hear him debate of commonwealth affairs,$NEWLINE$You would say it hath been all in all his study.$NEWLINE$List his discourse of war, and you shall hear$NEWLINE$A fearful battle rendered you in music.$NEWLINE$Turn him to any cause of policy,$NEWLINE$The Gordian knot of it he will unloose$NEWLINE$Familiar as his garter; that, when he speaks,$NEWLINE$The air, a chartered libertine, is still,$NEWLINE$And the mute wonder lurketh in men’s ears$NEWLINE$To steal his sweet and honeyed sentences;$NEWLINE$So that the art and practic part of life$NEWLINE$Must be the mistress to this theoric;$NEWLINE$Which is a wonder how his Grace should glean it,$NEWLINE$Since his addiction was to courses vain,$NEWLINE$His companies unlettered, rude, and shallow,$NEWLINE$His hours filled up with riots, banquets, sports,$NEWLINE$And never noted in him any study,$NEWLINE$Any retirement, any sequestration$NEWLINE$From open haunts and popularity.
paragraphs.translated:
CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$If you just listen to him discuss theological matters, you’ll find yourself thinking privately what an excellent bishop he would make. Hear him debate matters of domestic policy, and you’d swear he had made them his constant study. Listen to him talk about war, and you’ll hear elegant and thrilling accounts of the battles. Bring up any political topic, and he’ll untangle it as easily as if it were his own
garter. And the result is that when he speaks, the very air—which is free to go where it likes—stops dead, and men stand in silent wonder, hoping to catch the benefit of his gorgeous utterances. There must be skill and experience behind all this abstract thought, but it’s anyone’s guess how he obtained it, since in his youth he preferred shallow pursuits, with uneducated, crude and superficial companions. He spent his time drunken, overfed, and constantly seeking out entertainment, with no inclination for learning or quiet contemplation, nor any limit to his tolerance for public haunts and crowds.$NEWLINE$garter$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$The strawberry grows underneath the nettle,$NEWLINE$And wholesome berries thrive and ripen best$NEWLINE$Neighbored by fruit of baser quality;$NEWLINE$And so the Prince obscured his contemplation$NEWLINE$Under the veil of wildness, which, no doubt,$NEWLINE$Grew like the summer grass, fastest by night,$NEWLINE$Unseen yet crescive in his faculty.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$Strawberries grow underneath nettle plants, and berries grow best when they’re planted next to inferior fruit. In the same way, the prince hid his serious side under the guise of wild behavior. Just like summer grass, which grows fastest during the night, this sober quality was able to grow and thrive all the better for being undetected.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$It must be so, for miracles are ceased,$NEWLINE$And therefore we must needs admit the means$NEWLINE$How things are perfected.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$That must be it, because the age of miracles is passed, and we have to find reasonable explanations for why these things happen.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$But, my good lord,$NEWLINE$How now for mitigation of this bill$NEWLINE$Urged by the Commons? Doth his Majesty$NEWLINE$Incline to it or no?
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$But tell me, my lord: as to the softening of this bill proposed by the House of Commons, does his Majesty favor it or not?

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$He seems indifferent,$NEWLINE$Or rather swaying more upon our part$NEWLINE$Than cherishing th' exhibitors against us;$NEWLINE$For I have made an offer to his Majesty—$NEWLINE$Upon our spiritual convocation$NEWLINE$And in regard of causes now in hand,$NEWLINE$Which I have opened to his Grace at large,$NEWLINE$As touching France—to give a greater sum$NEWLINE$Than ever at one time the clergy yet$NEWLINE$Did to his predecessors part withal.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$He seems neutral, perhaps leaning a little more toward our side than that of our opponents—since I’ve made his Majesty an offer, following a meeting with our fellow bishops. The offer regards certain matters having to do with France that his Grace and I have been discussing. My offer would involve us giving him a greater sum than the clergy ever gave at one time to any of his predecessors.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$How did this offer seem received, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$How did he take the offer, my lord?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$With good acceptance of his Majesty—$NEWLINE$Save that there was not time enough to hear,$NEWLINE$As I perceived his Grace would fain have done,$NEWLINE$The severals and unhidden passages$NEWLINE$Of his true titles to some certain dukedoms,$NEWLINE$And generally to the crown and seat of France,$NEWLINE$Derived from Edward, his great-grandfather.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Favorably, except that there wasn’t enough time for his Grace to hear, as I sensed he would have liked to, the details about how he is rightfully entitled to certain dukedoms in France, and to the throne of France in general, through clear lines of descent originating with his great-grandfather, Edward III.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$What was th' impediment that broke this off?
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$What kept you from telling him this?

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$The French ambassador upon that instant$NEWLINE$Craved audience. And the hour, I think, is come$NEWLINE$To give him hearing. Is it four o'clock?
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$The French ambassador arrived at that moment and asked to see the king. And, in fact, I think they’re meeting together right now. Is it four o'clock?

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$It is.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$It is.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Then go we in to know his embassy,$NEWLINE$Which I could with a ready guess declare$NEWLINE$Before the Frenchman speak a word of it.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Then let’s go in and hear what he has to say—though I think I can guess before the Frenchman has uttered a word.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$I’ll wait upon you, and I long to hear it.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$I’ll accompany you. I’m also eager to hear it.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KING HENRY, GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, WARWICK, WESTMORELAND, and attendants$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY, GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, WARWICK, and WESTMORELAND enter, with attendants.$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Where is my gracious lord of Canterbury?

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Not here in presence.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$He’s not here.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Send for him, good uncle.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Send for him, dear uncle.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Shall we call in th' ambassador, my liege?
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Shall we call in the ambassador, my liege?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Not yet, my cousin. We would be resolved,$NEWLINE$Before we hear him, of some things of weight$NEWLINE$That task our thoughts concerning us and France.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Not yet, cousin. Before I hear him, I want to decide some important issues that are on my mind concerning my throne and France.

paragraphs.original: Enter the Archbishop of CANTERBURY and the Bishop of ELY$NEWLINE$CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$ELY
paragraphs.translated: The archbishop of CANTERBURY and the bishop of ELY enter.$NEWLINE$CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$ELY

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$God and his angels guard your sacred throne$NEWLINE$And make you long become it.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$May God and his angels guard your sacred throne and grant that you dignify it for a long time.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Sure we thank you.$NEWLINE$My learnèd lord, we pray you to proceed$NEWLINE$And justly and religiously unfold$NEWLINE$Why the law Salic that they have in France$NEWLINE$Or should or should not bar us in our claim.$NEWLINE$And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord,$NEWLINE$That you should fashion, wrest, or bow your reading,$NEWLINE$Or nicely charge your understanding soul$NEWLINE$With opening titles miscreate, whose right$NEWLINE$Suits not in native colors with the truth;$NEWLINE$For God doth know how many now in health$NEWLINE$Shall drop their blood in approbation
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Thank you, I’m sure. My learned lord, kindly explain to us the legal and religious grounds for why this French Salic law either should or shouldn’t bar me in my claim. And God forbid, my dear and faithful lord, that you should invent, twist, or distort your interpretation, or burden your conscience by subtly arguing for false claims. For God knows how many healthy men will shed their blood in support of whatever you persuade me to do. So think carefully before you incite me

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Of what your reverence shall incite us to.$NEWLINE$Therefore take heed how you impawn our person,$NEWLINE$How you awake our sleeping sword of war.$NEWLINE$We charge you in the name of God, take heed,$NEWLINE$For never two such kingdoms did contend$NEWLINE$Without much fall of blood, whose guiltless drops$NEWLINE$Are every one a woe, a sore complaint$NEWLINE$'Gainst him whose wrong gives edge unto the swords$NEWLINE$That make such waste in brief mortality.$NEWLINE$Under this conjuration, speak, my lord,$NEWLINE$For we will hear, note, and believe in heart$NEWLINE$That what you speak is in your conscience washed$NEWLINE$As pure as sin with baptism.
paragraphs.translated: to wage war. I charge you, in the name of God, be careful what you say. For mighty kingdoms such as England and France have never gone to war with one another without much bloodshed, every innocent drop of which cries out against the wrongdoer who caused such loss of life without good reason. With this in mind, speak, my lord. And I will listen, consider, and earnestly believe that what you say is spoken with a conscience as pure as a newly baptized soul.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you peers$NEWLINE$That owe yourselves, your lives, and services$NEWLINE$To this imperial throne. There is no bar$NEWLINE$To make against your Highness' claim to France$NEWLINE$But this, which they produce from Pharamond:$NEWLINE$“In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant”$NEWLINE$“In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant”$NEWLINE$(No woman shall succeed in Salic land),$NEWLINE$Which Salic land the French unjustly gloze$NEWLINE$To be the realm of France, and Pharamond$NEWLINE$The founder of this law and female bar.$NEWLINE$Yet their own authors faithfully affirm$NEWLINE$That the land Salic is in Germany,$NEWLINE$Between the floods of Sala and of Elbe,$NEWLINE$Where Charles the Great, having subdued the Saxons,$NEWLINE$There left behind and settled certain French,$NEWLINE$Who, holding in disdain the German women$NEWLINE$For some dishonest manners of their life,$NEWLINE$Established then this law: to wit, no female$NEWLINE$Should be inheritrix in Salic land,$NEWLINE$Which “Salic,” as I said, ’twixt Elbe and Sala$NEWLINE$Is at this day in Germany called Meissen.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and all you peers who owe your lives and duty to this imperial throne. There is no legal obstacle to your Highness’s claim to France except the following rule, which the French cite from King Pharamond: In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant (No woman shall inherit property in the Salic land). The French wrongly interpret “the Salic land” to mean France, and they cite Pharamond as the founder of this law that bars female succession to the throne. But their own authors assert that the Salic land is in Germany, between the Sala and the Elbe rivers, where Charles the Great left behind certain French settlements after conquering the Saxons. The French settlers despised the German women because they were unfaithful to their husbands, so the settlers passed this law that no woman should have right of inheritance in Salic land. And the Salic land—the region between the Elbe and the Sala, in Germany, as I said—is now called Meissen. It is clear, then, that the Salic law was not$NEWLINE$In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Then hear me, gracious sovereign, and you peers$NEWLINE$That owe yourselves, your lives, and services$NEWLINE$To this imperial throne. There is no bar$NEWLINE$To make against your Highness' claim to France$NEWLINE$But this, which they produce from Pharamond:$NEWLINE$“In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant”$NEWLINE$“In terram Salicam mulieres ne succedant”$NEWLINE$(No woman shall succeed in Salic land),$NEWLINE$Which Salic land the French unjustly gloze$NEWLINE$To be the realm of France, and Pharamond$NEWLINE$The founder of this law and female bar.$NEWLINE$Yet their own authors faithfully affirm$NEWLINE$That the land Salic is in Germany,$NEWLINE$Between the floods of Sala and of Elbe,$NEWLINE$Where Charles the Great, having subdued the Saxons,$NEWLINE$There left behind and settled certain French,$NEWLINE$Who, holding in disdain the German women$NEWLINE$For some dishonest manners of their life,$NEWLINE$Established then this law: to wit, no female$NEWLINE$Should be inheritrix in Salic land,$NEWLINE$Which “Salic,” as I said, ’twixt Elbe and Sala$NEWLINE$Is at this day in Germany called Meissen.$NEWLINE$Then doth it well appear the Salic law$NEWLINE$Was not devisèd for the realm of France,$NEWLINE$Nor did the French possess the Salic land$NEWLINE$Until four hundred one and twenty years$NEWLINE$After defunction of King Pharamond,$NEWLINE$Idly supposed the founder of this law;$NEWLINE$Who died within the year of our redemption$NEWLINE$Four hundred twenty-six; and Charles the Great$NEWLINE$Subdued the Saxons and did seat the French$NEWLINE$Beyond the river Sala in the year$NEWLINE$Eight hundred five. Besides, their writers say,$NEWLINE$King Pepin, which deposèd Childeric,$NEWLINE$Did, as heir general, being descended$NEWLINE$Of Blithild, which was daughter to King Clothair,$NEWLINE$Make claim and title to the crown of France.$NEWLINE$Hugh Capet also, who usurped the crown$NEWLINE$Of Charles the duke of Lorraine, sole heir male$NEWLINE$Of the true line and stock of Charles the Great,$NEWLINE$To find his title with some shows of truth,$NEWLINE$Though in pure truth it was corrupt and naught,$NEWLINE$Conveyed himself as th' heir to th' Lady Lingare,$NEWLINE$Daughter to Charlemagne, who was the son$NEWLINE$To Lewis the Emperor, and Lewis the son$NEWLINE$Of Charles the Great. Also King Lewis the Tenth,$NEWLINE$Who was sole heir to the usurper Capet,$NEWLINE$Could not keep quiet in his conscience,$NEWLINE$Wearing the crown of France, till satisfied$NEWLINE$That fair Queen Isabel, his grandmother,$NEWLINE$Was lineal of the Lady Ermengare,$NEWLINE$Daughter to Charles the foresaid duke of Lorraine,$NEWLINE$By the which marriage the line of Charles the Great$NEWLINE$Was reunited to the crown of France.$NEWLINE$So that, as clear as is the summer’s sun,$NEWLINE$King Pepin’s title and Hugh Capet’s claim,$NEWLINE$King Lewis his satisfaction, all appear$NEWLINE$To hold in right and title of the female.
paragraphs.translated: intended for the realm of France. Nor did the French possess the Salic land until four hundred twenty-one years after the death of King Pharamond, incorrectly thought to be the founder of the law. He died in the year 426, and Charles the Great conquered the Saxons and settled Frenchmen in the region beyond the river Sala in the year 805. Besides, according to the French historians, King Pepin, who deposed Childeric, based his own claim to the crown of France on his descent from Blithild, the daughter of King Clothair. Another case: Hugh Capet, who usurped the crown from Charles the duke of Lorraine—sole male heir in a direct line from Charles the Great—passed himself off as heir to Lady Lingare, daughter of Charlemagne, who was the son of Lewis the Emperor (who was the son of Charles the Great), in order to give his claim to the throne more validity (though, in fact, the claim was completely false and worthless). Another case: King Lewis the Tenth, who was sole heir to the usurper Capet, could not rest easy as king until he was assured that Queen Isabel, his grandmother, was a direct descendent of the Lady Ermengare, daughter of the aforementioned Charles duke of Lorraine, by which marriage the line of Charles the Great was reunited with the throne of France. Thus, it should be clear as day that King Pepin’s title, Hugh Capet’s claim, and the resolution of King Lewis’s doubts all plainly derive from the female.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So do the kings of France unto this day,$NEWLINE$Howbeit they would hold up this Salic law$NEWLINE$To bar your Highness claiming from the female$NEWLINE$And rather choose to hide them in a net$NEWLINE$Than amply to imbar their crooked titles$NEWLINE$Usurped from you and your progenitors.
paragraphs.translated: To this day, the kings of France follow this unspoken rule, even though they point to this Salic law to bar your Highness from inheriting it through the female line. They prefer to obscure matters rather than reveal how corrupt their own claims to the French crown are. They usurped that crown from you and your ancestors.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$May I with right and conscience make this claim?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Can I justifiably and in good conscience make this claim?

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$The sin upon my head, dread sovereign,$NEWLINE$For in the Book of Numbers is it writ:$NEWLINE$“When the man dies, let the inheritance$NEWLINE$Descend unto the daughter.” Gracious lord,$NEWLINE$Stand for your own, unwind your bloody flag,$NEWLINE$Look back into your mighty ancestors.$NEWLINE$Go, my dread lord, to your great-grandsire’s tomb,$NEWLINE$From whom you claim. Invoke his warlike spirit$NEWLINE$And your great-uncle’s, Edward the Black Prince,$NEWLINE$Who on the French ground played a tragedy,$NEWLINE$Making defeat on the full power of France$NEWLINE$Whiles his most mighty father on a hill$NEWLINE$Stood smiling to behold his lion’s whelp$NEWLINE$Forage in blood of French nobility.$NEWLINE$O noble English, that could entertain$NEWLINE$With half their forces the full pride of France$NEWLINE$And let another half stand laughing by,$NEWLINE$All out of work and cold for action!
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$If not, mighty sovereign, let the blame be mine. For it is written in the book of Numbers: “When the man dies, let the inheritance descend unto the daughter.” Gracious lord, claim what is yours. Unfurl your banners of war. Take your mighty ancestors as models. Go to the tomb of your great-grandfather, from whom your own title to the crown derives. Invoke his warlike spirit and that of Edward the Black Prince, your great-uncle, who fought a tragic battle on French soil, routing the French army in full force while his mighty father stood by on a hilltop, smiling to see his son steeped in the blood of French noblemen. O noble English, who could take on the entire French army with only half their forces, leaving the other half to stand by, idle and laughing.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$Awake remembrance of these valiant dead$NEWLINE$And with your puissant arm renew their feats.$NEWLINE$You are their heir, you sit upon their throne,$NEWLINE$The blood and courage that renownèd them$NEWLINE$Runs in your veins; and my thrice-puissant liege$NEWLINE$Is in the very May-morn of his youth,$NEWLINE$Ripe for exploits and mighty enterprises.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$Awaken the memory of those valiant ancestors and with your own powerful arm make their deeds live again. You are their heir and sit on their throne, and the blood and courage that glorified them run in your veins. You, my most powerful sovereign, are in the very prime of youth, ripe for glorious deeds and great enterprises.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Your brother kings and monarchs of the earth$NEWLINE$Do all expect that you should rouse yourself$NEWLINE$As did the former lions of your blood.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$The other kings throughout the world all expect you to take the offensive, just like your lion-hearted forebears.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$They know your Grace hath cause and means and might;$NEWLINE$So hath your Highness. Never king of England$NEWLINE$Had nobles richer, and more loyal subjects,$NEWLINE$Whose hearts have left their bodies here in England$NEWLINE$And lie pavilioned in the fields of France.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$They know your Grace has justification, as well as the money and military strength. And so you do. No king of England was ever backed by wealthier nobles or more loyal subjects. Their bodies may remain here in England, but their hearts are encamped on the fields of France already.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Oh, let their bodies follow, my dear liege,$NEWLINE$With blood and sword and fire to win your right,$NEWLINE$In aid whereof we of the spiritualty$NEWLINE$Will raise your Highness such a mighty sum$NEWLINE$As never did the clergy at one time$NEWLINE$Bring in to any of your ancestors.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Oh, let their bodies follow, my dear king, to win back what’s rightfully yours with blood and sword and fire. And to that end, we, the clergy, will raise your Highness a sum greater than your ancestors were ever given at any one time.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We must not only arm t' invade the French,$NEWLINE$But lay down our proportions to defend$NEWLINE$Against the Scot, who will make road upon us$NEWLINE$With all advantages.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We must not only arm ourselves to invade France, but must also apportion troops to defend against invasion by the Scots, who will see this as a perfect opportunity to attack.

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$They of those marches, gracious sovereign,$NEWLINE$Shall be a wall sufficient to defend$NEWLINE$Our inland from the pilfering borderers.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Your subjects in the north, gracious sovereign, will provide a wall of defense against Scottish thieves across the border.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We do not mean the coursing snatchers only,$NEWLINE$But fear the main intendment of the Scot,$NEWLINE$Who hath been still a giddy neighbor to us.$NEWLINE$For you shall read that my great-grandfather$NEWLINE$Never went with his forces into France$NEWLINE$But that the Scot on his unfurnished kingdom$NEWLINE$Came pouring like the tide into a breach$NEWLINE$With ample and brim fullness of his force,$NEWLINE$Galling the gleanèd land with hot assays,$NEWLINE$Girding with grievous siege castles and towns,$NEWLINE$That England, being empty of defense,$NEWLINE$Hath shook and trembled at th' ill neighborhood.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I don’t mean merely bands of thieves. What we have to worry about is a full-scale invasion from Scotland—always an unreliable neighbor. You’ll find that my great-grandfather never went to war with France without Scotland making an attack on his undefended kingdom, pouring in full force like the tide through a gap in a dyke, troubling the depleted country with violent attacks, and laying siege to towns and castles. The whole of England, being unprotected, trembled with fear.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$She hath been then more feared than harmed, my liege,$NEWLINE$For hear her but exampled by herself:$NEWLINE$When all her chivalry hath been in France$NEWLINE$And she a mourning widow of her nobles,$NEWLINE$She hath herself not only well defended$NEWLINE$But taken and impounded as a stray$NEWLINE$The king of Scots, whom she did send to France$NEWLINE$To fill King Edward’s fame with prisoner kings$NEWLINE$And make her chronicle as rich with praise$NEWLINE$As is the ooze and bottom of the sea$NEWLINE$With sunken wrack and sumless treasuries.
paragraphs.translated: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$But the country was more frightened than hurt, my liege. Take this example: when all its knights have been in France and all its noblemen absent, England has not only defended itself well, but actually seized the Scottish king and penned him up like a stray dog. Then he was sent off to France. He enhanced King Edward’s fame, adding royalty to his captives and thus making England’s own history as rich with glory as the muddy floor of the sea is rich with sunken ships and innumerable treasures.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$But there’s a saying very old and true:$NEWLINE$“If that you will France win,$NEWLINE$Then with Scotland first begin.”$NEWLINE$For once the eagle England being in prey,$NEWLINE$To her unguarded nest the weasel Scot$NEWLINE$Comes sneaking and so sucks her princely eggs,$NEWLINE$Playing the mouse in absence of the cat,$NEWLINE$To ’tame and havoc more than she can eat.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$But here’s an old, true saying: “If you want to win France, start with Scotland.” For when the eagle England leaves her nest to seek prey, the weasel Scot always comes sneaking around to suck dry her princely eggs and, like the mouse when the cat’s away, destroy more than she can actually eat.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$It follows, then, the cat must stay at home.$NEWLINE$Yet that is but a crushed necessity,$NEWLINE$Since we have locks to safeguard necessaries$NEWLINE$And pretty traps to catch the petty thieves.$NEWLINE$While that the armèd hand doth fight abroad,$NEWLINE$Th' advisèd head defends itself at home.$NEWLINE$For government, though high and low and lower,$NEWLINE$Put into parts, doth keep in one consent,$NEWLINE$Congreeing in a full and natural close,$NEWLINE$Like music.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$It would follow from this that the cat should stay home. But that is a false conclusion, since we have locks to keep our valuables safe and clever traps to catch little thieves. While the armed hand fights in foreign lands, the wise head defends itself at home. For though the state is divided into different levels and functions, it all works in agreement for a unified purpose, a natural and perfect end such as we find in music.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$Therefore doth heaven divide$NEWLINE$The state of man in diverse functions,$NEWLINE$Setting endeavor in continual motion,$NEWLINE$To which is fixèd as an aim or butt$NEWLINE$Obedience; for so work the honeybees,$NEWLINE$Creatures that by a rule in nature teach$NEWLINE$The act of order to a peopled kingdom.$NEWLINE$They have a king and officers of sorts,$NEWLINE$Where some like magistrates correct at home,$NEWLINE$Others like merchants venture trade abroad,$NEWLINE$Others like soldiers armèd in their stings$NEWLINE$Make boot upon the summer’s velvet buds,$NEWLINE$Which pillage they with merry march bring home$NEWLINE$To the tent royal of their emperor,$NEWLINE$Who, busied in his majesty, surveys$NEWLINE$The singing masons building roofs of gold,$NEWLINE$The civil citizens kneading up the honey,$NEWLINE$The poor mechanic porters crowding in$NEWLINE$Their heavy burdens at his narrow gate,$NEWLINE$The sad-eyed justice with his surly hum$NEWLINE$Delivering o'er to executors pale$NEWLINE$The lazy yawning drone. I this infer:$NEWLINE$That many things, having full reference$NEWLINE$To one consent, may work contrariously,$NEWLINE$As many arrows loosèd several ways$NEWLINE$Come to one mark, as many ways meet in one town,$NEWLINE$As many fresh streams meet in one salt sea,$NEWLINE$As many lines close in the dial’s center,$NEWLINE$So may a thousand actions, once afoot,$NEWLINE$End in one purpose, and be all well borne$NEWLINE$Without defeat. Therefore to France, my liege!$NEWLINE$Divide your happy England into four,$NEWLINE$Whereof take you one quarter into France,$NEWLINE$And you withal shall make all Gallia shake.
paragraphs.translated:
CANTERBURY$NEWLINE$That is why God divided humanity into various functions, so as to keep human endeavor moving ever forward, the one single fixed element—the aim—being obedience. Honey bees operate in just such a communal way. In fact, you can learn a lot about how to run a well-ordered kingdom from these creatures. They have a king and officers of sorts. Some, like magistrates, dole out punishment at home, while others venture forth for commerce, like merchants. Still others, armed like soldiers with stingers, pillage the summer flowers, bringing the booty triumphantly home to the royal tent of their emperor, who is preoccupied with governing. The emperor supervises the masons as they build gold roofs, the ordinary citizens as they process the honey, the humble laborers as they crowd through the city’s narrow gate with their heavy burdens, and the solemn-looking judge (with his grouchy hum) as he delivers lazy, unproductive drones to pale executioners. From this, I conclude that many different elements can work toward one common end—just as many arrows, shot from different points, converge on a single target; just as many roads meet in a single town; just as many fresh streams empty into only one salt sea; just as the many radiuses of a
sundial unite at its center. Just so, a thousand actions, once set in motion, will result in one desired object, and all will be well carried out and have a successful end. Therefore, head to France, my liege! Divide your lucky England into four. If you take even one quarter with you to France, you will nevertheless make the whole country shake.$NEWLINE$sundial$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If we, with thrice such powers left at home,$NEWLINE$Cannot defend our own doors from the dog,$NEWLINE$Let us be worried, and our nation lose$NEWLINE$The name of hardiness and policy.
paragraphs.translated: If we cannot defend our country with three times such a power left at home, then we deserve to be harassed by an invader and lose our reputation as a powerful and politically savvy nation.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Call in the messengers sent from the Dauphin.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some attendants
paragraphs.translated: Some attendants exit.

paragraphs.original: Now are we well resolved, and by God’s help$NEWLINE$And yours, the noble sinews of our power,$NEWLINE$France being ours, we’ll bend it to our awe$NEWLINE$Or break it all to pieces. Or there we’ll sit,$NEWLINE$Ruling in large and ample empery$NEWLINE$O'er France and all her almost kingly dukedoms,$NEWLINE$Or lay these bones in an unworthy urn,$NEWLINE$Tombless, with no remembrance over them.$NEWLINE$Either our history shall with full mouth$NEWLINE$Speak freely of our acts, or else our grave,$NEWLINE$Like Turkish mute, shall have a tongueless mouth,$NEWLINE$Not worshipped with a waxen epitaph.
paragraphs.translated: Now I’ve made up my mind, and with God’s help—and yours, you nobles who are the mainstay of my power—I’ll force France to fear me, or I’ll break her into pieces, as she’s rightfully mine. Either I’ll sit, ruling with absolute authority over France and all her dukedoms, or I’ll lay these bones in a common grave, with no stone or inscription over them. Either the story of my deeds will be declaimed loudly and without restraint, or else my grave will remain speechless, like a Turkish mute, not honored with even an epitaph etched in wax.

paragraphs.original: Enter AMBASSADORS of France, with attendants$NEWLINE$AMBASSADORS
paragraphs.translated: French AMBASSADORS enter.$NEWLINE$AMBASSADORS

paragraphs.original: Now are we well prepared to know the pleasure$NEWLINE$Of our fair cousin Dauphin, for we hear$NEWLINE$Your greeting is from him, not from the king.
paragraphs.translated: I’m ready now to hear what my good cousin the Dauphin has to say—for I hear that the greeting you bear is from him, not the king.

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$May ’t please your Majesty to give us leave$NEWLINE$Freely to render what we have in charge,$NEWLINE$Or shall we sparingly show you far off$NEWLINE$The Dauphin’s meaning and our embassy?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Will your Majesty grant us permission to freely express the message we’ve been asked to convey? Or should we be tactful and only hint at what the Dauphin sent us to say?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We are no tyrant, but a Christian king,$NEWLINE$Unto whose grace our passion is as subject$NEWLINE$As is our wretches fettered in our prisons.$NEWLINE$Therefore with frank and with uncurbèd plainness$NEWLINE$Tell us the Dauphin’s mind.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I am no tyrant but a Christian king, whose emotions are as tightly controlled as the wretches who languish in our prisons. Therefore tell me the Dauphin’s mind frankly and without constraint.

paragraphs.original: AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Thus, then, in few:$NEWLINE$Your Highness, lately sending into France,$NEWLINE$Did claim some certain dukedoms in the right$NEWLINE$Of your great predecessor, King Edward the Third;$NEWLINE$In answer of which claim, the prince our master$NEWLINE$Says that you savor too much of your youth$NEWLINE$And bids you be advised there’s naught in France$NEWLINE$That can be with a nimble galliard won.$NEWLINE$You cannot revel into dukedoms there.$NEWLINE$He therefore sends you, meeter for your spirit,$NEWLINE$This tun of treasure, and, in lieu of this,$NEWLINE$Desires you let the dukedoms that you claim$NEWLINE$Hear no more of you. This the Dauphin speaks.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST AMBASSADOR$NEWLINE$Here it is then, in as few words as possible. Your Highness recently sent word to France claiming certain dukedoms as your own, in the name of your great ancestor, King Edward the Third. By way of answer, the prince our master says that you’re acting like the immature youth that you are. He warns you to take note: there’s nothing in France that you can win by dancing. You can’t party your way into dukedoms there. He therefore sends you this casket of treasure as a gift more suited to your character. And in return for this gift, he wishes you to drop your claim to the dukedoms. This is the Dauphin’s message.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What treasure, uncle?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s the treasure, uncle?

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Tennis balls, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Tennis balls, my liege.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We are glad the Dauphin is so pleasant with us.$NEWLINE$His present and your pains we thank you for.$NEWLINE$When we have matched our rackets to these balls,$NEWLINE$We will in France, by God’s grace, play a set$NEWLINE$Shall strike his father’s crown into the hazard.$NEWLINE$Tell him he hath made a match with such a wrangler$NEWLINE$That all the courts of France will be disturbed$NEWLINE$With chases. And we understand him well,$NEWLINE$How he comes o'er us with our wilder days,$NEWLINE$Not measuring what use we made of them.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m happy the Dauphin has such a good sense of humor. Thank you for his present and your trouble. Once I’ve put my rackets to these balls, I’ll play a set in France, God willing, that will knock his father’s crown right out of the court. Tell him he’s got himself such a willing opponent that we’ll be chasing balls all over France. And I understand perfectly his sneering reference to my wilder days. He doesn’t realize how useful they were to me. For a long time, I didn’t value this humble throne of England, and therefore lived at some remove and gave myself over to riotous living.$NEWLINE$Men tend to be at their most irresponsible when they’re away from home. But tell the Dauphin I will retain the dignity of kingship and appear all the more royal and glorious on the throne of France. Precisely for this purpose I went about like a commoner and experienced the life of the ordinary man. Now I’ll rise there with

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: We never valued this poor seat of England$NEWLINE$And therefore, living hence, did give ourself$NEWLINE$To barbarous license, as ’tis ever common$NEWLINE$That men are merriest when they are from home.$NEWLINE$But tell the Dauphin I will keep my state,$NEWLINE$Be like a king, and show my sail of greatness$NEWLINE$When I do rouse me in my throne of France,$NEWLINE$For that I have laid by my majesty$NEWLINE$And plodded like a man for working days.$NEWLINE$But I will rise there with so full a glory$NEWLINE$That I will dazzle all the eyes of France,$NEWLINE$Yea, strike the Dauphin blind to look on us.$NEWLINE$And tell the pleasant prince this mock of his$NEWLINE$Hath turned his balls to gun-stones, and his soul$NEWLINE$Shall stand sore chargèd for the wasteful vengeance$NEWLINE$That shall fly with them; for many a thousand widows$NEWLINE$Shall this his mock mock out of their dear husbands,$NEWLINE$Mock mothers from their sons, mock castles down,$NEWLINE$And some are yet ungotten and unborn$NEWLINE$That shall have cause to curse the Dauphin’s scorn.$NEWLINE$But this lies all within the will of God,$NEWLINE$To whom I do appeal, and in whose name$NEWLINE$Tell you the Dauphin I am coming on,$NEWLINE$To venge me as I may and to put forth$NEWLINE$My rightful hand in a well-hallowed cause.$NEWLINE$So get you hence in peace. And tell the Dauphin$NEWLINE$His jest will savor but of shallow wit$NEWLINE$When thousands weep more than did laugh at it.$NEWLINE$—Convey them with safe conduct.—Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: such glory that I’ll dazzle all the eyes of France. I’ll shine so brightly that even the Dauphin will be struck blind. And tell the laughing prince that this joke of his has transformed his tennis balls into cannon balls, and the destructive vengeance they bring with them will be his responsibility. His mocking will mock many thousands of widows out of their husbands. It will mock mothers out of their sons, and mock castles down. There are people yet unborn and unconceived who will have reason to curse the Dauphin’s scorn. But all this lies with God, to whom I do appeal. In God’s name, inform the Dauphin I am coming, to avenge myself and to put forth my rightful hand in a sanctified cause. So go in peace. And tell the Dauphin his joke will look pretty stupid when thousands more weep than ever laughed at it. (to attendants) Give them safe conduct.—Farewell.$NEWLINE$(to attendants)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt AMBASSADORS, with attendants$NEWLINE$AMBASSADORS
paragraphs.translated: The AMBASSADORS exit, with some attendants.$NEWLINE$AMBASSADORS

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$This was a merry message.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$That was a humorous message.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We hope to make the sender blush at it.$NEWLINE$Therefore, my lords, omit no happy hour$NEWLINE$That may give furth'rance to our expedition;$NEWLINE$For we have now no thought in us but France,$NEWLINE$Save those to God, that run before our business.$NEWLINE$Therefore let our proportions for these wars$NEWLINE$Be soon collected, and all things thought upon$NEWLINE$That may with reasonable swiftness add$NEWLINE$More feathers to our wings. For, God before,$NEWLINE$We’ll chide this Dauphin at his father’s door.$NEWLINE$Therefore let every man now task his thought,$NEWLINE$That this fair action may on foot be brought.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I hope to make the sender blush for it. Now, lords, don’t let slip any opportunity that might be advantageous for our expedition. My thoughts are now bent entirely on France—except my thoughts about God, who takes precedence over this undertaking. Therefore, let’s set about mustering the requisite number of troops and give consideration to anything that can be expected to speed our enterprise. For, with God on our side, we’ll chastise this prince on his father’s own doorstep. Therefore, let every man give some thought to how this noble expedition may be undertaken.

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Now all the youth of England are on fire,$NEWLINE$And silken dalliance in the wardrobe lies.$NEWLINE$Now thrive the armorers, and honor’s thought$NEWLINE$Reigns solely in the breast of every man.$NEWLINE$They sell the pasture now to buy the horse,$NEWLINE$Following the mirror of all Christian kings$NEWLINE$With wingèd heels, as English Mercurys.$NEWLINE$For now sits Expectation in the air$NEWLINE$And hides a sword, from hilts unto the point,$NEWLINE$With crowns imperial, crowns and coronets$NEWLINE$Promised to Harry and his followers.$NEWLINE$The French, advised by good intelligence$NEWLINE$Of this most dreadful preparation,$NEWLINE$Shake in their fear, and with pale policy$NEWLINE$Seek to divert the English purposes.$NEWLINE$O England, model to thy inward greatness,$NEWLINE$Like little body with a mighty heart,$NEWLINE$What might’st thou do, that honor would thee do,$NEWLINE$Were all thy children kind and natural!$NEWLINE$But see, thy fault France hath in thee found out,$NEWLINE$A nest of hollow bosoms, which he fills$NEWLINE$With treacherous crowns, and three corrupted men—$NEWLINE$One, Richard, Earl of Cambridge, and the second,$NEWLINE$Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham, and the third,$NEWLINE$Sir Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland—$NEWLINE$Have, for the gilt of France (Oh, guilt indeed!),$NEWLINE$Confirmed conspiracy with fearful France,$NEWLINE$And by their hands this grace of kings must die,$NEWLINE$If hell and treason hold their promises,
paragraphs.translated:
CHORUS$NEWLINE$Now all the young men of England are inspired and have stored their party clothes in the closet. Armorers are doing great business, and all men think about is honor. People are selling off their land to buy warhorses so they can follow the exemplary king into battle as if they had winged feet, like
Mercury. There’s a sense of anticipation in the air. In the minds of Harry and his followers, visions of the kingdoms, spoils, and titles to be won eclipse thoughts of actual fighting. The French, meanwhile, have been forewarned of all this preparation by their spies and tremble in fear. They seek to derail the English with cowardly tricks. Oh, England! You are physically small but inwardly great, like a mighty heart enclosed in a small body. There is nothing you couldn’t accomplish if all your subjects were loyal and loving! But, see, the king of France has detected your weak spot: a nest of faithless traitors, whose treachery he has purchased with gold. Three corrupt men—Richard, earl of Cambridge; Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham; and Sir Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland—have agreed to conspire with the French in exchange for money. The gracious king will die by their hands in Southampton before he sets sail for France—if Hell and treason have their way. Stick with us, ladies and gentlemen, and we’ll make a play, conquering space and time. Imagine that the traitors have been paid and made their choice. The king has left London, and the scene now$NEWLINE$Mercury$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Ere he take ship for France, and in Southampton.$NEWLINE$Linger your patience on, and we’ll digest$NEWLINE$Th' abuse of distance, force a play.$NEWLINE$The sum is paid, the traitors are agreed,$NEWLINE$The king is set from London, and the scene$NEWLINE$Is now transported, gentles, to Southampton.$NEWLINE$There is the playhouse now, there must you sit,$NEWLINE$And thence to France shall we convey you safe$NEWLINE$And bring you back, charming the narrow seas$NEWLINE$To give you gentle pass; for, if we may,$NEWLINE$We’ll not offend one stomach with our play.$NEWLINE$But, till the king come forth, and not till then,$NEWLINE$Unto Southampton do we shift our scene.
paragraphs.translated: shifts, friends, to Southampton. That’s where you must pretend the theater is; that’s where you must sit. From there we’ll safely carry you to France and back, calming the waters of the Channel to provide you with a smooth voyage. For if we can help it, we’d just as soon nobody was made sick by our play. But we won’t shift the scene to Southampton until Henry reappears.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter Corporal NYM and Lieutenant BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: Corporal NYM and Lieutenant BARDOLPH enter.$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Well met, Corporal Nym.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Good to see you, Corporal Nym.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Lieutenant Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Good day, Lieutenant Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$What, are Ancient Pistol and you friends yet?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Tell me, are you and Ensign Pistol friends again yet?

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$For my part, I care not. I say little, but when time shall serve, there shall be smiles; but that shall be as it may. I dare not fight, but I will wink and hold out mine iron. It is a simple one, but what though? It will toast cheese, and it will endure cold as another man’s sword will, and there’s an end.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$For my part, I really don’t care. I don’t say much, but when the time comes, we’ll smile at each other. But that’s as it may be. I won’t fight, but I can close my eyes and take a swipe with my sword—just a simple sword, but so what? It’s good enough to toast cheese, and it will survive cold as well as another man’s sword. And that’s that.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I will bestow a breakfast to make you friends; and we’ll be all three sworn brothers to France. Let ’t be so, good Corporal Nym.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I’ll buy you both breakfast if it will make you two friends. Then we can all three be comrades on our way to France. How about it, Corporal Nym?

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Faith, I will live so long as I may, that’s the certain of it. And when I cannot live any longer, I will do as I may. That is my rest; that is the rendezvous of it.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Well, I will live until I die, that’s for sure, and when I can’t live anymore, I’ll deal with it. That’s it. That’s really all I can say.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$It is certain, corporal, that he is married to Nell Quickly, and certainly she did you wrong, for you were troth-plight to her.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$It’s true, corporal, that he is married to Nell Quickly. And it’s true that she did you wrong, since you were engaged to her.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$I cannot tell. Things must be as they may. Men may sleep, and they may have their throats about them at that time, and some say knives have edges. It must be as it may. Though patience be a tired mare, yet she will plod. There must be conclusions. Well, I cannot tell.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$It’s not for me to say. Things are what they are. Men may sleep, and when they do they may have their throats with them, and some people say knives have blades. What must be must be, and though my patience is worn out, it will last a little longer. There must be some resolution. Well, it’s not for me to say.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL and HOSTESS$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$HOSTESS
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL and HOSTESS QUICKLY enter.$NEWLINE$HOSTESS$NEWLINE$QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Here comes Ancient Pistol and his wife. Good corporal, be patient here.—How now, mine host Pistol?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Here comes Ensign Pistol and his wife. Be cool now, corporal.—How are you, Pistol, my good host?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Base tyke, call’st thou me host?$NEWLINE$Now, by this hand, I swear, I scorn the term,$NEWLINE$Nor shall my Nell keep lodgers.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$You peasant dog, are you calling me a host? I swear, I scorn the word. My Nell isn’t going to be taking any lodgers.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$No, by my troth, not long, for we cannot lodge and board a dozen or fourteen gentlewomen that live honestly by the prick of their needles but it will be thought we keep a bawdy house straight.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$No, not for long, that’s certain. For we couldn’t even put up a dozen or so nice girls who make an honest living sewing without our neighbors thinking we were running a brothel.

paragraphs.original: NYM and PISTOL draw$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$PISTOL
paragraphs.translated: NYM and PISTOL draw their swords.$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$PISTOL

paragraphs.original: Oh, well-a-day, Lady! If he be not hewn now, we shall see willful adultery and murder committed.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, dear. If he isn’t cut down in his tracks right now, we’ll see
willful adultery and murder committed.$NEWLINE$willful adultery and murder$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Good lieutenant, good corporal, offer nothing here.
paragraphs.translated: Good lieutenant, good corporal, don’t fight each other here.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Pish!
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Pish!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Pish for thee, Iceland dog,$NEWLINE$Thou prick-eared cur of Iceland!
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Pish to you, you mangy dog, you pointy-eared Icelandic mutt.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Good Corporal Nym, show thy valor and put up your sword.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$Corporal Nym, be a man and put away your sword.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Will you shog off? (to PISTOL) I would have you solus.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$solus
paragraphs.translated:
NYM$NEWLINE$Get lost, will you? (to PISTOL) I’d like to get you
solus.$NEWLINE$to$NEWLINE$solus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$“Solus,” egregious dog? O viper vile,$NEWLINE$“Solus,”$NEWLINE$The solus in thy most marvelous face,$NEWLINE$solus$NEWLINE$The solus in thy teeth and in thy throat$NEWLINE$solus$NEWLINE$And in thy hateful lungs, yea, in thy maw, perdy,$NEWLINE$And, which is worse, within thy nasty mouth!$NEWLINE$I do retort the solus in thy bowels,$NEWLINE$solus$NEWLINE$For I can take, and Pistol’s cock is up,$NEWLINE$And flashing fire will follow.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Solus, you unspeakable dog? You loathsome snake, I throw your solus in that weird face of yours, in your teeth and your throat and in your hateful lungs, and even worse, in your nasty mouth! Shove that solus into your bowels, because I can take you. My gun is cocked and ready to fire.$NEWLINE$Solus,$NEWLINE$solus$NEWLINE$solus

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$I am not Barbason; you cannot conjure me. I have an humor to knock you indifferently well. If you grow foul with me, Pistol, I will scour you with my rapier, as I may, in fair terms. If you would walk off, I would prick your guts a little in good terms, as I may, and that’s the humor of it.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$I am not some fiend of hell: you can’t get rid of me with spells. I’m in a mood to beat you up pretty good. If you get nasty with me, Pistol, I’ll stab you with my sword, in fair play. If you’d like to step aside with me, I’ll give you a little prick in the guts, all in fair play, if I can, and that’s the way it is.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$O braggart vile and damnèd furious wight,$NEWLINE$The grave doth gape, and doting death is near.$NEWLINE$Therefore exhale.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$You revolting braggart and hellish creature! Your grave is gaping open, and your death is near. So take your last breath.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Hear me, hear me what I say: he that strikes the first stroke,$NEWLINE$I’ll run him up to the hilts, as I am a soldier. (draws)$NEWLINE$(draws)
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Listen, listen to what I say: whoever strikes first, I’ll run him through with my sword, as sure as I’m a soldier. (drawing his sword)$NEWLINE$(drawing his sword)

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$An oath of mickle might, and fury shall abate.$NEWLINE$Give me thy fist, thy forefoot to me give.$NEWLINE$Thy spirits are most tall.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$That’s an oath of great power, and our fury must subside. ( PISTOL and NYM sheath their swords) Give me your hand—your forefoot. You have a brave spirit.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$sheath their swords)

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$I will cut thy throat one time or other in fair terms, that is the humor of it.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$I’ll cut your throat, sooner or later—that’s just how it is.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Couple à gorge, that is the word. I defy thee again.$NEWLINE$Couple à gorge$NEWLINE$O hound of Crete, think’st thou my spouse to get?$NEWLINE$No, to the spital go,$NEWLINE$And from the powd'ring tub of infamy$NEWLINE$Fetch forth the lazar kite of Cressid’s kind,$NEWLINE$Doll Tearsheet she by name, and her espouse.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Couple à gorge is the word for what you’re trying to say. I defy you again. You dog, do you think you’ll take my wife? No, go to the hospital, into the ward where they treat venereal disease, and get yourself a leprous, diseased prostitute like Doll Tearsheet and marry her.$NEWLINE$Couple à gorge$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I have, and I will hold, the quondam Quickly$NEWLINE$For the only she, And—pauca—there’s enough. Go to.$NEWLINE$pauca—
paragraphs.translated: I won the former Mistress Quickly and I’ll keep her as my only wife, and—Damn it! That’s enough. Come on!

paragraphs.original: Enter the BOY$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: A BOY enters.$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Mine host Pistol, you must come to my master and your hostess. He is very sick and would to bed.—Good Bardolph, put thy face between his sheets, and do the office of a warming-pan. Faith, he’s very ill.
paragraphs.translated:
BOY$NEWLINE$My host Pistol, you must come to my master. You too, my hostess: he is very sick and should be put to bed. Bardolph, put your face between his sheets and act as a
warming pan. Really, he’s very sick!$NEWLINE$warming pan$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Away, you rogue!
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Get out of here, you punk!

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$By my troth, he’ll yield the crow a pudding one of these days. The king has killed his heart. Good husband, come home presently.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$I swear, he’ll be food for the crows soon. The king has broken his heart. Good husband, come home soon.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt HOSTESS and BOY$NEWLINE$HOSTESS$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS QUICKLY and BOY exit.$NEWLINE$HOSTESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Come, shall I make you two friends? We must to France together. Why the devil should we keep knives to cut one another’s throats?
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Come on, can I get you two to make up? We have to go to France together: why should we cut each other’s throats?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let floods o'erswell and fiends for food howl on!
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let rivers flood and fiends howl for food!

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$You’ll pay me the eight shillings I won of you at betting?
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Are you going to pay the eight shillings I won from you in a bet?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Base is the slave that pays.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Paying debts is for peasants.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$That now I will have—that’s the humor of it.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$I’m going to take it from you now. That’s how it is.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$As manhood shall compound. Push home.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$We’ll see, won’t we? Do your best.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: They draw
paragraphs.translated: They draw their swords.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$By this sword, he that makes the first thrust, I’ll kill him. By this sword, I will.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$By this sword, I’ll kill whichever one of you makes the first thrust. By this sword, I will.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$“Sword” is an oath, and oaths must have their course.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$“By this sword” is an oath, and oaths must be kept.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Corporal Nym, an thou wilt be friends, be friends; an thou wilt not, why then be enemies with me too. Prithee, put up.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Corporal Nym, if you want to be friends, be friends. If not, then you can be my enemy, too. Come on, put it away.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$A noble shalt thou have, and present pay,$NEWLINE$And liquor likewise will I give to thee,$NEWLINE$And friendship shall combine, and brotherhood.$NEWLINE$I’ll live by Nym, and Nym shall live by me.$NEWLINE$Is not this just? For I shall subtler be$NEWLINE$Unto the camp, and profits will accrue.$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’ll give you a
noble right now, and I’ll give you liquor, too, and friendship and brotherhood. I’ll live for Nym, and Nym will live for me. Is that fair? For I’ll be selling provisions to the troops, and there’ll be profits to go around. Give me your hand.$NEWLINE$noble$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$I shall have my noble?
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$I’ll get my noble?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$In cash, most justly paid.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$In cash.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Well, then, that’s the humor of ’t.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Well, then, that’s how it is.

paragraphs.original: Enter HOSTESS$NEWLINE$HOSTESS
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS QUICKLY enters.$NEWLINE$HOSTESS QUICKLY

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$As ever you come of women, come in quickly to Sir John. Ah, poor heart, he is so shaked of a burning quotidian tertian that it is most lamentable to behold. Sweet men, come to him.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS QUICKLY$NEWLINE$If you ever had a mother, come in quickly to Sir John. The poor thing, he is so shaken with a fever that it’s terrible to see. Sweet men, come to him.

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$The king hath run bad humors on the knight, that’s the even of it.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$The king has done him a bad turn. That’s all there is to it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Nym, thou hast spoke the right.$NEWLINE$His heart is fracted and corroborate.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$Nym, what you say is true. His heart is broken and
corroborate.$NEWLINE$corroborate$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$The king is a good king, but it must be as it may. He passes some humors and careers.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$The king is a good king, but things must be as they may. He has his moods and his ways.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let us condole the knight, for, lambkins, we will live.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let us go sit with the knight; for, my little lambs, we will survive him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter EXETER, BEDFORD, and WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: EXETER, BEDFORD, and WESTMORELAND enter.$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$'Fore God, his grace is bold to trust these traitors.
paragraphs.translated: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$I must say, the king is taking a bold risk letting these traitors go free.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$They shall be apprehended by and by.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$They’ll be arrested in a little while.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$How smooth and even they do bear themselves,$NEWLINE$As if allegiance in their bosoms sat$NEWLINE$Crownèd with faith and constant loyalty.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$How smooth and cool they seem! Just as if they were perfectly loyal and faithful.

paragraphs.original: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$The king hath note of all that they intend,$NEWLINE$By interception which they dream not of.
paragraphs.translated: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$The king has been informed of all their plans, but they have no idea.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Nay, but the man that was his bedfellow,$NEWLINE$Whom he hath dulled and cloyed with gracious favors—$NEWLINE$That he should, for a foreign purse, so sell$NEWLINE$His sovereign’s life to death and treachery!
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$No, but it’s unbelievable that the man who was his dearest friend, a man he has showered with love and favor, would repay the king with treachery, selling his own sovereign’s life to a foreign power!

paragraphs.original: Trumpets sound. Enter KING HENRY, SCROOP, CAMBRIDGE, GREY, and attendants$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$SCROOP$NEWLINE$CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$GREY
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound. KING HENRY, SCROOP, CAMBRIDGE, and GREY enter, with attendants.$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$SCROOP$NEWLINE$CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$GREY

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now sits the wind fair, and we will aboard.$NEWLINE$—My Lord of Cambridge, and my kind Lord of Masham,$NEWLINE$And you, my gentle knight, give me your thoughts.$NEWLINE$Think you not that the powers we bear with us$NEWLINE$Will cut their passage through the force of France,$NEWLINE$Doing the execution and the act$NEWLINE$For which we have in head assembled them?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now that the wind is favorable, let’s board the ship.$NEWLINE$—My Lord of Cambridge and my good Lord of Masham and you, my noble knight, what do you think? Will our army cut a swath through the fighting force of France, achieving and accomplishing everything I’ve assembled them to do?

paragraphs.original: SCROOP$NEWLINE$No doubt, my liege, if each man do his best.
paragraphs.translated: SCROOP$NEWLINE$No doubt it will, my liege, if each man does his best.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I doubt not that, since we are well-persuaded$NEWLINE$We carry not a heart with us from hence$NEWLINE$That grows not in a fair consent with ours,$NEWLINE$Nor leave not one behind that doth not wish$NEWLINE$Success and conquest to attend on us.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I have no doubt about that, since I know there isn’t a man among us who isn’t with me wholeheartedly, or a soul left behind who doesn’t wish us success and conquest.

paragraphs.original: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$Never was monarch better feared and loved$NEWLINE$Than is your Majesty. There’s not, I think, a subject$NEWLINE$That sits in heart-grief and uneasiness$NEWLINE$Under the sweet shade of your government.
paragraphs.translated: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$There never was a monarch better feared and loved than yourself, your Majesty. I don’t think there’s a single unhappy subject living under the protection of your government.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$True. Those that were your father’s enemies$NEWLINE$Have steeped their galls in honey, and do serve you$NEWLINE$With hearts create of duty and of zeal.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$True. Those who were bitter enemies of your father in his time have turned their bitterness to sweetness, serving you loyally and wholeheartedly.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We therefore have great cause of thankfulness$NEWLINE$And shall forget the office of our hand$NEWLINE$Sooner than quittance of desert and merit$NEWLINE$According to the weight and worthiness.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes, I have great cause to be thankful. I’m more likely to forget how to use my own hand than how to reward virtue and merit as they deserve.

paragraphs.original: SCROOP$NEWLINE$So service shall with steelèd sinews toil,$NEWLINE$And labor shall refresh itself with hope$NEWLINE$To do your Grace incessant services.
paragraphs.translated: SCROOP$NEWLINE$And so your subjects serve you all the more energetically, hopeful of success and reward.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We judge no less.—Uncle of Exeter,$NEWLINE$Enlarge the man committed yesterday$NEWLINE$That railed against our person. We consider$NEWLINE$It was excess of wine that set him on,$NEWLINE$And on his more advice we pardon him.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I expect no less. Uncle of Exeter, release the man who was arrested yesterday for railing against me. I believe he only did it because he drank too much, and now that he’s had a chance to think about his actions, I can pardon him.

paragraphs.original: SCROOP$NEWLINE$That’s mercy, but too much security.$NEWLINE$Let him be punished, sovereign, lest example$NEWLINE$Breed, by his sufferance, more of such a kind.
paragraphs.translated: SCROOP$NEWLINE$That’s merciful but a bit careless. He should be punished, your Majesty. If we tolerate such behavior, we’re in danger of encouraging it.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, let us yet be merciful.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, let us be merciful anyway.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$So may Your Highness, and yet punish, too.
paragraphs.translated: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$Your Highness could be merciful but still punish.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$Sir, you show great mercy if you give him life$NEWLINE$After the taste of much correction.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$Sir, it would be merciful to let him live after beating him severely.$NEWLINE$after

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Alas, your too much love and care of me$NEWLINE$Are heavy orisons 'gainst this poor wretch.$NEWLINE$If little faults proceeding on distemper$NEWLINE$Shall not be winked at, how shall we stretch our eye$NEWLINE$When capital crimes, chewed, swallowed, and digested,$NEWLINE$Appear before us? We’ll yet enlarge that man,$NEWLINE$Though Cambridge, Scroop, and Grey, in their dear care$NEWLINE$And tender preservation of our person,$NEWLINE$Would have him punished. And now to our French causes.$NEWLINE$Who are the late commissioners?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m afraid your great love and concern for me lead you to deal too harshly with this poor fellow. If minor lapses caused by drunkenness are not to be tolerated, how will we punish capital crimes that result from much planning and forethought? No, I’ll have that man released, despite the fact that Cambridge, Scroop, and Grey, in their extreme concern for my safety, would prefer that he were punished. And now, let’s turn to our business with the French. Who are the new commissioners?

paragraphs.original: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$I one, my lord.$NEWLINE$Your Highness bade me ask for it today.
paragraphs.translated: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$I am one, my lord. Your Highness told me to ask for my commission today.

paragraphs.original: SCROOP$NEWLINE$So did you me, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: SCROOP$NEWLINE$You told me to do the same, my liege.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$And I, my royal sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$And me, too, my royal sovereign.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then, Richard, Earl of Cambridge, there is yours.$NEWLINE$—There yours, Lord Scroop of Masham.$NEWLINE$—And, sir knight, Grey of Northumberland, this same is yours. (gives each of them a paper)$NEWLINE$(gives each of them a paper)$NEWLINE$—Read them, and know I know your worthiness.$NEWLINE$—My Lord of Westmoreland and uncle Exeter,$NEWLINE$We will aboard tonight.—Why, how now, gentlemen?$NEWLINE$What see you in those papers, that you lose$NEWLINE$So much complexion?—Look you, how they change.$NEWLINE$Their cheeks are paper.—Why, what read you there$NEWLINE$That have so cowarded and chased your blood$NEWLINE$Out of appearance?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$In that case, there is yours, Richard Earl of Cambridge; there yours, Lord Scroop of Masham; and, sir knight, Grey of Northumberland, this one is yours. (he gives each of them a piece of paper) Read them, and trust that I recognize your true worth. My Lord of Westmoreland, and uncle Exeter, we will set sail night.—Why, what’s this, gentlemen! What’s in those papers that makes you change color?—Look how pale they’re turning! Their cheeks are like paper.—What are you reading that makes you turn white?$NEWLINE$(he gives each of them a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
