paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$I do confess my fault,$NEWLINE$And do submit me to Your Highness' mercy.
paragraphs.translated: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$I confess my crime and throw myself on your Highness’s mercy.

paragraphs.original: GREY, SCROOP$NEWLINE$To which we all appeal.
paragraphs.translated: GREY AND SCROOP$NEWLINE$To which we all appeal.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$The mercy that was quick in us but late$NEWLINE$By your own counsel is suppressed and killed.$NEWLINE$You must not dare, for shame, to talk of mercy,$NEWLINE$For your own reasons turn into your bosoms,$NEWLINE$As dogs upon their masters, worrying you.$NEWLINE$—See you, my princes and my noble peers,$NEWLINE$These English monsters. My Lord of Cambridge here,$NEWLINE$You know how apt our love was to accord$NEWLINE$To furnish him with all appurtenants$NEWLINE$Belonging to his honor, and this man$NEWLINE$Hath, for a few light crowns, lightly conspired,$NEWLINE$And sworn unto the practices of France,$NEWLINE$To kill us here in Hampton; to the which$NEWLINE$This knight, no less for bounty bound to us$NEWLINE$Than Cambridge is, hath likewise sworn.—But Oh,$NEWLINE$What shall I say to thee, Lord Scroop, thou cruel,$NEWLINE$Ingrateful, savage, and inhuman creature?$NEWLINE$Thou that didst bear the key of all my counsels,$NEWLINE$That knew’st the very bottom of my soul,$NEWLINE$That almost mightst have coined me into gold,$NEWLINE$Wouldst thou have practiced on me for thy use—$NEWLINE$May it be possible that foreign hire$NEWLINE$Could out of thee extract one spark of evil$NEWLINE$That might annoy my finger? 'Tis so strange$NEWLINE$That, though the truth of it stands off as gross$NEWLINE$As black and white, my eye will scarcely see it.$NEWLINE$Treason and murder ever kept together$NEWLINE$As two yoke-devils sworn to either’s purpose,$NEWLINE$Working so grossly in a natural cause$NEWLINE$That admiration did not whoop at them.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$The mercy that was alive in me a moment ago was smothered and killed by your own advice. For shame, don’t talk of mercy. Your own arguments turn against you, like dogs who bite their own masters.—Princes and noble peers, take a look at these English monsters. Cambridge here, you know how I favored him and treated him with every respect due his rank. He was bought for a few coins, entering easily into this conspiracy with the French, promising to kill me here in Southhampton. And this knight, whom I’ve treated as generously as I have Cambridge, also joined the plot. But, oh, what can I say to you, Lord Scroop? You cruel, ungrateful, savage, and inhuman creature! You who had access to all my thoughts, who knew me to the inmost part of my soul, who could have had any amount of gold from me if you’d needed it and only asked me: is it possible that a foreign power could find in you even enough evil to injure one of my fingers? Though the truth of your treachery is as plain as black on white, I can scarcely believe it, it’s so past understanding. Treason and murder have always gone together, like two devils joined in a common purpose. That’s natural. But you, against all reason, added something new to the equation. You added the sheer improbability that you could do this. Whatever fiend it was that seduced you must win the prize for excellence in hell. All other devils who tempt people to treason patch together some motive, put together from shreds

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But thou, 'gainst all proportion, didst bring in$NEWLINE$Wonder to wait on treason and on murder,$NEWLINE$And whatsoever cunning fiend it was$NEWLINE$That wrought upon thee so preposterously$NEWLINE$Hath got the voice in hell for excellence.$NEWLINE$All other devils that suggest by treasons$NEWLINE$Do botch and bungle up damnation$NEWLINE$With patches, colors, and with forms being fetched$NEWLINE$From glist'ring semblances of piety.$NEWLINE$But he that tempered thee bade thee stand up,$NEWLINE$Gave thee no instance why thou shouldst do treason,$NEWLINE$Unless to dub thee with the name of traitor.$NEWLINE$If that same demon that hath gulled thee thus$NEWLINE$Should with his lion gait walk the whole world,$NEWLINE$He might return to vasty Tartar back$NEWLINE$And tell the legions “I can never win$NEWLINE$A soul so easy as that Englishman’s.”$NEWLINE$Oh, how hast thou with jealousy infected$NEWLINE$The sweetness of affiance! Show men dutiful?$NEWLINE$Why, so didst thou. Seem they grave and learnèd?$NEWLINE$Why, so didst thou. Come they of noble family?$NEWLINE$Why, so didst thou. Seem they religious?$NEWLINE$Why, so didst thou. Or are they spare in diet,$NEWLINE$Free from gross passion or of mirth or anger,$NEWLINE$Constant in spirit, not swerving with the blood,$NEWLINE$Garnished and decked in modest complement,$NEWLINE$Not working with the eye without the ear,$NEWLINE$And but in purgèd judgment trusting neither?$NEWLINE$Such and so finely bolted didst thou seem.$NEWLINE$And thus thy fall hath left a kind of blot$NEWLINE$To mark the full-fraught man and best endued$NEWLINE$With some suspicion. I will weep for thee,$NEWLINE$For this revolt of thine methinks is like$NEWLINE$Another fall of man.—Their faults are open.$NEWLINE$Arrest them to the answer of the law,$NEWLINE$And God acquit them of their practices.
paragraphs.translated:
and patches of righteousness. But the devil that tempted you gave you no reason why you should commit treason other than to win the name of traitor. The demon who seduced you could stride the world over with the proud gait of a lion, could return to hell and tell the devil’s legions, “I will never win another soul as easily as I won that Englishman’s.” How you have poisoned my faith in people! Now I am suspicious of everyone. Are there men who appear dutiful? Why, so did you. Are there those who seem serious and knowledgeable? Why, so did you. Do they come from good families? Why, so did you. Do they seem religious? Why, so did you. Do they live in moderation, free from excessive emotion—stable rather than changing their minds constantly—tastefully dressed, not merely seeing but also listening, and trusting no impression without confirmation? That’s how sound a man you appeared. Your fall has left a blot that opens even the best and brightest to suspicion. You have broken my heart. This treachery of yours is like the second
Fall of man.—Their crimes are revealed. Arrest and punish them according to the law, and may God pardon them for what they would have done.$NEWLINE$Fall of man$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of$NEWLINE$Richard, Earl of Cambridge.$NEWLINE$—I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of$NEWLINE$Henry, Lord Scroop of Masham.$NEWLINE$—I arrest thee of high treason, by the name of$NEWLINE$Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Richard Earl of Cambridge, I arrest you for high treason. Henry Lord Scroop of Masham, I arrest you for high treason. Thomas Grey, knight, of Northumberland, I arrest you for high treason.

paragraphs.original: SCROOP$NEWLINE$Our purposes God justly hath discovered,$NEWLINE$And I repent my fault more than my death,$NEWLINE$Which I beseech Your Highness to forgive,$NEWLINE$Although my body pay the price of it.
paragraphs.translated: SCROOP$NEWLINE$A just God has discovered our plot. I regret my crime more than my death, and I beg your Highness to forgive me, while punishing my body with death.

paragraphs.original: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$For me, the gold of France did not seduce,$NEWLINE$Although I did admit it as a motive$NEWLINE$The sooner to effect what I intended;$NEWLINE$But God be thankèd for prevention,$NEWLINE$Which I in sufferance heartily will rejoice,$NEWLINE$Beseeching God and you to pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$For my part, I didn’t do it for the money, though I admit the money encouraged me to do what I was planning sooner. But I thank God that I failed in my scheme, and I rejoice in paying the penalty, as I beg God and you to pardon me.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$Never did faithful subject more rejoice$NEWLINE$At the discovery of most dangerous treason$NEWLINE$Than I do at this hour joy o'er myself,$NEWLINE$Prevented from a damnèd enterprise.$NEWLINE$My fault, but not my body, pardon, sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$No faithful subject ever rejoiced more at the discovery of most dangerous treason than I now rejoice that I was thwarted in a damnable undertaking. Pardon my crime, sovereign, but not my person.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$God quit you in His mercy. Hear your sentence:$NEWLINE$You have conspired against our royal person,$NEWLINE$Joined with an enemy proclaimed, and from his coffers$NEWLINE$Received the golden earnest of our death,$NEWLINE$Wherein you would have sold your king to slaughter,$NEWLINE$His princes and his peers to servitude,$NEWLINE$His subjects to oppression and contempt,$NEWLINE$And his whole kingdom into desolation.$NEWLINE$Touching our person, seek we no revenge,$NEWLINE$But we our kingdom’s safety must so tender,$NEWLINE$Whose ruin you have sought, that to her laws$NEWLINE$We do deliver you. Get you therefore hence,$NEWLINE$Poor miserable wretches, to your death,$NEWLINE$The taste whereof God of His mercy give$NEWLINE$You patience to endure, and true repentance$NEWLINE$Of all your dear offences.—Bear them hence.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$May God in His mercy forgive you. This is your sentence. You have conspired against us with a proclaimed enemy and accepted his money in exchange for killing us. In doing so, you would have sold your king to slaughter, his princes and lords to slavery, his subjects to oppression and abuse, and his whole kingdom to ruin. I seek no revenge for myself, but so dearly do I hold the safety of my kingdom, which you sought to destroy, that you must be punished according to her laws. So go to your deaths, poor miserable wretches, the pain of which may merciful God give you the strength to endure. And may you truly regret your terrible crimes. Take them away.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CAMBRIDGE, SCROOP, and GREY, guarded$NEWLINE$CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$SCROOP$NEWLINE$GREY
paragraphs.translated: CAMBRIDGE, SCROOP, and GREY exit under guard.$NEWLINE$CAMBRIDGE$NEWLINE$SCROOP$NEWLINE$GREY

paragraphs.original: Now, lords, for France, the enterprise whereof$NEWLINE$Shall be to you as us, like glorious.$NEWLINE$We doubt not of a fair and lucky war,$NEWLINE$Since God so graciously hath brought to light$NEWLINE$This dangerous treason lurking in our way$NEWLINE$To hinder our beginnings. We doubt not now$NEWLINE$But every rub is smoothèd on our way.$NEWLINE$Then forth, dear countrymen. Let us deliver$NEWLINE$Our puissance into the hand of God,$NEWLINE$Putting it straight in expedition.$NEWLINE$Cheerly to sea. The signs of war advance.$NEWLINE$No king of England if not king of France.
paragraphs.translated: And now, my lords, off to France. This invasion will be as glorious to you as it is to me. I have no doubt that it will be a swift and successful war, since God so graciously exposed this dangerous plot. I’m now sure that every bump in the road has been removed. Let’s go forth, dear countrymen. Our strength is God. Let’s get going. We’re off to sea, banners flying. I’ll be no king of England if I’m not also king of France.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL, HOSTESS, NYM, BARDOLPH, and BOY$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$HOSTESS$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL, HOSTESS, NYM, BARDOLPH, and BOY enter.$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$HOSTESS$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Prithee, honey-sweet husband, let me bring thee to Staines.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Please, sweet husband, let me come with you as far as the town of Staines.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$No; for my manly heart doth earn.—Bardolph, be blithe.— Nym, rouse thy vaunting veins.—Boy, bristle thy courage up. For Falstaff, he is dead, and we must earn therefore.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$No, because my manly heart is grieving. Bardolph, be happy.—Nym, rouse your bragging spirits.—Boy, be brave. Falstaff is dead, and we must mourn him.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Would I were with him, wheresome'er he is, either in heaven or in hell.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$I wish I were with him, wherever he is—in heaven or in hell.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Nay, sure, he’s not in hell! He’s in Arthur’s bosom, if ever man went to Arthur’s bosom. He made a finer end, and went away an it had been any christom child. He parted ev'n just between twelve and one, ev'n at the turning o' th' tide; for after I saw him fumble with the sheets and play with flowers and smile upon his finger’s end, I knew there was but one way, for his nose was as sharp as a pen, and he told of green fields. “How now, Sir John?” quoth I. “What, man, be o' good cheer!” So he cried out “God, God, God!” three or four times. Now I, to comfort him, bid him he should not think of God. I hoped there was no need to trouble himself with any such thoughts yet. So he bade me lay more clothes on his feet. I put my hand into the bed and felt them, and they were as cold as any stone. Then I felt to his knees, and so upward and upward, and all was as cold as any stone.
paragraphs.translated:
HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Oh, no, he’s surely not in hell. He’s in
Arthur’s bosom, if any man ever went to Arthur’s bosom. He died as peacefully as a baby. He departed right between twelve and one, just as the tide was turning. For after I saw him fumbling with the sheets and playing with imaginary flowers and smiling at the ends of his fingers, I knew it was the end. His face was gaunt and he was babbling about green fields. “Now, now, Sir John!” I said. “What’s all this? Cheer up!” And he called out “God, God, God!” three or four times. To soothe him, I told him not to think of God, that I hoped it wasn’t yet time to bother with such thoughts. So he asked me to put more blankets on his feet. I put my hand into the bed and felt his feet, and they were stone-cold. Then I felt his legs, and they were stone-cold, and so I moved upward and upward, and his whole body was stone-cold.$NEWLINE$Arthur’s bosom$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$They say he cried out of sack.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$They say he cried out against sherry.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Ay, that he did.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Yes, he did.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$And of women.
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$And women.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Nay, that he did not.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$No, he did not.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Yes, that he did, and said they were devils incarnate.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Yes, he did. He said they were devils incarnate.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$'A could never abide carnation. 'Twas a color he never liked.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$He could never bear carnation. It was a color he never did like.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$He said once the devil would have him about women.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$He once said the devil would get him because of women.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$He did in some sort, indeed, handle women, but then he was rheumatic, and talked of the Whore of Babylon.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$He did touch on women a bit, but his body was aching with fever and he talked about the Whore of Babylon.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Do you not remember he saw a flea stick upon Bardolph’s nose, and he said it was a black soul burning in hell?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Don’t you remember how he saw a flea land on Bardolph’s nose and said it was a black soul burning in hell?

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Well, the fuel is gone that maintained that fire. That’s all the riches I got in his service.
paragraphs.translated:
BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Well, the
fuel that sustained that fire is gone. That’s all the wealth I ever earned in his company.$NEWLINE$fuel$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Shall we shog? The King will be gone from Southampton.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Shall we get moving? The king will already have left Southampton.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Come, let’s away.—My love, give me thy lips.$NEWLINE$Look to my chattels and my movables.$NEWLINE$Let senses rule. The word is “Pitch and pay.”$NEWLINE$Trust none, for oaths are straws, men’s faiths are$NEWLINE$wafer-cakes,$NEWLINE$And Holdfast is the only dog, my duck.$NEWLINE$Therefore, caveto be thy counselor.$NEWLINE$caveto$NEWLINE$Go, clear thy crystals.—Yoke-fellows in arms,$NEWLINE$Let us to France, like horse-leeches, my boys,$NEWLINE$To suck, to suck, the very blood to suck.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Come, let’s be on our way. My love, let me kiss your lips. Look after my goods and possessions. Keep on your toes: the rule is “cash down, no credit.” Trust no one. For oaths are as easily broken as straws, and men’s faith crumbles like crackers, and you can only rely on what you can hold onto. Let caution be your guide. Go dry your eyes. Brothers in arms, we’re off to France—like leeches, my boys: to suck, to suck, their very blood to suck!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$And that’s but unwholesome food, they say.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$I’ve heard that’s not the most nourishing food.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Touch her soft mouth, and march.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Kiss her soft mouth, and we’ll be off.

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Farewell, hostess. (kissing her)$NEWLINE$(kissing her)
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$Farewell, hostess. (kisses her)$NEWLINE$(kisses her)

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$I cannot kiss, that is the humor of it. But adieu.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$I can’t kiss—that’s just how it is—but farewell.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Let housewifery appear. Keep close, I thee command.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Be thrifty. And keep yourself hidden, I command you.

paragraphs.original: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Farewell. Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: HOSTESS$NEWLINE$Farewell. Adieu.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter the KING OF FRANCE, the DAUPHIN, the Dukes of Berri and Brittany, the CONSTABLE, and others$NEWLINE$KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound. The KING OF FRANCE, the DAUPHIN, the CONSTABLE, the dukes of Berri and Bretagne, and others enter.$NEWLINE$KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Thus comes the English with full power upon us,$NEWLINE$And more than carefully it us concerns$NEWLINE$To answer royally in our defenses.$NEWLINE$Therefore the Dukes of Berri and of Brittany,$NEWLINE$Of Brabant and of Orléans, shall make forth,$NEWLINE$And you, Prince Dauphin, with all swift dispatch,$NEWLINE$To line and new-repair our towns of war$NEWLINE$With men of courage and with means defendant.$NEWLINE$For England his approaches makes as fierce$NEWLINE$As waters to the sucking of a gulf.$NEWLINE$It fits us then to be as provident$NEWLINE$As fear may teach us out of late examples$NEWLINE$Left by the fatal and neglected English$NEWLINE$Upon our fields.
paragraphs.translated:
KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$The English army is advancing on us at full strength. It is more important that we respond majestically than that we respond carefully. Therefore the dukes of Berri, Bretagne, Brabant, and Orléans shall advance, and you, Prince Dauphin, will swiftly entrench and fortify our fortress towns with men of courage and the means to defend themselves. The king of England’s approach is as forceful as a whirlpool. It is right for us to prepare like people who are afraid, as we’ve been taught by the
recent lessons given us by the deadly and underestimated English on our own soil.$NEWLINE$recent lessons$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$To view the sick and feeble parts of France.$NEWLINE$And let us do it with no show of fear,$NEWLINE$No, with no more than if we heard that England$NEWLINE$Were busied with a Whitsun morris-dance.$NEWLINE$For, my good liege, she is so idly kinged,$NEWLINE$Her scepter so fantastically borne$NEWLINE$By a vain, giddy, shallow, humorous youth,$NEWLINE$That fear attends her not.$NEWLINE$My most redoubted father,$NEWLINE$It is most meet we arm us 'gainst the foe,$NEWLINE$For peace itself should not so dull a kingdom,$NEWLINE$Though war nor no known quarrel were in question,$NEWLINE$But that defenses, musters, preparations,$NEWLINE$Should be maintained, assembled, and collected,$NEWLINE$As were a war in expectation.$NEWLINE$Therefore I say ’tis meet we all go forth
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$My most feared father, it is certainly appropriate for us to arm ourselves against the enemy, because even in peace time, when no war or conflict is at hand, a kingdom should not lose its edge, but always be ready—with defenses, men, and training—as though it expected a war. Therefore, I agree that we should all go and inspect those French territories that are weak. Let’s do it with no show of anxiety—no, with no more fear than if we’d heard that the English were busying themselves with folk dancing. Because, my good king, England is so poorly led, her scepter so foolishly borne by a vain, silly, shallow, impulsive youth, that she’s hardly a threat.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Oh peace, Prince Dauphin!$NEWLINE$You are too much mistaken in this king.$NEWLINE$Question your Grace the late ambassadors$NEWLINE$With what great state he heard their embassy,$NEWLINE$How well supplied with noble counselors,$NEWLINE$How modest in exception, and withal$NEWLINE$How terrible in constant resolution,$NEWLINE$And you shall find his vanities forespent$NEWLINE$Were but the outside of the Roman Brutus,$NEWLINE$Covering discretion with a coat of folly,$NEWLINE$As gardeners do with ordure hide those roots$NEWLINE$That shall first spring and be most delicate.
paragraphs.translated:
CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Oh, please, Prince Dauphin! You are completely wrong about this king. Talk to the ambassadors who’ve just come back: ask them how majestically he responded to their message, how well supplied he was with good advisors, how restrained in expressing his displeasure, and, moreover, how terrifyingly firm he was in his resolve. You’ll discover that his youthful follies were like the persona that
Lucius Junius Brutus adopted to deceive Tarquin—cloaking wisdom in folly the way gardeners cover the most delicate roots with manure when they first sprout up.$NEWLINE$Lucius Junius Brutus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Well, ’tis not so, my Lord High Constable.$NEWLINE$But though we think it so, it is no matter.$NEWLINE$In cases of defense ’tis best to weigh$NEWLINE$The enemy more mighty than he seems.$NEWLINE$So the proportions of defense are filled,$NEWLINE$Which of a weak or niggardly projection$NEWLINE$Doth, like a miser, spoil his coat with scanting$NEWLINE$A little cloth.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Well, you’re wrong, my Lord High Constable. But even if I thought you were right, it doesn’t matter. When it comes to defense, it’s best to assume that the enemy is more powerful than he seems. That way, we fill the gaps in our defenses. Otherwise, if we do it on the cheap, we’ll be like the miser who spoils his new coat by not buying quite enough cloth to make it.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Think we King Harry strong,$NEWLINE$And, princes, look you strongly arm to meet him.$NEWLINE$The kindred of him hath been fleshed upon us,$NEWLINE$And he is bred out of that bloody strain$NEWLINE$That haunted us in our familiar paths.$NEWLINE$Witness our too-much-memorable shame$NEWLINE$When Cressy battle fatally was struck$NEWLINE$And all our princes captived by the hand$NEWLINE$Of that black name, Edward, Black Prince of Wales,$NEWLINE$Whiles that his mountain sire, on mountain standing
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$I think King Harry is strong, so the rest of you princes make sure to arm yourselves to meet him with strength. His ancestors got their first taste of blood in battle with us, and he is born of that warlike strain that haunted us on our home ground. Reflect on the battle of Crécy, where, to our everlasting shame, all our princes were taken prisoner by the Prince of Wales, he whom they called Edward the Black Prince. Remember how his mountain-bred father, standing high on a mountain,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Up in the air, crowned with the golden sun,$NEWLINE$Saw his heroical seed and smiled to see him$NEWLINE$Mangle the work of nature and deface$NEWLINE$The patterns that by God and by French fathers$NEWLINE$Had twenty years been made. This is a stem$NEWLINE$Of that victorious stock, and let us fear$NEWLINE$The native mightiness and fate of him.
paragraphs.translated: crowned by the golden sun, observed his heroic son and smiled to see him mangle the work of nature, French youth whose fathers and God had nurtured for twenty years, since they were babies. This king is a branch of that same victorious stock. So let us be wary both of his inborn might and of his destiny.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Ambassadors from Harry King of England$NEWLINE$Do crave admittance to your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Ambassadors of Harry, king of England, request a hearing with your Majesty.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$We’ll give them present audience. Go, and bring them.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$We’ll see them immediately. Bring them right in.

paragraphs.original: Exit MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER and certain lords exit.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: You see this chase is hotly followed, friends.
paragraphs.translated: Notice, my friends, how closely this hunter follows his prey.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Turn head and stop pursuit, for coward dogs$NEWLINE$Most spend their mouths when what they seem to threaten$NEWLINE$Runs far before them. Good my sovereign,$NEWLINE$Take up the English short, and let them know$NEWLINE$Of what a monarchy you are the head.$NEWLINE$Self-love, my liege, is not so vile a sin$NEWLINE$As self-neglecting.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Turn and face them and you’ll stop the pursuit. The cowardly pack barks loudest when the quarry is way out front. My good King, surprise the English and let them know what kind of kingdom you rule over. Self-love, my liege, is not so great a sin as self-neglect.

paragraphs.original: Enter EXETER and train, and lords$NEWLINE$EXETER
paragraphs.translated: The Lords and EXETER enter with followers.$NEWLINE$EXETER

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$From our brother England?
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$From our brother monarch, the king of England?

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$From him, and thus he greets your Majesty:$NEWLINE$He wills you, in the name of God Almighty,$NEWLINE$That you divest yourself and lay apart
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Yes, from him. Thus he greets your Majesty. He commands you, in the name of God: give up. Relinquish the stolen titles that, by the gift of heaven and the laws

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The borrowed glories that, by gift of heaven,$NEWLINE$By law of nature and of nations, 'longs$NEWLINE$To him and to his heirs—namely, the crown$NEWLINE$And all wide-stretchèd honors that pertain$NEWLINE$By custom and the ordinance of times$NEWLINE$Unto the crown of France. That you may know$NEWLINE$'Tis no sinister nor no awkward claim$NEWLINE$Picked from the wormholes of long-vanished days,$NEWLINE$Nor from the dust of old oblivion raked,$NEWLINE$He sends you this most memorable line,$NEWLINE$In every branch truly demonstrative,$NEWLINE$Willing you overlook this pedigree,$NEWLINE$And when you find him evenly derived$NEWLINE$From his most famed of famous ancestors,$NEWLINE$Edward the Third, he bids you then resign$NEWLINE$Your crown and kingdom, indirectly held$NEWLINE$From him, the native and true challenger.
paragraphs.translated: of nature and of nations, belong to him and his heirs. That is, give up the crown and all the extensive titles that go with it, according to custom and long use. So that you’ll know this is no dubious or farfetched claim, he sends you his family tree, every line of which supports the claim. Look over this document, and when you see that he is directly descended from his most famous of famous ancestors, Edward the Third, he demands that you resign your crown and kingdom, which you wrongfully hold at the expense of himself, the true and natural owner.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Or else what follows?
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$And what will happen if I don’t?

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Bloody constraint, for if you hide the crown$NEWLINE$Even in your hearts, there will he rake for it.$NEWLINE$Therefore in fierce tempest is he coming,$NEWLINE$In thunder and in earthquake like a Jove,$NEWLINE$That, if requiring fail, he will compel,$NEWLINE$And bids you, in the bowels of the Lord,$NEWLINE$Deliver up the crown and to take mercy$NEWLINE$On the poor souls for whom this hungry war$NEWLINE$Opens his vasty jaws, and on your head$NEWLINE$Turning the widows' tears, the orphans' cries,$NEWLINE$The dead men’s blood, the pining maidens' groans,$NEWLINE$For husbands, fathers, and betrothèd lovers,$NEWLINE$That shall be swallowed in this controversy.$NEWLINE$This is his claim, his threat'ning, and my message—$NEWLINE$Unless the Dauphin be in presence here,$NEWLINE$To whom expressly I bring greeting too.
paragraphs.translated:
EXETER$NEWLINE$Bloodshed will force you to. No matter how deeply you hid the crown, even if you hid it in your own hearts, he’d dig it up. That’s why he’s coming after you like a fierce storm, with thunder and earthquakes like
Jove could stir up. So, if asking you for the crown doesn’t work, he will force you to give it to him. In the name of God, then, he asks that you deliver up the crown. He says to take pity on the poor souls whom this ravenous war will swallow up. The widows' tears, the orphans' cries, the dead men’s blood, the girls mourning for their husbands, the fathers and the men they might have married will all be your fault. This is his claim, his threat, and my message. If the Dauphin is here, I have a message for him, too.$NEWLINE$Jove$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$For us, we will consider of this further.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow shall you bear our full intent$NEWLINE$Back to our brother England.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$I’ll think it over. Tomorrow, I’ll let you know what I’ve decided and what answer you should deliver to the king of England.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$For the Dauphin,$NEWLINE$I stand here for him. What to him from England?
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Regarding the Dauphin, you can speak to me. What’s the message from the English king?

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Scorn and defiance, slight regard, contempt,$NEWLINE$And anything that may not misbecome$NEWLINE$The mighty sender, doth he prize you at.$NEWLINE$Thus says my king: an if your father’s Highness$NEWLINE$Do not, in grant of all demands at large,$NEWLINE$Sweeten the bitter mock you sent his Majesty,$NEWLINE$He’ll call you to so hot an answer of it$NEWLINE$That caves and womby vaultages of France$NEWLINE$Shall chide your trespass and return your mock$NEWLINE$In second accent of his ordinance.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Scorn and defiance, indifference, contempt, and any insult that wouldn’t disgrace the mighty sender—that’s the value he puts on you. And my king goes on: if your royal father does not sweeten the bitter insult you sent my king and grant all our demands, Henry’s artillery will give you so resounding an answer that the very caves and vaulted cathedrals of France shall echo your mocking of him back in your face.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Say, if my father render fair return,$NEWLINE$It is against my will, for I desire$NEWLINE$Nothing but odds with England. To that end,$NEWLINE$As matching to his youth and vanity,$NEWLINE$I did present him with the Paris balls.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Say this: if my father sends a friendly answer, it is against my will. I want nothing but conflict with England. To that end, I presented him with the tennis balls, the perfect expression of his inexperience and frivolity.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$He’ll make your Paris Louvre shake for it,$NEWLINE$Were it the mistress court of mighty Europe.$NEWLINE$And be assured you’ll find a difference,$NEWLINE$As we his subjects have in wonder found,$NEWLINE$Between the promise of his greener days$NEWLINE$And these he masters now. Now he weighs time$NEWLINE$Even to the utmost grain. That you shall read$NEWLINE$In your own losses, if he stay in France.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$He’ll make your palace tremble for this insult, even if it were the mightiest in all of Europe. And, make no mistake, you’ll find, as we his subjects have, an amazing difference between the king as a young man and the way he is now. Now he uses his time wisely, as you will see by your own casualties, if he remains in France.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Tomorrow shall you know our mind at full.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$We’ll give you an answer tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet plays.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Dispatch us with all speed, lest that our king$NEWLINE$Come here himself to question our delay,$NEWLINE$For he is footed in this land already.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Don’t take too long, unless you want our king to come after me to ask what’s holding things up, because he’s already landed here.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$You shall be soon dispatched with fair conditions.$NEWLINE$A night is but small breath and little pause$NEWLINE$To answer matters of this consequence.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$You’ll have your answer soon. A night isn’t much time for addressing matters of this importance.

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Thus with imagined wing our swift scene flies$NEWLINE$In motion of no less celerity$NEWLINE$Than that of thought. Suppose that you have seen$NEWLINE$The well-appointed king at Hampton pier$NEWLINE$Embark his royalty, and his brave fleet$NEWLINE$With silken streamers the young Phoebus fanning.$NEWLINE$Play with your fancies and in them behold,$NEWLINE$Upon the hempen tackle, shipboys climbing.$NEWLINE$Hear the shrill whistle, which doth order give$NEWLINE$To sounds confused. Behold the threaden sails,$NEWLINE$Borne with th' invisible and creeping wind,$NEWLINE$Draw the huge bottoms through the furrowed sea,$NEWLINE$Breasting the lofty surge. Oh, do but think$NEWLINE$You stand upon the rivage and behold$NEWLINE$A city on th' inconstant billows dancing,$NEWLINE$For so appears this fleet majestical$NEWLINE$Holding due course to Harfleur. Follow, follow!$NEWLINE$Grapple your minds to sternage of this navy$NEWLINE$And leave your England, as dead midnight still,$NEWLINE$Guarded with grandsires, babies, and old women,$NEWLINE$Either past or not arrived to pith and puissance,$NEWLINE$For who is he whose chin is but enriched$NEWLINE$With one appearing hair that will not follow$NEWLINE$These culled and choice-drawn cavaliers to France?$NEWLINE$Work, work your thoughts, and therein see a siege.$NEWLINE$Behold the ordnance on their carriages,$NEWLINE$With fatal mouths gaping on girded Harfleur.$NEWLINE$Suppose th' Ambassador from the French comes back,$NEWLINE$Tells Harry that the king doth offer him
paragraphs.translated: CHORUS$NEWLINE$And so, on the wings of imagination and at the speed of thought, our scene flies swiftly on. Imagine that you have seen the well-equipped king at Dover pier set sail in full royal regalia and his noble fleet fan the rising sun with its silken banners. Give your imagination free rein. Picture the cabin boys climbing around the rigging. Hear the shrill whistle that brings order to the hubbub. Picture the linen sails driven by the invisible and subtle wind as they pull the vast hulls through the wrinkled sea, breasting the high waves. Pretend that you’re standing on the shore, watching a city dance on the shifting waves, and you’ll have an idea of the look of this majestic fleet as it holds a straight course for Harfleur. Follow it, follow it! Hitch your minds to this navy’s sterns and leave your England, silent as midnight, guarded by grandfathers, babies, and old women. For what male subject is there old enough for his chin to be graced with even one hair who doesn’t want to follow this select band of hand-picked knights to France? Once there, make your thoughts work harder, and witness a siege. Take in the wheeled canons with their deadly gaping mouths trained on the walled city of Harfleur. Imagine the French ambassador returning to inform Harry that the king offers him

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Katherine his daughter and with her, to dowry,$NEWLINE$Some petty and unprofitable dukedoms.$NEWLINE$The offer likes not, and the nimble gunner$NEWLINE$With linstock now the devilish cannon touches,
paragraphs.translated: his daughter, Katherine, with some insignificant, unprofitable dukedoms as her dowry. The offer doesn’t go over well, and the nimble gunner now moves to ignite the devilish canon.

paragraphs.original: Alarum, and chambers go off
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle and gunfire from offstage.

paragraphs.original: And down goes all before them. Still be kind$NEWLINE$And eke out our performance with your mind.
paragraphs.translated: Down goes everything in their path. Indulge us further and supplement our performance with your own imaginings.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original: Enter KING HENRY, EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers, with scaling ladders$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY enters, with EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers carrying ladders for scaling the walls that surround Harfleur.$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Once more unto the breach, dear friends, once more,$NEWLINE$Or close the wall up with our English dead!$NEWLINE$In peace there’s nothing so becomes a man$NEWLINE$As modest stillness and humility,$NEWLINE$But when the blast of war blows in our ears,$NEWLINE$Then imitate the action of the tiger:$NEWLINE$Stiffen the sinews, summon up the blood,$NEWLINE$Disguise fair nature with hard-favored rage,$NEWLINE$Then lend the eye a terrible aspect,$NEWLINE$Let pry through the portage of the head$NEWLINE$Like the brass cannon, let the brow o'erwhelm it$NEWLINE$As fearfully as doth a gallèd rock$NEWLINE$O'erhang and jutty his confounded base,$NEWLINE$Swilled with the wild and wasteful ocean.$NEWLINE$Now set the teeth and stretch the nostril wide,$NEWLINE$Hold hard the breath and bend up every spirit$NEWLINE$To his full height. On, on, you noblest English,$NEWLINE$Whose blood is fet from fathers of war-proof,$NEWLINE$Fathers that, like so many Alexanders,$NEWLINE$Have in these parts from morn till even fought$NEWLINE$And sheathed their swords for lack of argument.$NEWLINE$Dishonor not your mothers. Now attest$NEWLINE$That those whom you called fathers did beget you.$NEWLINE$Be copy now to men of grosser blood,$NEWLINE$And teach them how to war. And you, good yeoman,$NEWLINE$Whose limbs were made in England, show us here$NEWLINE$The mettle of your pasture. Let us swear$NEWLINE$That you are worth your breeding, which I doubt not,
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Attack the breach in the city wall once more, dear friends, attack it once more—or else let’s close it up with English corpses. In peacetime, nothing looks better in a man than restraint and humility. But when the battle trumpet blows in our ears, then it’s time to act like the tiger. With muscles taut and blood stirred up, hide your civilized nature under the guise of ugly rage. Lend your eyes a terrifying gleam and let them jut out from the portholes of the head like brass cannon. Make your brow jut out over your eyes like a frightening cliff over the wild and desolate ocean. Now grit your teeth and let your nostrils flare. Take a deep breath and draw on every impulse to its fullest strength. On, on, you noblest Englishmen, descended as you are from battle-tested fathers, fathers who, like so many Alexander the Greats, have fought in these regions from morning until night, sheathing their swords only when there was no one left to fight. Don’t dishonor your mothers! Prove that the men you call your fathers did truly conceive you. Serve as an example to men of common birth and teach them how to fight. And you, good farmers, whose limbs were made in England, show us here the vigor of your upbringing. Prove you are worthy of your birth, which I do not doubt for a moment. For there isn’t one of you so low-born that your eyes don’t shine with noble luster. I see you’re standing like greyhounds

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: For there is none of you so mean and base$NEWLINE$That hath not noble luster in your eyes.$NEWLINE$I see you stand like greyhounds in the slips,$NEWLINE$Straining upon the start. The game’s afoot.$NEWLINE$Follow your spirit, and upon this charge$NEWLINE$Cry “God for Harry, England, and Saint George!”
paragraphs.translated: on a leash, straining for the moment when you’ll be let loose. The hunt is on! Follow your spirit, and as you charge cry, “God for Harry, England, and Saint George!”

paragraphs.original: Alarum, and chambers go off Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit to the sounds of battle and gunfire from offstage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter NYM, BARDOLPH, PISTOL, and BOY$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: NYM, BARDOLPH, PISTOL, and the BOY enter.$NEWLINE$NYM$NEWLINE$BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$On, on, on, on, on! To the breach, to the breach!
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH$NEWLINE$On, on, on, on, on! To the breach, to the breach!

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$Pray thee, corporal, stay. The knocks are too hot, and, for mine own part, I have not a case of lives. The humor of it is too hot; that is the very plainsong of it.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$Please, corporal, stop! The fighting is too violent. Speaking for myself, I only have one life, not dozens. Too violent! That’s just how it is, the plain truth of it.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$“The plainsong” is most just, for humors do abound.$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$Knocks go and come. God’s vassals drop and die,$NEWLINE$Knocks go and come. God’s vassals drop and die,$NEWLINE$And sword and shield$NEWLINE$And sword and shield$NEWLINE$In bloody field$NEWLINE$In bloody field$NEWLINE$Doth win immortal fame.$NEWLINE$Doth win immortal fame.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The plain truth doesn’t lie. You can see how it is all around. Fighting comes and goes, God’s loyal servants drop and die. (he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$And sword and shield$NEWLINE$And sword and shield$NEWLINE$In bloody field$NEWLINE$In bloody field$NEWLINE$Will win immortal fame.$NEWLINE$Will win immortal fame.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Would I were in an alehouse in London! I would give all my fame for a pot of ale, and safety.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$I wish I were in an alehouse in London! I would give all my glory for a mug of ale and safety.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$And I.$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$If wishes would prevail with me,$NEWLINE$If wishes would prevail with me,$NEWLINE$My purpose should not fail with me,$NEWLINE$My purpose should not fail with me,$NEWLINE$But thither would I hie.$NEWLINE$But thither would I hie.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Me too. (he sings)$NEWLINE$(he sings)$NEWLINE$If wishes could avail me,$NEWLINE$If wishes could avail me,$NEWLINE$My purpose would not fail me,$NEWLINE$My purpose would not fail me,$NEWLINE$It’s there that I would go.$NEWLINE$It’s there that I would go.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$As duly,$NEWLINE$As duly,$NEWLINE$But not as truly,$NEWLINE$But not as truly,$NEWLINE$As bird doth sing on bough.$NEWLINE$As bird doth sing on bough.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$As surely but more poorly$NEWLINE$As surely but more poorly$NEWLINE$Than birds sing on the bough.$NEWLINE$Than birds sing on the bough.

paragraphs.original: Enter FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN enters.$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Up to the breach, you dogs! Avaunt, you cullions!
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Up to the breach, you dogs! Go! Get a move on, you scrotems!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Be merciful, great duke, to men of mold. Abate thy rage, abate thy manly rage, abate thy rage, great duke. Good bawcock, 'bate thy rage. Use lenity, sweet chuck.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Great Duke, be merciful to mortal men. Calm your rage, your manly rage! Calm your rage, great Duke! Dear man, calm your rage. Be lenient, dearest!

paragraphs.original: NYM$NEWLINE$These be good humors. Your Honor wins bad humors.
paragraphs.translated: NYM$NEWLINE$This is healthy talk. Your Honor’s is unhealthy talk.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but BOY$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but the BOY exits.$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$As young as I am, I have observed these three swashers. I am boy to them all three, but all they three, though they would serve me, could not be man to me. For indeed three such antics do not amount to a man: for Bardolph, he is white-livered and red-faced, by the means whereof he faces it out but fights not; for Pistol, he hath a killing tongue and a quiet sword, by the means whereof he breaks words and keeps whole weapons; for Nym, he hath heard that men of few words are the best men, and therefore he scorns to say his prayers, lest he should be thought a coward, but his few bad words are matched with as few good deeds, for he never broke any man’s head but his own, and that was against a post when he was drunk. They will steal anything and call it purchase. Bardolph stole a lute case, bore it twelve leagues, and sold it for three halfpence. Nym and Bardolph are sworn brothers in filching, and in Calais they stole a fire shovel. I knew by that piece of service the men would carry coals. They would have me as familiar with men’s pockets as their gloves or their handkerchers, which makes much against my manhood, if I should take from another’s pocket to put into mine, for it is plain pocketing up of wrongs. I must leave them and seek some better service. Their villainy goes against my weak stomach, and therefore I must cast it up.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Young though I am, I’ve been observing these three blowhards closely. I am “man”—which is to say, servant—to all three of them. Yet not one among them, if all three were to wait on me, could be my “man,” because three such fakes don’t amount to a man. Take Bardolph: he is cowardly and blustery. He acts tough, but he doesn’t fight. Pistol, meanwhile, has a lethal tongue but an inert sword. He destroys words but keeps his weapon in one piece. As for Nym, he’s heard men of valor are men of few words, so he refuses to pray lest he should be thought a coward. But he has as few good deeds as he has bad words—for he never cracked anyone’s head but his own, and that was against a post when he was drunk. They will steal anything and call it spoils. Bardolph stole a lute case, carried it for thirty-six miles, and sold it for a penny and a half. Nym and Bardolph are sworn brothers in crime, and in Calais they stole a fire shovel: I could see from that that they had no pride. They would like me to be as familiar with men’s pockets as their gloves and handkerchiefs, which goes against my manhood, because to take something from another’s pocket and put it into my own is plain stealing. I must leave them and seek some better employment. Their villainy nauseates me, and I must therefore vomit it up.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN enters, with GOWER following.$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Captain Fluellen, you must come presently to the mines; the duke of Gloucester would speak with you.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Captain Fluellen, you must come straight to the tunnels. The duke of Gloucester wants a word with you.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$To the mines? Tell you the duke it is not so good to come to the mines, for, look you, the mines is not according to the disciplines of the war. The concavities of it is not sufficient, for, look you, th' athversary, you may discuss unto the duke, look you, is digt himself four yard under the countermines. By Cheshu, I think he will plow up all if there is not better directions.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$The tunnels! Tell the duke I’m not so keen to come to the tunnels. For the tunnels, see, are not strictly in accordance with the proper practice of war. They’re not deep enough. For the enemy, see—and you can explain this to the duke, see—has dug its own tunnels four yards below ours. By Jesus, I think they will blow up everything if we don’t improve our tactics.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$The duke of Gloucester, to whom the order of the siege is given, is altogether directed by an Irishman, a very valiant gentleman, i' faith.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$The duke of Gloucester, who has command over the siege, is in consultation with an Irishman, a very valiant gentleman indeed.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It is Captain Macmorris, is it not?
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It’s Captain Macmorris, right?

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$I think it be.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$I think so.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$By Cheshu, he is an ass, as in the world. I will verify as much in his beard. He has no more directions in the true disciplines of the wars, look you, of the Roman disciplines, than is a puppy dog.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Jesus, he’s an ass if there ever was one! I will say as much to his face. He knows no more about the proper practice of war, see—the ancient practices—than a puppy.

paragraphs.original: Enter Captain MACMORRIS and Captain JAMY$NEWLINE$MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$JAMY
paragraphs.translated: Captain MACMORRIS and Captain JAMY enter.$NEWLINE$MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$JAMY

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Here he comes, and the Scots captain, Captain Jamy, with him.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Here he comes with Captain Jamy, the Scots captain.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Jamy is a marvelous falorous gentleman, that is certain, and of great expedition and knowledge in th' aunchient wars, upon my particular knowledge of his directions. By Cheshu, he will maintain his argument as well as any military man in the world in the disciplines of the pristine wars of the Romans.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Jamy is a wonderfully valorous gentleman, that’s certain, one with great learning and knowledge concerning ancient warfare, I happen to know from his maneuvers. By Jesus, he will defend his position on the practices of the ancient Roman wars as well as any military man in the world.

paragraphs.original: JAMY$NEWLINE$I say gudday, Captain Fluellen.
paragraphs.translated: JAMY$NEWLINE$Good day to you, Captain Fluellen.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Godden to your Worship, good Captain James.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Good evening to your Worship, good Captain James.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$How now, Captain Macmorris, have you quit the mines?$NEWLINE$Have the pioneers given o'er?
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Tell me, Captain Macmorris, have you left the tunnels? Have the excavators stopped work?

paragraphs.original: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$By Chrish, la, ’tish ill done. The work ish give over. The trompet sound the retreat. By my hand I swear, and my father’s soul, the work ish ill done. It ish give over. I would have blowed up the town, so Chrish save me, la, in an hour. Oh, ’tish ill done, ’tish ill done, by my hand, ’tish ill done.
paragraphs.translated: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$Christ, it’s a disaster. The work is stopped, the trumpet has sounded the retreat. I swear by this hand and my father’s soul, the whole thing is a disaster. It’s all stopped. I could have blown up the town in an hour. Oh, it’s a disaster, a disaster, by this hand, it’s a disaster.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, I beseech you now, will you voutsafe me, look you, a few disputations with you as partly touching or concerning the disciplines of the war, the Roman wars? In the way of argument, look you, and friendly communication, partly to satisfy my opinion, and partly for the satisfaction, look you, of my mind, as touching the direction of the military discipline, that is the point.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, I beg your pardon, but would you grant me a discussion or two with you, see, partly touching on or concerning the practice of war, the Roman wars, for the sake of argument, see, and friendly conversation? Partly to confirm my opinion and partly for the satisfaction, see, of my mind, with respect to the demands of proper military practice—that’s the point?

paragraphs.original: JAMY$NEWLINE$It sall be vary gud, gud feith, gud captens bath, and I sall quit you with gud leve, as I may pick occasion, that sall I, marry.
paragraphs.translated: JAMY$NEWLINE$Oh, this is fine, good captains. And I’ll answer you, if I may, when I get a chance. Indeed I will.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$It is no time to discourse, so Chrish save me. The day is hot, and the weather, and the wars, and the king, and the dukes. It is no time to discourse. The town is beseeched, and the trumpet call us to the breach, and we talk and, be Chrish, do nothing, ’tis shame for us all. So God sa' me, ’tis shame to stand still. It is shame, by my hand. And there is throats to be cut and works to be done, and there ish nothing done, so Chrish sa' me, la.
paragraphs.translated: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$This is no time to have a discussion. Christ! The day is hot and between the weather and the wars and the king and the dukes, it’s no time for a discussion. The town is besieged, and the trumpet calls us to the gap, and we talk and do nothing, by Christ. It’s a disgrace to us all. God save me, it’s a disgrace, by this hand, when there are throats to be cut and work to be done, and nothing gets done, Christ save me.

paragraphs.original: JAMY$NEWLINE$By the mess, ere theise eyes of mine take themselves to slomber, ay’ll de gud service, or I’ll lig i' th' grund for it, ay, or go to death. And I’ll pay ’t as valorously as I may, that sall I suerly do, that is the breff and the long. Marry, I wad full fain heard some question ’tween you tway.
paragraphs.translated: JAMY$NEWLINE$I swear by the mass, before I close my eyes to go to sleep, I’ll put in some good fighting, or I’ll lie in the ground dead. And I’ll kill as valiantly as I can, that’s for sure. That is the long and the short of it. But truly, I would love to hear the two of you discuss warfare.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, I think, look you, under your correction, there is not many of your nation—
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, I think, see—correct me if I’m wrong—there are not many of your nation—

paragraphs.original: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$Of my nation? What ish my nation? Ish a villain and a basterd and a knave and a rascal. What ish my nation? Who talks of my nation?
paragraphs.translated: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$My nation? What is my nation? It’s a villain and a bastard and a coward and a rascal. What is my nation? Who talks of my nation?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Look you, if you take the matter otherwise than is meant, Captain Macmorris, peradventure I shall think you do not use me with that affability as, in discretion, you ought to use me, look you, being as good a man as yourself, both in the disciplines of war and in the derivation of my birth and in other particularities.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, if you take my words in some way other than how they were meant, see, I’ll have to think you’re not treating me with the good will you ought to, see, since I am as good a man as yourself, both in the practice of war and in my country of origin and in other respects.

paragraphs.original: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$I do not know you so good a man as myself. So Chrish save me, I will cut off your head.
paragraphs.translated: MACMORRIS$NEWLINE$I do not know that you are as good a man as myself. So, by Christ, I’ll cut off your head.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Gentlemen both, you will mistake each other.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Now, now, both of you gentlemen! You go out of your way to misunderstand each other.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: JAMY$NEWLINE$Ah, that’s a foul fault.
paragraphs.translated: JAMY$NEWLINE$Yes, and that’s a serious failing.

paragraphs.original: A parley sounds
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet tune that indicates a request for a ceasefire sounds.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$The town sounds a parley.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$The town is asking for a pause in the fighting for negotiation.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, when there is more better opportunity to be required, look you, I will be so bold as to tell you I know the disciplines of war, and there is an end.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Captain Macmorris, when we have more leisure, see, I will be so bold as to show you I know about the practice of warfare, and that’s that.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the GOVERNOR and some citizens on the walls. Enter KING HENRY and his train before the gates$NEWLINE$GOVERNOR$NEWLINE$KING HENRY
paragraphs.translated: The GOVERNOR and some citizens appear on the walls, the English army below. KING HENRY and his train enter.$NEWLINE$GOVERNOR$NEWLINE$KING HENRY

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How yet resolves the governor of the town?$NEWLINE$This is the latest parle we will admit.$NEWLINE$Therefore to our best mercy give yourselves$NEWLINE$Or, like to men proud of destruction,$NEWLINE$Defy us to our worst. For, as I am a soldier,$NEWLINE$A name that in my thoughts becomes me best,$NEWLINE$If I begin the batt'ry once again,$NEWLINE$I will not leave the half-achieved Harfleur$NEWLINE$Till in her ashes she lie burièd.$NEWLINE$The gates of mercy shall be all shut up,$NEWLINE$And the fleshed soldier, rough and hard of heart,$NEWLINE$In liberty of bloody hand, shall range$NEWLINE$With conscience wide as hell, mowing like grass$NEWLINE$Your fresh fair virgins and your flow'ring infants.$NEWLINE$What is it then to me if impious war,$NEWLINE$Arrayed in flames like to the prince of fiends,$NEWLINE$Do with his smirched complexion all fell feats$NEWLINE$Enlinked to waste and desolation?$NEWLINE$What is ’t to me, when you yourselves are cause,$NEWLINE$If your pure maidens fall into the hand$NEWLINE$Of hot and forcing violation?$NEWLINE$What rein can hold licentious wickedness$NEWLINE$When down the hill he holds his fierce career?$NEWLINE$We may as bootless spend our vain command$NEWLINE$Upon th' enragèd soldiers in their spoil$NEWLINE$As send precepts to the Leviathan$NEWLINE$To come ashore. Therefore, you men of Harfleur,$NEWLINE$Take pity of your town and of your people$NEWLINE$Whiles yet my soldiers are in my command,$NEWLINE$Whiles yet the cool and temperate wind of grace
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What has the governor of the town decided? This is the final discussion I will grant. So submit to my mercy or, like men who revel in their own destruction, challenge me to do my worst. For, as I am a soldier, the name I think suits me best, once I begin my attack on Harfleur again, I will not leave the half-conquered town until she lies buried in her own ashes. The gates of mercy will be closed by then, and harsh and hard-hearted soldiers, who have tasted blood, will have free reign to commit whatever violence they want, mowing down your lovely young virgins and budding infants. What will it matter to me, since you will have brought it on yourselves, if sacrilegious war, dressed in red like Satan, his face blackened by smoke, should commit every form of savage destruction and ruin? What will it matter to me if your innocent maidens are raped, since you will have asked for it? What power can rein in promiscuous evil once it’s gotten rolling? We might as well send orders to the whale to come ashore as try to restore order in soldiers carried away with their looting. Therefore, you men of Harfleur, take pity on your town and on your people while I still have control over my men, while the cool and moderate winds of mercy still have power to disperse the depraved, infected clouds of murder, plunder, and crazed soldiers defile your shrieking daughters with their foul hands, and your fathers dragged by their silver beards, their reverend heads dashed against the walls. Expect to see your naked babies skewered upon pikes while their

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O'erblows the filthy and contagious clouds$NEWLINE$Of heady murder, spoil, and villainy.$NEWLINE$If not, why, in a moment look to see$NEWLINE$The blind and bloody soldier with foul hand$NEWLINE$Desire the locks of your shrill-shrieking daughters,$NEWLINE$Your fathers taken by the silver beards$NEWLINE$And their most reverend heads dashed to the walls,$NEWLINE$Your naked infants spitted upon pikes$NEWLINE$Whiles the mad mothers with their howls confused$NEWLINE$Do break the clouds, as did the wives of Jewry$NEWLINE$At Herod’s bloody-hunting slaughtermen.$NEWLINE$What say you? Will you yield and this avoid$NEWLINE$Or, guilty in defense, be thus destroyed?
paragraphs.translated: grief-crazed mothers tear the clouds with their loud cries, just as the women of Judea did when Herod slaughtered their infants. What do you say? Will you surrender and avoid all this or be called to account for the destruction of this town?

paragraphs.original: GOVERNOR$NEWLINE$Our expectation hath this day an end.$NEWLINE$The Dauphin, whom of succors we entreated,$NEWLINE$Returns us that his powers are yet not ready$NEWLINE$To raise so great a siege. Therefore, great King,$NEWLINE$We yield our town and lives to thy soft mercy.$NEWLINE$Enter our gates, dispose of us and ours,$NEWLINE$For we no longer are defensible.
paragraphs.translated: GOVERNOR$NEWLINE$Today our hopes are at an end. The Dauphin, whom we asked for reinforcements, sends back the answer that he’s not yet in a position to raise so great an army. Therefore, great king, we surrender our town and lives to your kind mercy. Enter our gates and do as you like with us and our possessions, for we cannot defend ourselves any longer.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Open your gates.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Open your gates.

paragraphs.original: Exit GOVERNOR$NEWLINE$GOVERNOR
paragraphs.translated: The GOVERNOR exits.$NEWLINE$GOVERNOR

paragraphs.original: Come, uncle Exeter,$NEWLINE$Go you and enter Harfleur. There remain$NEWLINE$And fortify it strongly 'gainst the French.$NEWLINE$Use mercy to them all for us, dear uncle,$NEWLINE$The winter coming on and sickness growing$NEWLINE$Upon our soldiers, we will retire to Calais.$NEWLINE$Tonight in Harfleur will we be your guest;$NEWLINE$Tomorrow for the march are we addressed.
paragraphs.translated: Come, uncle Exeter, enter Harfleur. Stay there and fortify it well against the French. Deal with them all mercifully on my behalf, dear uncle. Meanwhile, with winter coming on and sickness growing among our troops, we’ll withdraw to Calais. Tonight in Harfleur we will be your guest; tomorrow we’ll march on.

paragraphs.original: Flourish, and enter the town
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets. The KING and his train enter the town.$NEWLINE$KING

paragraphs.original: Enter KATHERINE and ALICE$NEWLINE$KATHERINE$NEWLINE$ALICE
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE and ALICE enter.$NEWLINE$KATHERINE$NEWLINE$ALICE

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Alice, tu as été en Angleterre, et tu parles bien le langage.$NEWLINE$Alice, tu as été en Angleterre, et tu parles bien le langage.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$(speaking in French, for the entire scene) Alice, you have been to England and you know the language.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French, for the entire scene)

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Un peu, madame.$NEWLINE$Un peu, madame
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$(speaking in French, for the entire scene) A little, madam.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French, for the entire scene)

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Je te prie, m'enseignez. Il faut que j'apprenne à parler.$NEWLINE$Je te prie, m'enseignez. Il faut que j'apprenne à parler$NEWLINE$Comment appelez-vous la main en anglais?$NEWLINE$Comment appelez-vous$NEWLINE$en anglais?
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Please teach me English. I must learn to speak it. What is the word for la main in English?$NEWLINE$la main

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$La main? Elle est appelée “de hand.”$NEWLINE$Elle est appelée “de hand.”
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$La main? That is “de hand.”$NEWLINE$La main

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De hand.” Et les doigts?$NEWLINE$“De hand.” Et
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De hand.” And les doigts?$NEWLINE$les doigts?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Les doigts? Ma foi, j'oublie les doigts; mais je me souviendrai. Les doigts? Je pense qu'ils sont appelés “de fingres”; oui, “de fingres.”$NEWLINE$Ma foi, j'oublie les doigts; mais je me souviendrai.$NEWLINE$Je pense qu'ils sont appelés$NEWLINE$oui,
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Les doigts? Good lord, I forget les doigts. But it will come to me. The word for les doigts, I believe, is “de fangres.” Yes, “de fangres.”$NEWLINE$Les doigts$NEWLINE$les doigts.$NEWLINE$les doigts,

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$La main, “de hand”; les doigts, “de fingres.” Je pense que je suis le bon écolier. J'ai gagné deux mots d'anglais vitement. Comment appelez-vous les ongles?$NEWLINE$La main$NEWLINE$les doigts$NEWLINE$Je pense que je suis le bon écolier. J'ai gagné deux mots d'anglais vitement. Comment appelez-vous
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$La main, “de hand”; les doigts, “de fangres.” I think I am a very apt student! I have learned two words of English already. What is the word for les ongles?$NEWLINE$La main,$NEWLINE$les doigts,$NEWLINE$les ongles?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Les ongles? Nous les appelons “de nails.”$NEWLINE$Nous les appelons “de nails.”
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“Les ongles?” That is “de nails.”$NEWLINE$“Les ongles?”

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De nails.” Écoutez. Dites-moi si je parle bien: “de hand, de fingres, et de nails.”$NEWLINE$Écoutez. Dites-moi si je parle bien
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De nails.” Listen! Tell me if I’m saying it right. De hand, de fangres, et de nails.”

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$C'est bien dit, madame. Il est fort bon anglais.$NEWLINE$C'est bien dit, madame. Il est fort bon anglais.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Well done, madam. Excellent English.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Dites-moi l'anglais pour le bras.$NEWLINE$Dites-moi l'anglais pour
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Tell me the English for le bras.$NEWLINE$le bras.

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De arme,” madame.$NEWLINE$“De arme,” madame.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De arm,” madam.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Et le coude?$NEWLINE$Et
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$And le coud?$NEWLINE$le coud?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“D'elbow.”$NEWLINE$“D'elbow.”
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“D'elbow.”

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“D'elbow.” Je m'en fais la répétition de tous les mots que vous m'avez appris dés à présent.$NEWLINE$Je m'en fais la répétition de tous les mots que vous m'avez appris dés à présent.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“D'elbow.” Let me practice all the words you’ve taught me so far.

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Il est trop difficile, madame, comme je pense.$NEWLINE$Il est trop difficile, madame, comme je pense.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$It’s too difficult, I think, madam.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Excusez-moi, Alice. Écoutez: “de hand, de fingres, de nails, de arma, de bilbow.”$NEWLINE$Excusez-moi, Alice. Écoutez:
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I beg to differ, Alice. Listen: “de hand, de fangres, de nails, d'arma, de bilbow.”

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“D'elbow,” madame.$NEWLINE$madame.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“D'elbow,” madam.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Ô Seigneur Dieu! Je m'en oublie; “d'elbow.” Comment appelez-vous le col?$NEWLINE$Ô Seigneur Dieu! Je m'en oublie;$NEWLINE$appelez-vous
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Oh, Lord, I forgot! “D'elbow.” What is the word for le col?$NEWLINE$le col?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De nick,” madame.$NEWLINE$madame.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De neck,” madam.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De nick.” Et le menton?$NEWLINE$Et le menton?
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De nick.” And le menton?$NEWLINE$le menton?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De chin.”
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De chin.”

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De sin.” Le col, “de nick”; le menton, “de sin.”$NEWLINE$Le col,$NEWLINE$le menton,
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Le col, “de nick”; le menton, “de sin.”$NEWLINE$Le col,$NEWLINE$le menton,

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Oui. Sauf votre honneur, en vérité, vous prononcez les mots aussi droit que les natifs d'Angleterre.$NEWLINE$Oui. Sauf votre honneur, en vérité, vous prononcez les mots aussi droit que les natifs d'Angleterre.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Yes. If I may say so, your Highness pronounces the words just like a native English speaker.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Je ne doute point d'apprendre, par la grâce de Dieu, et en peu de temps.$NEWLINE$Je ne doute point d'apprendre, par la grâce de Dieu, et en peu de temps.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I have no doubt I’ll learn it, and in a short time, too—God willing.

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$N'avez vous pas déjà oublié ce que je vous ai enseigné?$NEWLINE$N'avez vous pas déjà oublié ce que je vous ai enseigné?
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$You haven’t forgotten what you just learned?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Non, je réciterai à vous promptement: “de hand, de fingre, de nails—”$NEWLINE$Non, je réciterai à vous promptement:
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$No, I’ll recite it for you right now: “de hand, de fangres, de nails—”

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De nails,” madame.$NEWLINE$madame.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$“De nails,” madame.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De nails, de arme, de ilbow.”
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De nails, de arme, de ilbow.”

paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Forgive me, de elbow.$NEWLINE$el

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Ainsi dis-je: “d'elbow, de nick, et de sin.” Comment appelez-vous le pied et la robe?$NEWLINE$Ainsi dis-je:$NEWLINE$Comment appelez-vous le pied et la robe?
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$That’s what I said, “de elbow, de nick, et de sin.” What are the words for le pied and la robe?$NEWLINE$le pied$NEWLINE$la robe?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$“Le foot,” madame, et “le count.”$NEWLINE$madame, et
paragraphs.translated:
ALICE$NEWLINE$“De foot,” madame, and “
de count.”$NEWLINE$de count$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“Le foot” et “de count.” Ô Seigneur Dieu! Ils sont mots de son mauvais, corruptible, gros, et impudique, et non pour les dames d'honneur d'user. Je ne voudrais prononcer ces mots devant les seigneurs de France pour tout le monde. Foh! “Le foot” et “le count”! Néanmoins, je réciterai une autre fois ma leçon ensemble: “d' hand, de fingre, de nails, d' arme, d'elbow, de nick, de sin, de foot, le count.”$NEWLINE$et$NEWLINE$Seigneur Dieu! Ils sont mots de son mauvais, corruptible, gros, et impudique, et non pour les dames d'honneur d'user. Je ne voudrais prononcer ces mots devant les seigneurs de France pour tout le monde. Foh!$NEWLINE$et$NEWLINE$Néanmoins, je réciterai une autre fois ma leçon ensemble:
paragraphs.translated:
KATHERINE$NEWLINE$“De foot” and “de count”! Oh, Lord, those are vulgar words—wicked, ugly, immodest, not fitting for respectable girls to speak. I would not utter those words in the presence of the lords of France for all the world. Ugh! “Le foot” and “le count”! Nevertheless, I will recite my lesson one more time all together: “de hand, de fangres, de nails, de arm, de elbow, de nick, de sin,
de foot, de coun.”$NEWLINE$de foot$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Excellent, madame!
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$That is excellent, madame!

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$C'est assez pour une fois: Allons-nous à d”ner.$NEWLINE$C'est assez pour une fois: Allons-nous à d”ner.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$That’s enough for one lesson. Let’s go to lunch.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the KING OF FRANCE, the DAUPHIN, the duke of BOURBON, the CONSTABLE of France, and others$NEWLINE$KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$BOURBON$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE
paragraphs.translated: The KING OF FRANCE, the DAUPHIN, the duke of BOURBON, and the CONSTABLE of France enter, with others.$NEWLINE$KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$BOURBON$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$'Tis certain he hath passed the river Somme.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$He’s certainly crossed the river Somme.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$An if he be not fought withal, my lord,$NEWLINE$Let us not live in France. Let us quit all$NEWLINE$And give our vineyards to a barbarous people.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$And if he advances unopposed, my lord, let us abandon France. Let us leave everything and give our vineyards to the barbarous nation.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Ô Dieu vivant, shall a few sprays of us,$NEWLINE$Ô Dieu vivant$NEWLINE$The emptying of our fathers' luxury,$NEWLINE$Our scions, put in wild and savage stock,$NEWLINE$Spurt up so suddenly into the clouds$NEWLINE$And overlook their grafters?
paragraphs.translated:
DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$God alive! Shall a few offshoots of our nation, born of our father’s lust—our branches grafted to wild and savage trunks—grow to such a height that they look down with contempt on the plants from which they first
sprang?$NEWLINE$sprang$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BOURBON$NEWLINE$Normans, but bastard Normans, Norman bastards!$NEWLINE$Mort de ma vie, if they march along$NEWLINE$Mort de ma vie,$NEWLINE$Unfought withal, but I will sell my dukedom$NEWLINE$To buy a slobb'ry and a dirty farm$NEWLINE$In that nook-shotten isle of Albion.
paragraphs.translated: BOURBON$NEWLINE$Normans, nothing more than bastard Normans, Norman bastards! I hope I die! If they march along unopposed, I will sell my dukedom for a sodden, filthy farm in that craggy isle of Albion.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Dieu de batailles, where have they this mettle?$NEWLINE$Dieu de batailles,$NEWLINE$Is not their climate foggy, raw, and dull,$NEWLINE$On whom, as in despite, the sun looks pale,$NEWLINE$Killing their fruit with frowns? Can sodden water,$NEWLINE$A drench for sur-reined jades, their barley broth,
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$God of battles! Where do they get this spirit? Isn’t their climate foggy, cold, and dark? Doesn’t the sun shine palely down on them, as though in contempt, killing their fruit with frowns?
