Can boiled water (beer, they call it)—a drink for broken-down horses, heat their cold blood to such a valiant level? And shall our lively blood, quickened by wine, be so frosty? Oh, for the

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Decoct their cold blood to such valiant heat?$NEWLINE$And shall our quick blood, spirited with wine,$NEWLINE$Seem frosty? Oh, for honor of our land,$NEWLINE$Let us not hang like roping icicles$NEWLINE$Upon our houses' thatch, whiles a more frosty people$NEWLINE$Sweat drops of gallant youth in our rich fields!$NEWLINE$“Poor” we may call them in their native lords.
paragraphs.translated: honor of our land, let us not hang like ropes of icicles off the thatched roofs of our houses while men of a more frosty temperament sweat off their own gallant youth in our rich fields! Our fields may be rich, but they are ruled poorly.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$By faith and honor,$NEWLINE$Our madams mock at us and plainly say$NEWLINE$Our mettle is bred out and they will give$NEWLINE$Their bodies to the lust of English youth$NEWLINE$To new-store France with bastard warriors.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$By faith and honor, our wives mock us, telling us brazenly that our vigor has been so bred out of us that they plan to give their bodies to the lusty youth of England to resupply France with men who, though bastards, will at least be warriors.

paragraphs.original: BOURBON$NEWLINE$And teach lavoltas high, and swift corantos,$NEWLINE$Saying our grace is only in our heels$NEWLINE$And that we are most lofty runaways.$NEWLINE$They bid us to the$NEWLINE$English dancing schools.
paragraphs.translated: BOURBON$NEWLINE$They tell us we’d be better off in English dancing schools, where we could teach the latest dances, as our grace is all in our heels; we are no better than high-class deserters.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Where is Montjoy the herald? Speed him hence.$NEWLINE$Let him greet England with our sharp defiance.$NEWLINE$Up, princes, and, with spirit of honor edged$NEWLINE$More sharper than your swords, hie to the field:$NEWLINE$Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France;$NEWLINE$You dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, and of Berri,$NEWLINE$Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy;$NEWLINE$Jacques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont,$NEWLINE$Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Faulconbridge,$NEWLINE$Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois;$NEWLINE$High dukes, great princes, barons, lords, and knights,$NEWLINE$For your great seats now quit you of great shames.$NEWLINE$Bar Harry England, that sweeps through our land$NEWLINE$With pennons painted in the blood of Harfleur.$NEWLINE$Rush on his host, as doth the melted snow$NEWLINE$Upon the valleys, whose low vassal seat$NEWLINE$The Alps doth spit and void his rheum upon.$NEWLINE$Go down upon him—you have power enough—$NEWLINE$And in a captive chariot into Rouen$NEWLINE$Bring him our prisoner.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Where is Montjoy, the herald? Send him on his way quickly. Tell him to greet the king of England with our sharp defiance. Rise, princes, and, with a spirit of honor more sharply edged than your swords, rush to the battlefield: Charles Delabreth, High Constable of France; you dukes of Orléans, Bourbon, Berri, Alençon, Brabant, Bar, and Burgundy; Jaques Chatillon, Rambures, Vaudemont, Beaumont, Grandpré, Roussi, and Fauconberg, Foix, Lestrale, Bouciqualt, and Charolois. High dukes, great princes, barons, lords and knights—for the sake of the great positions you hold, rid yourselves of this great shame. Stop Harry of England, who is now sweeping through our land with banners drenched in the French blood he spilled at Harfleur. Rush on his army the way the melting snow of the Alps spits on the low valleys below them. Descend on him: you have power enough. And bring him into Rouen as our prisoner.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$This becomes the great!$NEWLINE$Sorry am I his numbers are so few,$NEWLINE$His soldiers sick and famished in their march,$NEWLINE$For, I am sure, when he shall see our army$NEWLINE$He’ll drop his heart into the sink of fear$NEWLINE$And for achievement offer us his ransom.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Now that’s a mission worthy of great men! I’m only sorry that his numbers are so few and those men he has sick and starving on the march. When he sees our army, I’m sure his heart will sink with fear and he’ll offer us a large sum in exchange for avoiding battleof.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Therefore, Lord Constable, haste on Montjoy$NEWLINE$And let him say to England that we send$NEWLINE$To know what willing ransom he will give.$NEWLINE$—Prince Dauphin, you shall stay with us in Rouen.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Have Montjoy hurry, then, Lord Constable, and have him ask the king of England what he is willing to pay us to get out of the war. Prince Dauphin, you’ll stay with me in Rouen.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Not so, I do beseech your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$No, please, I beg your Majesty.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Be patient, for you shall remain with us.$NEWLINE$—Now forth, Lord Constable and princes all,$NEWLINE$And quickly bring us word of England’s fall.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Be patient, because you’re staying with me. Go now, Lord Constable and all you princes, and quickly bring us news of England’s defeat.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GOWER and FLUELLEN, meeting$NEWLINE$GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN
paragraphs.translated: GOWER and FLUELLEN enter from opposite sides of the stage.$NEWLINE$GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$How now, Captain Fluellen? Come you from the bridge?
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Greetings, Captain Fluellen! Have you just come from the bridge?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I assure you, there is very excellent services committed at the bridge.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I assure you, there are some excellent military operations being carried out at the bridge.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Is the duke of Exeter safe?
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Is the duke of Exeter safe?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$The duke of Exeter is as magnanimous as Agamemnon, and a man that I love and honor with my soul and my heart and my duty and my life and my living and my uttermost power. He is not, God be praised and blessed, any hurt in the world, but keeps the bridge most valiantly, with excellent discipline. There is an aunchient lieutenant there at the pridge. I think in my very conscience he is as valiant a man as Mark Antony, and he is a man of no estimation in the world, but I did see him do as gallant service.
paragraphs.translated:
FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$The duke of Exeter is as courageous as
Agamemnonand a man whom I love and honor deeply, with my soul, and my heart, and my duty, and my life, and my livelihood, to the very utmost of my being. He is not—God be praised and blessed—hurt in any way but is holding the bridge most valiantly, with excellent discipline. There is a standard-bearer there at the bridge. I truly think he is as valiant a man as Mark Antony. He is a man of no rank or consequence, but I saw him fight as gallantly as though he were.$NEWLINE$Agamemnon$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$What do you call him?
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$What is his name?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$He is called Aunchient Pistol.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$He is called Ensign Pistol.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$I know him not.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$I don’t know him.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL$NEWLINE$PISTOL
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL enters.$NEWLINE$PISTOL

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Here is the man.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Here he is.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Captain, I thee beseech to do me favors.$NEWLINE$The duke of Exeter doth love thee well.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Captain, I have a favor to beg of you. You’re on very good terms with the duke of Exeter.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Ay, I praise God, and I have merited some love at his hands.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, God be praised, I have managed to earn his favor.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Bardolph, a soldier firm and sound of heart$NEWLINE$And of buxom valor, hath, by cruel Fate$NEWLINE$And giddy Fortune’s furious fickle wheel,$NEWLINE$That goddess blind$NEWLINE$That stands upon the rolling restless stone—
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Bardolph, a soldier who is loyal and stout-hearted and full of valour, has, by a cruel trick of fate and a turn of silly Fortune’s wildly spinning wheel, that blind goddess who stands upon an ever-rolling stone—

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$By your patience, Aunchient Pistol, Fortune is painted blind, with a muffler afore her eyes, to signify to you that Fortune is blind; and she is painted also with a wheel to signify to you, which is the moral of it, that she is turning and inconstant, and mutability and variation; and her foot, look you, is fixed upon a spherical stone, which rolls and rolls and rolls. In good truth, the poet makes a most excellent description of it. Fortune is an excellent moral.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Now, now, Ensign Pistol. Fortune is depicted as blind, with a scarf over her eyes, to signify that she is blind. And she is depicted with a wheel to signify—this is the point—that she is turning and inconstant, and all about change and variation. And her foot, see, is planted on a spherical stone that rolls and rolls and rolls. Truly, artists do wonderful things with the image of Fortune. She provides an excellent moral.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Fortune is Bardolph’s foe and frowns on him,$NEWLINE$For he hath stolen a pax and hangèd must he be.$NEWLINE$A damnèd death!$NEWLINE$Let gallows gape for dog, let man go free,$NEWLINE$And let not hemp his windpipe suffocate.$NEWLINE$But Exeter hath given the doom of death$NEWLINE$For pax of little price.$NEWLINE$Therefore go speak—the duke will hear thy voice—$NEWLINE$And let not Bardolph’s vital thread be cut$NEWLINE$With edge of penny cord and vile reproach.$NEWLINE$Speak, Captain, for his life, and I will thee requite.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$Fortune is Bardolph’s enemy. She frowns on him, for he has stolen a
pax from a church and he must be hanged. A damnable death! It’s fine for dogs to be hung, but men should go free and not have their windpipes strangled with hemp. But Exeter has pronounced a death sentence—and for a cheap little pax. Therefore, go and speak for him! The duke will listen to you. Don’t let Bardolph’s life be brought to an end by a length of cheap rope and with this shame. Save his life, Captain, and I will repay you.$NEWLINE$pax$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Aunchient Pistol, I do partly understand your meaning.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Ensign Pistol, I think I understand you.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Why then, rejoice therefore.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’m glad to hear it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Certainly, aunchient, it is not a thing to rejoice at, for if, look you, he were my brother, I would desire the duke to use his good pleasure and put him to execution, for discipline ought to be used.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Actually, you shouldn’t be, because, see, even if he were my own brother I’d want the duke to stick to his plan and have Bardolph executed. Discipline must be kept.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Die and be damned, and figo for thy friendship!$NEWLINE$figo
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then die and be damned! And I’m giving the finger to your friendship!

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It is well.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Very well.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The fig of Spain!
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$And the
Spanish finger to you!$NEWLINE$Spanish finger$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Very good.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Very good.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Why, this is an arrant counterfeit rascal. I remember him now, a bawd, a cutpurse.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Why, that man is a total fraud and rascal. I remember him now. A pimp, a pickpocket.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I’ll assure you, he uttered as prave words at the pridge as you shall see in a summer’s day. But it is very well; what he has spoke to me, that is well, I warrant you, when time is serve.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$At the bridge he spoke as excellently as anyone I’ve ever heard, I promise you. But that’s alright. What he just said to me—it’s alright. I assure you, when the time comes—

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Why, ’tis a gull, a fool, a rogue, that now and then goes to the wars to grace himself at his return into London under the form of a soldier. And such fellows are perfect in the great commanders' names, and they will learn you by rote where services were done—at such and such a sconce, at such a breach, at such a convoy; who came off bravely, who was shot, who disgraced, what terms the enemy stood on. And this they con perfectly in the phrase of war, which they
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Why, he’s a fool, an idiot, a moron, a man who now and then joins the army so as to be able to give himself airs when he gets back to London and masquerades as a soldier. Such fellows have memorized the names of famous commanders, and they can tell you—having learned such things by rote, not by experience—where this or that battle was fought, at such and such fort, at such and such wall, with such and such protective escort. And they can say who fought well, who was

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: trick up with new-tuned oaths; and what a beard of the general’s cut and a horrid suit of the camp will do among foaming bottles and ale-washed wits is wonderful to be thought on. But you must learn to know such slanders of the age, or else you may be marvelously mistook.
paragraphs.translated: shot, who was disgraced, what terms the enemy insisted on. And they study how to express these things in proper military jargon, which they embellish with fashionable oaths. And what a beard trimmed like the general’s or a rough uniform will do among foaming mugs and brains washed with ale, you wouldn’t believe. But you must learn to recognize such liars, or you will be greatly taken advantage of.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I tell you what, Captain Gower. I do perceive he is not the man that he would gladly make show to the world he is. If I find a hole in his coat, I will tell him my mind.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I tell you what, Captain Gower; I perceive that he is not the man that he would have the world think he is. If I find an opportunity, I will give him a piece of my mind.

paragraphs.original: Drum and colors Enter KING HENRY, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY, GLOUCESTER, and soldiers enter, with a drum roll and military flags.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: Hark you, the king is coming, and I must speak with him from the pridge.—God pless your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: Listen. The king is coming, and I must speak with him about what went on at the bridge.—God bless your Majesty!

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How now, Fluellen, cam’st thou from the bridge?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Tell me, Fluellen: did you just come from the bridge?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Ay, so please your Majesty. The duke of Exeter has very gallantly maintained the pridge. The French is gone off, look you, and there is gallant and most prave passages. Marry, th' athversary was have possession of the pridge, but he is enforced to retire, and the duke of Exeter is master of the pridge. I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a prave man.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, your Majesty. The duke of Exeter has held the bridge very gallantly. The French have retreated, see, and there were great acts of courage. Indeed, the enemy nearly took the bridge, but he was forced to retreat, and the duke of Exeter holds the bridge. I can tell your Majesty, the duke is a brave man.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What men have you lost, Fluellen?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What men have you lost, Fluellen?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$The perdition of th' athversary hath been very great, reasonable great. Marry, for my part, I think the duke hath lost never a man, but one that is like to be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph, if your Majesty know the man. His face is all bubukles and whelks and knobs and flames o' fire; and his lips blows at his nose, and it is like a coal of fire, sometimes plue and sometimes red, but his nose is executed, and his fire’s out.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$The enemy’s losses have been very great, pretty substantial. To tell the truth, though, I think the duke hasn’t lost a single man, except for one who will probably be executed for robbing a church, one Bardolph—I don’t know if your Majesty knows the man. His face is all pustules and pockmarks, and pimples and inflammation, and his lips blow up toward his nose, which is like a red-hot coal, sometimes blue, sometimes red. But his nose is dead, and the fire’s put out.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We would have all such offenders so cut off, and we give express charge that in our marches through the country there be nothing compelled from the villages, nothing taken but paid for, none of the French upbraided or abused in disdainful language; for when lenity and cruelty play for a kingdom, the gentler gamester is the soonest winner.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I want all such offenders to be dealt with that way, and I give precise orders that in our progress through the country there shall be nothing seized from the villages, nothing taken that is not paid for, none of the French harassed or abused in disrespectful language. For when mercy and cruelty compete for a kingdom, the gentler player is bound to win.

paragraphs.original: Tucket Enter MONTJOY$NEWLINE$MONTJOY
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet plays. MONTJOY enters.$NEWLINE$MONTJOY

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$You know me by my habit.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$You know from my clothing who I am.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well then, I know thee. What shall I know of thee?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well then, I know who you are. What do you have to tell me?

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$My master’s mind.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$My master’s decision.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Unfold it.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Go ahead.

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$Thus says my king: “Say thou to Harry of England, though we seemed dead, we did but sleep. Advantage is a better soldier than rashness. Tell him we could have rebuked him at Harfleur, but that we thought not good to bruise an injury till it were full ripe. Now we speak upon our cue, and our voice is imperial. England shall repent his folly, see his
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$My king says this: “Tell Harry of England: though we appeared dead, we were only asleep. Strategy makes a better soldier than haste. Tell him we could have driven him back at Harfleur but thought it unwise to burst a pustule before it had fully ripened. Now the time is right for us to speak, and we do so with imperial authority. The king of England will regret his foolishness, discover his weakness, and marvel at our restraint. Tell him therefore to consider what ransom he can offer as a prisoner of war. It must be commensurate with the losses we have suffered, the subjects we

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: weakness, and admire our sufferance. Bid him therefore consider of his ransom, which must proportion the losses we have borne, the subjects we have lost, the disgrace we have digested, which, in weight to reanswer, his pettiness would bow under. For our losses, his exchequer is too poor; for th' effusion of our blood, the muster of his kingdom too faint a number; and for our disgrace, his own person, kneeling at our feet but a weak and worthless satisfaction. To this, add defiance, and tell him, for conclusion, he hath betrayed his followers, whose condemnation is pronounced.” So far my king and master; so much my office.
paragraphs.translated: have lost, and the indignity we have endured, for which he is too insignificant to sufficiently pay us back. His coffers are too poor to atone for our losses, his entire kingdom too small to account for the amount of blood we’ve shed, and the sight of him kneeling at our feet an empty satisfaction compared to the indignity we have put up with. Add defiance to all this and, by way of conclusion, tell him that he has betrayed the men who follow him, whose death sentence has been pronounced.” My king and master’s message delivered, my task is done.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What is thy name? I know thy quality.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What is your name? I know your position.

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$Montjoy.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$Montjoy.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou dost thy office fairly. Turn thee back,$NEWLINE$And tell thy king I do not seek him now$NEWLINE$But could be willing to march on to Calais$NEWLINE$Without impeachment, for, to say the sooth,$NEWLINE$Though ’tis no wisdom to confess so much$NEWLINE$Unto an enemy of craft and vantage,$NEWLINE$My people are with sickness much enfeebled,$NEWLINE$My numbers lessened, and those few I have$NEWLINE$Almost no better than so many French,$NEWLINE$Who when they were in health, I tell thee, herald,$NEWLINE$I thought upon one pair of English legs$NEWLINE$Did march three Frenchmen. Yet, forgive me, God,$NEWLINE$That I do brag thus. This your air of France$NEWLINE$Hath blown that vice in me. I must repent.$NEWLINE$Go therefore, tell thy master: here I am.$NEWLINE$My ransom is this frail and worthless trunk,$NEWLINE$My army but a weak and sickly guard,$NEWLINE$Yet, God before, tell him we will come on$NEWLINE$Though France himself and such another neighbor$NEWLINE$Stand in our way. There’s for thy labor, Montjoy.$NEWLINE$Go bid thy master well advise himself:$NEWLINE$If we may pass, we will; if we be hindered,$NEWLINE$We shall your tawny ground with your red blood$NEWLINE$Discolor. And so, Montjoy, fare you well.$NEWLINE$The sum of all our answer is but this:$NEWLINE$We would not seek a battle as we are,$NEWLINE$Nor, as we are, we say we will not shun it.$NEWLINE$So tell your master.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$You do your job well. Go back and tell your king I do not seek an encounter with him now but would be willing to march on to Calais without interference, for—to be honest, though it’s probably unwise to confess this to a powerful enemy who has the advantage—my men are considerably weakened by illness, my numbers reduced, and those few men I have almost no better than so many Frenchmen, though when they were in good form, I tell you, herald, I thought three Frenchmen walked on every pair of English legs. But God forgive me for bragging. It’s a vice I’ve picked up since I’ve been here, and I must get rid of it. Anyway, go tell your master I am here. My ransom is my own fragile, worthless body, my army but a weak and sickly escort. But, before God, tell him we will advance, even if the king of France himself and another foe as strong should stand in our way. (giving him money) That’s for your trouble, Montjoy. Go tell your master to consider carefully. If we’re allowed to pass, we will. If we’re prevented, we’ll discolor your golden ground with your red blood. And so, Montjoy, farewell. This is our whole answer: We do not seek a battle nor will we avoid one. Tell your master this.$NEWLINE$(giving him money)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$I shall deliver so. Thanks to your Highness.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$I’ll deliver the message. I thank your Highness.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I hope they will not come upon us now.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$I hope they don’t attack us now.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We are in God’s hand, brother, not in theirs.$NEWLINE$March to the bridge. It now draws toward night.$NEWLINE$Beyond the river we’ll encamp ourselves,$NEWLINE$And on tomorrow bid them march away.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We’re in God’s hands, brother, not in theirs. March to the bridge. Night is approaching. We’ll set up camp across the river and continue on tomorrow. Give the order to march.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the CONSTABLE of France, the Lord RAMBURES, ORLÉANS, DAUPHIN, with others$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$RAMBURES$NEWLINE$ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN
paragraphs.translated: The CONSTABLE of France, Lord RAMBURES, ORLÉANS, and the DAUPHIN enter, with others.$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$RAMBURES$NEWLINE$ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Tut, I have the best armor of the world. Would it were day!
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Nonsense. I have the best armor in the world. I wish it were day!

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$You have an excellent armor, but let my horse have his due.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$You have wonderful armor, but give my horse his due.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$It is the best horse of Europe.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$It is the best horse in Europe.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Will it never be morning?
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Will it never be morning?

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$My lord of Orléans, and my Lord High Constable, you talk of horse and armor?
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$My lord of Orléans, and my lord high Constable, are you talking about horses and armor?

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$You are as well provided of both as any prince in the world.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$You are as well provided in both respects as any prince in the world.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$What a long night is this! I will not change my horse with any that treads but on four pasterns. Çà ha! He bounds from the earth, as if his entrails were hairs, le cheval volant, the Pegasus, qui a les narines de feu. When I bestride him, I soar; I am a hawk; he trots the air. The earth sings when he touches it. The basest horn of his hoof is more musical than the pipe of Hermes.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$What a long night this is! I will not trade my horse for any that walks on four legs. He leaps from the ground as if his insides were light as hairs. He’s a flying horse, a Pegasus, breathing fire out of his nostrils. When I sit astride him, I soar, I am a hawk. He trots on air. The earth sings when he touches it. The lowest part of his hoof is more musical than Pan’s pipe.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He’s of the color of the nutmeg.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He’s the color of nutmeg.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$And of the heat of the ginger. It is a beast for Perseus. He is pure air and fire; and the dull elements of earth and water never appear in him, but only in patient stillness while his rider mounts him. He is indeed a horse, and all other jades you may call beasts.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$And hot as ginger. He is an animal worthy of Perseus. He is pure air and fire. The duller elements of earth and water have no part in him, except in the moment of patient stillness when his rider mounts him. He is indeed worthy of the name “horse,” and you can call all the rest beasts.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Indeed, my lord, it is a most absolute and excellent horse.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Indeed, my lord, he is a perfectly wonderful horse.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$It is the prince of palfreys. His neigh is like the bidding of a monarch, and his countenance enforces homage.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$He is the prince of horses. His neigh is like a monarch’s command. His face demands respect.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$No more, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Enough, cousin.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Nay, the man hath no wit that cannot, from the rising of the lark to the lodging of the lamb, vary deserved praise on my palfrey. It is a theme as fluent as the sea. Turn the sands into eloquent tongues, and my horse is argument for them all. 'Tis a subject for a sovereign to reason on, and for a sovereign’s sovereign to ride on, and for the world, familiar to us and unknown, to lay apart their particular functions and wonder at him. I once writ a sonnet in his praise and began thus: “Wonder of nature—”
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$No, the man who cannot extol the virtues of my horse from dawn to dusk is not particularly clever. It’s a subject as worthy of endless discussion as the changing sea. If each grain of sand had a tongue to eulogize, my horse would be a topic for them all. He is a subject for a king to contemplate, and for a king’s king to ride on, and for the world at large—both friend and stranger—to stop whatever they are doing and marvel at. I once wrote a sonnet in his praise which began, “Wonder of nature—”

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$I have heard a sonnet begin so to one’s mistress.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$I have heard a sonnet to one’s mistress that began like that.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Then did they imitate that which I composed to my courser, for my horse is my mistress.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Then the writer imitated the one I composed to my steed, for my horse is my mistress.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Your mistress bears well.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Your mistress is a good mount.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Me well—which is the prescript praise and perfection of a good and particular mistress.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$A good mount for me—and that’s the highest praise and very definition of a good mistress, that she belong to one alone.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Nay, for methought yesterday your mistress shrewdly shook your back.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Yes, but yesterday I could have sworn your mistress gave you a bumpy ride.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$So perhaps did yours.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$So, perhaps, did yours.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Mine was not bridled.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Mine wasn’t wearing a bridle.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Oh, then belike she was old and gentle, and you rode, like a kern of Ireland, your French hose off and in your straight strossers.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Oh, then I guess she was old and gentle, and you rode barelegged, like an Irish yokel.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$You have good judgment in horsemanship.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$You’re a good judge of horsemanship.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Be warned by me, then: they that ride so, and ride not warily, fall into foul bogs. I had rather have my horse to my mistress.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Take a tip from me, then. Those who don’t take care when they ride often find themselves thrown into a messy situation. I’d rather have my horse than a mistress.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I had as lief have my mistress a jade.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I’d prefer to keep my mistress rather than some lame horse.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$I tell thee, Constable, my mistress wears his own hair.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you this, Constable, my mistress has his own hair.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I could make as true a boast as that if I had a sow to my mistress.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I could make the same boast even if I had a pig as my mistress.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$“Le chien est retourné à son propre vomissement, et la truie lavée au bourbier.” Thou mak’st use of anything.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$“The dog returns to its own vomit, and the newly washed sow to its mud puddle.”$NEWLINE$You’d take anything for a mistress.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Yet do I not use my horse for my mistress, or any such proverb so little kin to the purpose.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$At least I don’t have a horse for my mistress—or a saying so beside the point.

paragraphs.original: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$My Lord Constable, the armor that I saw in your tent tonight, are those stars or suns upon it?
paragraphs.translated: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$My Lord Constable, are those stars or suns I saw on the armor in your tent tonight?

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Stars, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Stars, my lord.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Some of them will fall tomorrow, I hope.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$I hope some will fall off tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$And yet my sky shall not want.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$And yet I’ll still have plenty.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$That may be, for you bear a many superfluously, and ’twere more honor some were away.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$No doubt, for you wear too many in the first place, and it might be more seemly to make do with fewer.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Ev'n as your horse bears your praises—who would trot as well were some of your brags dismounted.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Yes, like your horse, who, staggering under your boasts, would trot more easily if some of them dismounted.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Would I were able to load him with his desert! Will it never be day? I will trot tomorrow a mile, and my way shall be paved with English faces.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$I only wish I could load him up with all the praise he deserves! Oh, will it never be day?$NEWLINE$I will ride out a mile tomorrow and leave the road paved with the faces of dead Englishmen.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I will not say so, for fear I should be faced out of my way. But I would it were morning, for I would fain be about the ears of the English.
paragraphs.translated:
CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I’d say the same thing, but I’m afraid I’d be faced out of my way. But I do wish it were
morning, for I long to be mixing it up with the English.$NEWLINE$morning$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$Who will go to hazard with me for twenty prisoners?
paragraphs.translated:
RAMBURES$NEWLINE$Would anyone like to
bet twenty prisoners with me?$NEWLINE$bet$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$You must first go yourself to hazard ere you have them.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$You’ll have to take some chances yourself before you catch them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$'Tis midnight. I’ll go arm myself.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$It’s midnight. I’ll go put my armor on.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$The Dauphin longs for morning.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$The Dauphin really wants it to be morning.

paragraphs.original: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$He longs to eat the English.
paragraphs.translated: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$He wants to eat the English.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I think he will eat all he kills.
paragraphs.translated:
CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I think he’ll
eat everyone he kills.$NEWLINE$eat$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$By the white hand of my lady, he’s a gallant prince.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$By my mistress’s white hand, he’s a gallant prince.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Swear by her foot, that she may tread out the oath.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Swear by her foot, so she can stamp out the oath.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He is simply the most active gentleman of France.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He’s definitely the most active gentleman of France.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Doing is activity, and he will still be doing.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Performing is activity, and he is always doing that.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He never did harm that I heard of.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He never did harm that I heard of.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Nor will do none tomorrow. He will keep that good name still.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$And he’s not going to do any tomorrow. That part of his reputation will stand.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$I know him to be valiant.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$I know him to be valiant.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I was told that by one that knows him better than you.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I was told that by one who knows him better than you.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$What’s he?
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Who was that?

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Marry, he told me so himself; and he said he cared not who knew it.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Why, he told me so himself, and he said he didn’t care who knew it.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He needs not. It is no hidden virtue in him.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$He doesn’t have to care. His virtue is not hidden.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$By my faith, sir, but it is; never anybody saw it but his lackey. 'Tis a hooded valor, and when it appears, it will bate.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Oh, but it is, sir. No one but his valet ever saw it. His courage is hidden, and when it is revealed, it will shrink.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Ill will never said well.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Ill will never prompted anything well said.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I will cap that proverb with “There is flattery in friendship.”
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I’ll challenge that proverb with one of my own: “There is flattery in friendship.”

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$And I will take up that with “Give the devil his due.”
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$And I’ll match that with “Give the devil his due.”

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Well placed; there stands your friend for the devil. Have at the very eye of that proverb with “A pox of the devil.”
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Very apt! Your friend is equated with the devil. I’ll go straight for that proverb with “To hell with the devil.”

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$You are the better at proverbs, by how much “A fool’s bolt is soon shot.”
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$You are better at proverbs than I am by as much as “A fool shoots quickly and overshoots his mark.”

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$You have shot over.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$You have overshot.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$'Tis not the first time you were overshot.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$I’ve outshot you, and not for the first time.

paragraphs.original: Enter MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My Lord High Constable, the English lie within fifteen hundred paces of your tents.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Who hath measured the ground?
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Who measured the ground?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The Lord Grandpré.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The Lord Grandpré.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$A valiant and most expert gentleman.—Would it were day! Alas, poor Harry of England! He longs not for the dawning as we do.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$A very valiant and knowledgeable gentleman. If only it were day! Poor Harry of England! He doesn’t long for the dawn as we do.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$What a wretched and peevish fellow is this king of England to mope with his fat-brained followers so far out of his knowledge.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$What a miserable and obstinate fellow this king of England is, to blunder with his fat-headed followers so far beyond his capacity.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$If the English had any apprehension, they would run away.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$If the English had any sense, they would run away.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$That they lack, for if their heads had any intellectual armor, they could never wear such heavy head-pieces.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Well, obviously they don’t. If there were anything inside their heads, they could never wear such heavy helmets.

paragraphs.original: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$That island of England breeds very valiant creatures. Their mastiffs are of unmatchable courage.
paragraphs.translated: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$That island of England breeds very valiant creatures. Their hounds are unequaled in courage.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Foolish curs, that run winking into the mouth of a Russian bear and have their heads crushed like rotten apples. You may as well say, that’s a valiant flea that dare eat his breakfast on the lip of a lion.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Foolish dogs, blindly running straight toward a Russian bear only to have their heads crushed like rotten apples. You might just as well say, “That’s a valiant flea that dares to eat its breakfast on the lip of a lion.”

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Just, just; and the men do sympathize with the mastiffs in robustious and rough coming on, leaving their wits with their wives. And then give them great meals of beef and iron and steel, they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Yes, exactly. And the men resemble their English hounds in their loud, showy ferocity, too, leaving their brains behind with their wives. Give them hefty meals of beef and iron and steel, and they will eat like wolves and fight like devils.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Ay, but these English are shrewdly out of beef.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Yes, but these English are seriously short of beef.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Then shall we find tomorrow they have only stomachs to eat and none to fight. Now is it time to arm. Come, shall we about it?
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Then tomorrow we’ll find that they feel only like eating, not like fighting. It’s time to put our armor on. Shall we get started?

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$It is now two o'clock. But, let me see, by ten$NEWLINE$We shall have each a hundred Englishmen.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$It’s two o'clock now. But let me see, by ten we shall each have captured a hundred Englishmen.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Now entertain conjecture of a time$NEWLINE$When creeping murmur and the poring dark$NEWLINE$Fills the wide vessel of the universe.$NEWLINE$From camp to camp, through the foul womb of night,$NEWLINE$The hum of either army stilly sounds,$NEWLINE$That the fixed sentinels almost receive$NEWLINE$The secret whispers of each other’s watch.$NEWLINE$Fire answers fire, and through their paly flames$NEWLINE$Each battle sees the other’s umbered face.$NEWLINE$Steed threatens steed, in high and boastful neighs$NEWLINE$Piercing the night’s dull ear; and from the tents$NEWLINE$The armorers, accomplishing the knights,$NEWLINE$With busy hammers closing rivets up,$NEWLINE$Give dreadful note of preparation.$NEWLINE$The country cocks do crow, the clocks do toll,$NEWLINE$And, the third hour of drowsy morning named,$NEWLINE$Proud of their numbers and secure in soul,$NEWLINE$The confident and overlusty French$NEWLINE$Do the low-rated English play at dice$NEWLINE$And chide the cripple, tardy-gaited night,$NEWLINE$Who like a foul and ugly witch doth limp$NEWLINE$So tediously away. The poor condemnèd English,$NEWLINE$Like sacrifices, by their watchful fires$NEWLINE$Sit patiently and inly ruminate$NEWLINE$The morning’s danger; and their gesture sad,$NEWLINE$Investing lank-lean cheeks and war-worn coats,$NEWLINE$Presenteth them unto the gazing moon$NEWLINE$So many horrid ghosts. Oh, now, who will behold$NEWLINE$The royal captain of this ruined band
paragraphs.translated: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Now summon up the image of stealthy murmurs and engulfing darkness filling the wide vessel of the universe. From camp to camp through the dark cave of night, the noise from both armies grows so quiet that those standing watch almost think they can hear the whispered secrets of one another’s sentinels. One by one, fires are lit on both sides, and through their pale flames, each army thinks he sees the smoke-tinged faces of the other. The horses of each army answer one another’s proud, threatening neighs as they pierce the dull night, and from the tents the sound of the blacksmiths' hammers as they fit out the knights, closing rivets up, adds a note of fear to the preparations. The country cocks crow and the clocks toll, sounding a drowsy three o'clock in the morning. Proud of their army and secure in their numbers, the confident and overeager French play dice, betting on how many worthless Englishmen each will capture. They scold the limping, slowly moving night, which, like an ugly old woman, takes so long to pass. The poor doomed English, like sacrificial beasts, sit patiently, and privately contemplate the dangers that will arrive with morning. With their grave faces, emaciated cheeks, and war-torn coats, they seem to the gazing moon like so many horrifying ghosts. Now, whoever spots the royal captain of this ruined army walking from camp to camp, from tent to tent, let him cry “Praise and glory on his head!” For out he goes visiting all his troops. He bids them good morning with a modest smile and calls

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Walking from watch to watch, from tent to tent?$NEWLINE$Let him cry, “Praise and glory on his head!”$NEWLINE$For forth he goes and visits all his host,$NEWLINE$Bids them good morrow with a modest smile,$NEWLINE$And calls them brothers, friends, and countrymen.$NEWLINE$Upon his royal face there is no note$NEWLINE$How dread an army hath enrounded him,$NEWLINE$Nor doth he dedicate one jot of color$NEWLINE$Unto the weary and all-watchèd night,$NEWLINE$But freshly looks and overbears attaint$NEWLINE$With cheerful semblance and sweet majesty,$NEWLINE$That every wretch, pining and pale before,$NEWLINE$Beholding him, plucks comfort from his looks.$NEWLINE$A largess universal, like the sun,$NEWLINE$His liberal eye doth give to everyone,$NEWLINE$Thawing cold fear, that mean and gentle all$NEWLINE$Behold, as may unworthiness define,$NEWLINE$A little touch of Harry in the night.$NEWLINE$And so our scene must to the battle fly,$NEWLINE$Where, Oh, for pity, we shall much disgrace,$NEWLINE$With four or five most vile and ragged foils$NEWLINE$Right ill-disposed in brawl ridiculous,$NEWLINE$The name of Agincourt. Yet sit and see,$NEWLINE$Minding true things by what their mock'ries be.
paragraphs.translated: them brothers, friends, and countrymen. There is no indication of the mighty army that surrounds them in his expression, nor has the long, sleepless night robbed his face of an ounce of color. Instead, he looks fresh and covers any signs of fatigue with a show of cheerfulness and sweet majesty that every sad and pale wretch takes comfort in when they see him. His generous eye notices everyone, doling out a bounty as far-reaching as the sun, thawing cold fear, so that low and well-born alike may all experience (for want of a better way of putting it) a little touch of Harry in the night. With that, our scene rushes on toward the battle, which we will represent with four or five worn-out fencing foils, a travesty of battle—forgive us!—that disgraces the name of Agincourt. Still, stay to watch, imagining the way it really was from our own inadequate imitation.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter KING HENRY, BEDFORD, and GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY enters with BEDFORD and GLOUCESTER.$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Gloucester, ’tis true that we are in great danger.$NEWLINE$The greater therefore should our courage be.$NEWLINE$—Good morrow, brother Bedford. God almighty,$NEWLINE$There is some soul of goodness in things evil,$NEWLINE$Would men observingly distill it out.$NEWLINE$For our bad neighbor makes us early stirrers,$NEWLINE$Which is both healthful and good husbandry.$NEWLINE$Besides, they are our outward consciences$NEWLINE$And preachers to us all, admonishing$NEWLINE$That we should dress us fairly for our end.$NEWLINE$Thus may we gather honey from the weed$NEWLINE$And make a moral of the devil himself.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Gloucester, it’s true that we are in great danger. But our courage should only be the greater for that. Good morning, brother Bedford. God Almighty, there must be some essential goodness even in evil, if men would only look for it. In our case, our bad neighbors over their make us early risers, a healthy and sensible thing to be. Besides, they act as outward consciences and preachers to us all, a visible reminder that we should prepare ourselves for death. Think like that, and you’ll manage to get honey out of a common weed and find a moral lesson in the devil himself.

paragraphs.original: Enter ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$ERPINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM enters.$NEWLINE$ERPINGHAM

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, old Sir Thomas Erpingham.$NEWLINE$A good soft pillow for that good white head$NEWLINE$Were better than a churlish turf of France.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, old Sir Thomas Erpingham! A nice, soft pillow would be a more suitable place to lay that good white head than France’s hard, cold ground.

paragraphs.original: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$Not so, my liege, this lodging likes me better,$NEWLINE$Since I may say, “Now lie I like a king.”
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$Not at all, my liege. I prefer these quarters, since they allow me to say, “Now I live like a king.”

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$'Tis good for men to love their present pains$NEWLINE$Upon example. So the spirit is eased.$NEWLINE$And when the mind is quickened, out of doubt,$NEWLINE$The organs, though defunct and dead before,$NEWLINE$Break up their drowsy grave and newly move,$NEWLINE$With casted slough and fresh legerity.$NEWLINE$Lend me thy cloak, Sir Thomas. Brothers both,$NEWLINE$Commend me to the princes in our camp,$NEWLINE$Do my good morrow to them, and anon$NEWLINE$Desire them all to my pavilion.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It’s good for men to be given an example of how to take pleasure in discomfort. It eases the spirit. And when the mind is engaged, the rest of the body, dead and dull before, wakes up and comes to life with a new nimbleness and sensitivity, like a snake shedding its dead skin. Lend me your cloak, Sir Thomas. Brothers, give my regards to the princes in our camp. Say good day to them from me and ask them to come to my tent.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$We shall, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$We shall, my liege.

paragraphs.original: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$Shall I attend your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$Shall I accompany your Grace?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, my good knight.$NEWLINE$Go with my brothers to my lords of England.$NEWLINE$I and my bosom must debate awhile,$NEWLINE$And then I would no other company.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, my good knight. Go with my brothers to my English peers. I need to be alone with my thoughts for a while and don’t want any company.

paragraphs.original: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$The Lord in heaven bless thee, noble Harry!
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$The Lord in heaven bless you, noble Harry!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but KING HENRY$NEWLINE$KING HENRY
paragraphs.translated: All but KING HENRY exit.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$God-a-mercy, old heart, thou speak’st cheerfully.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Bless you, old soul! Your words cheer my heart.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL$NEWLINE$PISTOL
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL enters.$NEWLINE$PISTOL

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Qui vous là?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Who goes there?$NEWLINE$speaking in French

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$A friend.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$A friend.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Discuss unto me: art thou officer or art thou base, common, and popular?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Declare yourself to me. Are you an officer? Or are you low, vulgar, and of the common people?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I am a gentleman of a company.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I am a gentleman of a company.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Trail’st thou the puissant pike?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Do you carry a pike?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Even so. What are you?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Exactly. What about you?

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$As good a gentleman as the emperor.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’m as good a gentleman as the emperor.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then you are a better than the king.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then you’re a better man than the king.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The king’s a bawcock, and a heart of gold,$NEWLINE$A lad of life, an imp of fame,$NEWLINE$Of parents good, of fist most valiant.$NEWLINE$I kiss his dirty shoe, and from heartstring$NEWLINE$I love the lovely bully. What is thy name?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The king’s a dear boy with a heart of gold, he’s a lively lad, a wag, born of fine parents, good with his fists. I kiss his dirty shoe, and from the bottom of my heart I love the lovely boy. What is your name?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Harry le Roy.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Harry le Roy.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Le Roy? A Cornish name. Art thou of Cornish crew?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Le Roy? That’s a Cornish name. Are you with a Cornish company?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, I am a Welshman.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, I am a Welshman.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Know’st thou Fluellen?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Do you know Fluellen?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Tell him I’ll knock his leek about his pate$NEWLINE$Upon Saint Davy’s day.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Tell him I’ll take the leek out of his hat on Saint Davy’s Day and slap his head with it.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Do not you wear your dagger in your cap that day, lest he knock that about yours.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$You’d better not wear your dagger in your cap that day, or he might slap your head with it.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Art thou his friend?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Are you his friend?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$And his kinsman too.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes, and his relative, too.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$The figo for thee then!$NEWLINE$figo
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Then I’m giving you the finger.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I thank you. God be with you.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Thank you. God be with you.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$My name is Pistol called.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$My name is Pistol.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It sorts well with your fierceness.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$The name suits your fierceness.

paragraphs.original: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN and GOWER enter.$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Captain Fluellen.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Captain Fluellen!

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$So. In the name of Jesu Christ, speak fewer. It is the greatest admiration in the universal world when the true and aunchient prerogatifes and laws of the wars is not kept. If you would take the pains but to examine the wars of Pompey the Great, you shall find, I warrant you, that there is no tiddle toddle nor pibble babble in Pompey’s camp. I warrant you, you shall find the ceremonies of the wars and the cares of it and the forms of it and the sobriety of it and the modesty of it to be otherwise.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$In the name of Jesus Christ, keep it down! It never ceases to amaze me the way people ignore the correct, traditional principles and rules of war. If you would take the trouble to study the tactics of Pompey the Great, I can tell you that you would find no tittle-tattle or pibble-pabble in Pompey’s camp. I tell you, you would find the rituals of war and, I promise you, its ceremonies and its solicitudes and its forms and its gravity and its discipline all to be quite counter to all this noise.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Why, the enemy is loud. You hear him all night.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$But the enemy is loud. You can hear them all night long.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, is it meet, think you, that we should also, look you, be an ass and a fool and a prating coxcomb, in your own conscience, now?
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$And if the enemy is an ass and a fool and a prating idiot, does that mean, you think, that we should also be an ass and a fool and a prating idiot? Think about it.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$I will speak lower.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$I will lower my voice.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I pray you and beseech you that you will.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I’d be very glad if you would.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt GOWER and FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN
paragraphs.translated: GOWER and FLUELLEN exit.$NEWLINE$GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Though it appear a little out of fashion,$NEWLINE$There is much care and valor in this Welshman.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Though he seems a little old-fashioned, there is much care and courage in this Welshman.

paragraphs.original: Enter three soldiers, John BATES, Alexander COURT, and Michael WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$BATES$NEWLINE$COURT$NEWLINE$WILLIAMS
paragraphs.translated: Three soldiers, John BATES, Alexander COURT, and Michael WILLIAMS, enter.$NEWLINE$BATES$NEWLINE$COURT$NEWLINE$WILLIAMS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: COURT$NEWLINE$Brother John Bates, is not that the morning which breaks yonder?
paragraphs.translated: COURT$NEWLINE$Brother John Bates, isn’t that dawn breaking over there?

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$I think it be, but we have no great cause to desire the approach of day.
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$I think it is. But we have no great reason to long for day.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$We see yonder the beginning of the day, but I think we shall never see the end of it.—Who goes there?
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$That’s the beginning of the day we see, but I don’t think we’ll see the end of it.—Who goes there?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$A friend.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$A friend.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Under what captain serve you?
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$What captain do you serve?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Sir Thomas Erpingham.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$A good old commander and a most kind gentleman. I pray you, what thinks he of our estate?
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$A veteran commander and a very kind gentleman. Tell me, what does he think of our situation?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Even as men wracked upon a sand, that look to be washed off the next tide.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We’re men beached on the sand, hoping to be washed out by the next tide.

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$He hath not told his thought to the king?
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$He hasn’t told this to the king, has he?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No. Nor it is not meet he should, for, though I speak it to you, I think the king is but a man as I am. The violet smells to him as it doth to me. The element shows to him as it doth to me. All his senses have but human conditions. His ceremonies laid by, in his nakedness he appears but a man, and though his affections are higher mounted than ours, yet when they stoop, they stoop with the like wing. Therefore, when he sees reason of fears as we do, his fears, out of doubt, be of the same relish as ours are. Yet, in reason, no man should possess him with any appearance of fear, lest he, by showing it, should dishearten his army.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, nor would it be right for him to. Though it’s not my place to say so, I think the king is, after all, only a man, the same as me. The violet smells to him the same as it does to me. The sky appears to him much as it does to me, and all his senses are those of a mortal man. Without his fine clothes, the king appears just like any other naked man. And though his feelings may be pitched higher than ours, when they plummet, they plummet that much farther. Therefore, when he has reason to fear, as we do, his fears are without question of the same order. Still, it stands to reason that he mustn’t betray his fear, as it might dishearten his army.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$He may show what outward courage he will, but I believe, as cold a night as ’tis, he could wish himself in Thames up to the neck; and so I would he were, and I by him, at all adventures, so we were quit here.
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$He can act as brave as he wants, but I believe on a cold night like this he wishes he were neck-deep in the Thames, and I wish he were, too, and I with him, whatever the danger, so long as we were far away from here.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$By my troth, I will speak my conscience of the king. I think he would not wish himself anywhere but where he is.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you truly what I think about the king in my heart. I don’t think he wants to be anywhere but where he is.

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$Then I would he were here alone; so should he be sure to be ransomed, and a many poor men’s lives saved.
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$Then I wish he were here alone. He’d be sure to be ransomed, and many a poor man’s life saved.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I dare say you love him not so ill to wish him here alone, howsoever you speak this to feel other men’s minds. Methinks I could not die anywhere so contented as in the king’s company, his cause being just and his quarrel honorable.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, I’m sure you don’t dislike him so much as to wish he were here alone, even though you say this to find out how the rest of us feel. I don’t think there’s anywhere I’d rather die than in the king’s company, as his cause is just and honorable.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$That’s more than we know.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$That’s more than we know.

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$Ay, or more than we should seek after, for we know enough if we know we are the king’s subjects. If his cause be wrong, our obedience to the king wipes the crime of it out of us.
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$Yes, and more than we should seek to know. It’s enough that we know we’re the king’s subjects. If his cause is wrong, our obedience to the king clears us of responsibility for it.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$But if the cause be not good, the king himself hath a heavy reckoning to make, when all those legs and arms and heads, chopped off in a battle, shall join together at the latter day, and cry all, “We died at such a place,” some swearing, some crying for a surgeon, some upon their wives left poor behind them, some upon the debts they owe, some upon their children rawly left. I am afeard there are few die well that die in a battle, for how can they charitably dispose of anything, when blood is their argument? Now, if these men do not die well, it will be a black matter for the king that led them to it, who to disobey were against all proportion of subjection.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$But if the cause is not just, the king himself will have a lot to answer for, when all those legs and arms and heads chopped off in battle shall join together on Judgment Day crying, “We died at such and such a place.” Some will be swearing, some crying for a surgeon, some for the wives that are destitute without them, some about the debts they owed, some for their children left unprovided for. I think few die well who die in battle. How can a person expect to resolve anything in a Christian manner when they’ve passed their lives killing? Now, if these men don’t die in a state of grace, it will be a heavy charge against the king who led them into battle, whom they, as his subjects, could not disobey.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$So, if a son that is by his father sent about merchandise do sinfully miscarry upon the sea, the imputation of his wickedness, by your rule, should be imposed upon his father that sent him. Or if a servant, under his master’s command transporting a sum of money, be assailed by robbers and die in many irreconciled iniquities, you may call the business of the master the author of the servant’s damnation. But this is not so. The king is not bound to answer the particular endings of his soldiers, the father of his son, nor the master of his servant, for they purpose not their death, when they purpose their services. Besides, there is no king, be his cause never so spotless, if it come to the arbitrament of swords, can try it out with all unspotted soldiers. Some, peradventure, have on them the guilt of premeditated and contrived murder; some, of beguiling virgins with the broken seals of perjury; some, making the wars their bulwark, that have before gored the gentle bosom of peace with pillage and robbery. Now, if these men have defeated the law and outrun native punishment, though they can outstrip men, they have no wings to fly from God. War is His beadle, war is His vengeance, so that here men are punished for before-breach of the king’s laws in now the king’s quarrel. Where they feared the death, they have borne life away; and where they would be safe, they perish. Then, if they die unprovided, no more is the king guilty of their damnation than he was before guilty of those impieties for the which they are now visited. Every subject’s duty is the king’s, but every subject’s soul is his own. Therefore should every soldier in the wars do as every sick man in his bed: wash every mote out of his conscience. And, dying so, death is to him advantage; or not dying, the time was blessedly lost wherein such preparation was gained. And in him that escapes, it were not sin to think that, making God so free an offer, He let him outlive that day to see His greatness and to teach others how they should prepare.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$The king isn’t responsible for the particular end each soldier comes to, nor is the father responsible for his son’s final end or the master for his servant’s. The father and the master and the king didn’t order their subordinates' deaths when they ordered their services. Besides, there’s no king, however pure his cause, who, if it comes to a trial by combat, can rely on using completely blameless soldiers. Perhaps some may be guilty of plotting murder, some of seducing maidens with lies and then abandoning them; some, of looting and stealing before they were even hired as soldiers. Even if these men have escaped the law and punishment at home, they cannot escape God. War is God’s agent of justice. War is vengeance. So there are men here who have broken the king’s law earlier and are punished now in his war. When they feared death, they escaped with their lives; and now where they imagine they’re safe, they perish. So, if they die unprepared, the king is no more guilty of their damnation than he was guilty of the earlier crimes they’re finally being punished for. Every subject’s duty is the king’s, but every subject’s soul is his own. Therefore, every soldier should do as any man who is sick in his bed would do: clear his conscience of any stain. Then if he dies, his death serves him. Or, if he doesn’t die, the time he spent preparing himself was at least blessed. And in the case of the man who survives, one could be forgiven for supposing that God spared him exactly because he was so ready to die; now he can live to appreciate God’s greatness and teach others to prepare.By this reasoning, if a son is sent by his father on business and drowns at sea while still in a state of sin, his wickedness is his father’s fault. Or if a servant, carrying a sum of money for his master, is attacked by robbers and dies without confessing his sins, we can say that the master’s business is to blame for the servant’s damnation. But that isn’t so.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$'Tis certain, every man that dies ill, the ill upon his own head. The king is not to answer it.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$It’s clear, every man must take responsibility for the manner of his own death. The king is not responsible for it.

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$I do not desire he should answer for me, and yet I determine to fight lustily for him.
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$I don’t expect him to answer for me, and yet I’m determined to fight vigorously for him.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I myself heard the king say he would not be ransomed.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Ay, he said so, to make us fight cheerfully, but when our throats are cut, he may be ransomed, and we ne'er the wiser.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Sure, he said so to make us fight cheerfully. But when our throats are cut, he could be ransomed without our being any the wiser.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$If I live to see it, I will never trust his word after.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$If I live to see it, I’ll never trust his word again.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$You pay him then. That’s a perilous shot out of an elder gun, that a poor and private displeasure can do against a monarch. You may as well go about to turn the sun to ice with fanning in his face with a peacock’s feather. You’ll “never trust his word after.” Come, ’tis a foolish saying.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Yeah, right, go get him. That’s a lame threat from a toy gun, a poor individual’s private displeasure with a monarch. You may as well try to turn the sun to ice by fanning its face with a peacock feather. You’ll “never trust his word again.” Come on, that was a stupid thing to say.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Your reproof is something too round. I should be angry with you if the time were convenient.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Your scolding is somewhat overblown. I’d be angry with you if the occasion allowed.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Let it be a quarrel between us, if you live.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I embrace it.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m game.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$How shall I know thee again?
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$How will I recognize you in the future?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Give me any gage of thine, and I will wear it in my bonnet. Then, if ever thou dar’st acknowledge it, I will make it my quarrel.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Give me some trinket of yours, and I will wear it in my hat. Then, if you dare to acknowledge it, I’ll take up my quarrel with you.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Here’s my glove. Give me another of thine.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Here’s my glove; give me one of yours.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$There.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$This will I also wear in my cap. If ever thou come to me and say, after tomorrow, “This is my glove,” by this hand I will take thee a box on the ear.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I’ll also wear this in my cap. If you come to me after tomorrow and say, “That’s my glove,” I swear by this hand, I will take it and give you a box on the ear.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$If ever I live to see it, I will challenge it.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$If I ever see it, I will challenge you.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Thou dar’st as well be hanged.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$You may as well undertake to be hanged.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, I will do it, though I take thee in the king’s company.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’ll do it even if I find you in the company of the king himself.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Keep thy word. Fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Keep your word. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: BATES$NEWLINE$Be friends, you English fools, be friends. We have French quarrels enough, if you could tell how to reckon.
paragraphs.translated: BATES$NEWLINE$Be friends, you English fools, be friends: we have enough enemies on the French side, if either of you could count.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Indeed, the French may lay twenty French crowns to one they will beat us, for they bear them on their shoulders. But it is no English treason to cut French crowns, and tomorrow the king himself will be a clipper.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Indeed, the French can bet twenty French crowns to one that they’ll beat us, they have such an army. But it’s no treason for an Englishman to cut off a French crown—a head, I mean—and tomorrow the king himself will do some snipping.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt soldiers
paragraphs.translated: BATES, COURT, and WILLIAMS exit.$NEWLINE$BATES$NEWLINE$COURT$NEWLINE$WILLIAMS

paragraphs.original: Upon the king! Let us our lives, our souls, our debts, our careful wives, our children, and our sins lay on the king!$NEWLINE$We must bear all. O hard condition,$NEWLINE$Twin-born with greatness, subject to the breath$NEWLINE$Of every fool, whose sense no more can feel$NEWLINE$But his own wringing. What infinite heart’s ease$NEWLINE$Must kings neglect that private men enjoy?$NEWLINE$And what have kings that privates have not too,$NEWLINE$Save ceremony, save general ceremony?$NEWLINE$And what art thou, thou idol ceremony?$NEWLINE$What kind of god art thou, that suffer’st more$NEWLINE$Of mortal griefs than do thy worshippers?$NEWLINE$What are thy rents? What are thy comings in?$NEWLINE$O ceremony, show me but thy worth!$NEWLINE$What is thy soul of adoration?$NEWLINE$Art thou aught else but place, degree, and form,$NEWLINE$Creating awe and fear in other men,$NEWLINE$Wherein thou art less happy, being feared,$NEWLINE$Than they in fearing?$NEWLINE$What drink’st thou oft, instead of homage sweet,$NEWLINE$But poisoned flattery?
