Oh, be sick, great greatness,$NEWLINE$And bid thy ceremony give thee cure!$NEWLINE$Think’st thou the fiery fever will go out$NEWLINE$With titles blown from adulation?$NEWLINE$Will it give place to flexure and low bending?$NEWLINE$Canst thou, when thou command’st the beggar’s knee,$NEWLINE$Command the health of it? No, thou proud dream,$NEWLINE$That play’st so subtly with a king’s repose.$NEWLINE$I am a king that find thee, and I know$NEWLINE$'Tis not the balm, the scepter, and the ball,$NEWLINE$The sword, the mace, the crown imperial,$NEWLINE$The intertissued robe of gold and pearl,$NEWLINE$The farcèd title running 'fore the king,$NEWLINE$The throne he sits on, nor the tide of pomp
paragraphs.translated:
Upon the king! “Let’s lay everything upon the king: our lives, our souls, our debts, our anxious wives, our children, and our sins.” I must bear responsibility for all of it. What a painful condition responsibility is. It goes along with being born to greatness, but it makes you get badmouthed by every fool who only has his own suffering to care about. What infinite peace do king’s give up that private men enjoy? What do kings have that private men do not, besides the pomp of their position? And what is this useless ceremony of kings? What kind of god is ceremony, which suffers more than its worshippers do? What income, what profit does it bring in? Oh, ceremony, only show me your value! Why are you adored? Do you amount to anything besides position, status, and ritual, which inspire awe and fear in others? You’re less happy, being feared, than they are in fearing you. What do you get to drink, instead of sweet obedience, but poisonous flattery? Try being sick, great greatness, and see if ceremony can cure you! Do you think fiery fever can be put out by the windy puff of titles? Will it be chased away by bowing and scraping? You can command a beggar to bow on bended knee, but can you take possession of his health? No, vain illusion, so intricately bound up with a king’s rest. I who understand you, gorgeous ceremony, because I’m a
king and I know that neither the balm, the scepter, and the ball, the robe layered in gold and pearls, the fancy title that precedes the king, the throne he sits on, nor the tide of pomp that beats upon the high shore of this world —not all of these put together, not all of these laid down at night in an imperial bed, can cause the king to rest so soundly as does the miserable wretch who turns in at night with a full stomach and an empty mind, fed on the bread of his daily struggle. He never wakes to horrifying darkness, born of hell, but sweats in the hot sun from dawn to$NEWLINE$king$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That beats upon the high shore of this world.$NEWLINE$No, not all these, thrice-gorgeous ceremony,$NEWLINE$Not all these, laid in bed majestical,$NEWLINE$Can sleep so soundly as the wretched slave,$NEWLINE$Who, with a body filled and vacant mind,$NEWLINE$Gets him to rest, crammed with distressful bread;$NEWLINE$Never sees horrid night, the child of hell,$NEWLINE$But, like a lackey, from the rise to set$NEWLINE$Sweats in the eye of Phoebus, and all night$NEWLINE$Sleeps in Elysium; next day after dawn,$NEWLINE$Doth rise and help Hyperion to his horse,$NEWLINE$And follows so the ever-running year$NEWLINE$With profitable labor to his grave.$NEWLINE$And, but for ceremony, such a wretch,$NEWLINE$Winding up days with toil and nights with sleep,$NEWLINE$Had the forehand and vantage of a king.$NEWLINE$The slave, a member of the country’s peace,$NEWLINE$Enjoys it, but in gross brain little wots$NEWLINE$What watch the king keeps to maintain the peace,$NEWLINE$Whose hours the peasant best advantages.
paragraphs.translated: dusk and all night long sleeps in peace. Come morning, he wakes and helps the sun into his chariot and so wears out the ever-rolling years until his death. Apart from ceremony, this poor creature who spends his days in toil and his nights in sleep is better off than the king. The peasant enjoys his country’s peace without ever worrying his dull head about the vigil the king must keep to maintain that peace.

paragraphs.original: Enter ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$ERPINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM enters.$NEWLINE$ERPINGHAM

paragraphs.original: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$My lord, your nobles, jealous of your absence,$NEWLINE$Seek through your camp to find you.
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$My lord, your noble subjects are looking for you all over the camp. They’re anxious to see you.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Good old knight,$NEWLINE$Collect them all together at my tent.$NEWLINE$I’ll be before thee.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Good old knight, gather them all together at my tent. I’ll meet you there.

paragraphs.original: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$I shall do’t, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$Consider it done, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$O God of battles, steel my soldiers' hearts.$NEWLINE$Possess them not with fear. Take from them now$NEWLINE$The sense of reck'ning ere th' opposèd numbers$NEWLINE$Pluck their hearts from them. Not today, O Lord,$NEWLINE$Oh, not today, think not upon the fault$NEWLINE$My father made in compassing the crown.$NEWLINE$I Richard’s body have interrèd anew,$NEWLINE$And on it have bestowed more contrite tears$NEWLINE$Than from it issued forcèd drops of blood.$NEWLINE$Five hundred poor I have in yearly pay,$NEWLINE$Who twice a day their withered hands hold up$NEWLINE$Toward heaven to pardon blood. And I have built$NEWLINE$Two chantries where the sad and solemn priests$NEWLINE$Sing still for Richard’s soul. More will I do—$NEWLINE$Though all that I can do is nothing worth,$NEWLINE$Since that my penitence comes after all,$NEWLINE$Imploring pardon.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh God of battles, bolster my soldiers' courage. Don’t let them know fear. Rob them of the ability to count before the numbers against them overwhelm their courage. And just for today, Oh, Lord, just today don’t think of the crime my father committed in seizing the crown! I’ve transferred Richard’s body to a new grave and on it poured more tears of remorse than it has shed drops of blood. I’ve hired five hundred almsmen to hold up their withered hands to heaven, praying for my pardon twice a day throughout the year. And I’ve built two chapels where solemn priests sing continually for Richard’s soul. I will do more, though nothing I can do is any good since this remorse comes after the crime, asking for pardon.

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER enters.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$My liege.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$My liege.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$My brother Gloucester’s voice.—Ay,$NEWLINE$I know thy errand. I will go with thee.$NEWLINE$The day, my friends, and all things stay for me.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$My brother Gloucester’s voice? Yes, I know why you’ve come. I’ll go with you. The day, my friends, and everything await me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the DAUPHIN, ORLÉANS, RAMBURES, and others$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$RAMBURES
paragraphs.translated: The DAUPHIN enters with ORLÉANS, RAMBURES, and others.$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$RAMBURES

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$The sun doth gild our armor. Up, my lords.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$The sun glints off our armor. Awake, my lords!

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Montez à cheval! My horse, varlet! Lackey! Ha!$NEWLINE$Montez à cheval!
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Mount up our horses! Bring my horse, lackey! Ha!

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$O brave spirit!
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Oh, brave spirit!

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Via les eaux et la terre.$NEWLINE$Via les eaux et la terre.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$He’ll take me through flood and field.

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Rien puis? L'air et feu?$NEWLINE$Rien puis? L'air et feu?
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Is that all? How about air and fire?

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Cieux, cousin Orléans.$NEWLINE$Cieux,
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Just the heavens, cousin OrlÉans.

paragraphs.original: Enter CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE
paragraphs.translated: The CONSTABLE enters.$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE

paragraphs.original: Now, my Lord Constable?
paragraphs.translated: Is it time, my Lord Constable?

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Hark how our steeds for present service neigh.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Listen to our horses neighing, longing to be working.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Mount them and make incision in their hides,$NEWLINE$That their hot blood may spin in English eyes$NEWLINE$And dout them with superfluous courage. Ha!
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Mount them and dig your spurs into their flanks so that their hot blood may spurt in English eyes and douse them with some of the spare courage we have around. Ha!

paragraphs.original: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?$NEWLINE$How shall we then behold their natural tears?
paragraphs.translated: RAMBURES$NEWLINE$What, you want them to weep our horses' blood? Then how will we see their own natural tears?

paragraphs.original: Enter MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The English are embattled, you French peers.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The English are in the field, French lords.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$To horse, you gallant princes, straight to horse.$NEWLINE$Do but behold yond poor and starvèd band,$NEWLINE$And your fair show shall suck away their souls,$NEWLINE$Leaving them but the shales and husks of men.$NEWLINE$There is not work enough for all our hands,$NEWLINE$Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins$NEWLINE$To give each naked curtal axe a stain,$NEWLINE$That our French gallants shall today draw out$NEWLINE$And sheathe for lack of sport. Let us but blow on them,$NEWLINE$The vapor of our valor will o'erturn them.$NEWLINE$'Tis positive against all exceptions, lords,$NEWLINE$That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants,$NEWLINE$Who in unnecessary action swarm$NEWLINE$About our squares of battle, were enough$NEWLINE$To purge this field of such a hilding foe,$NEWLINE$Though we upon this mountain’s basis by$NEWLINE$Took stand for idle speculation,$NEWLINE$But that our honors must not. What’s to say?$NEWLINE$A very little little let us do,$NEWLINE$And all is done. Then let the trumpets sound$NEWLINE$The tucket sonance and the note to mount,$NEWLINE$For our approach shall so much dare the field$NEWLINE$That England shall couch down in fear and yield.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$To our horses, you gallant princes. Let’s mount straight away. All we have to do is look at that poor starving army, and our wonderful display of strength will eat away their souls, leaving them the mere husk of men. There isn’t enough work out there to keep us all busy, and hardly enough blood in all their sickly veins put together to put a stain on each of our swords, which our French knights will take out and then put away again, with nothing to do. Let’s blow on them. The breath of our valor will send them sprawling. There’s no question, lords, but that those extra servants and peasants swarming uselessly around our battle formations would be sufficient to rid this field of such a good-for-nothing foe, while we ourselves stood at the base of this mountain idly looking on. But our honor wouldn’t stand for that. What’s there to say? Doing the very least will do the whole job. Let the trumpets sound the signal to mount up and march. Our advance will so dazzle the enemy that England will cower in fear and surrender.

paragraphs.original: Enter GRANDPRÉ$NEWLINE$GRANDPRÉ
paragraphs.translated: GRANDPRÉ enters.$NEWLINE$GRANDPRÉ

paragraphs.original: GRANDPRÉ$NEWLINE$Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?$NEWLINE$Yond island carrions, desperate of their bones,$NEWLINE$Ill-favoredly become the morning field.$NEWLINE$Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose,$NEWLINE$And our air shakes them passing scornfully.$NEWLINE$Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggared host$NEWLINE$And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps.
paragraphs.translated: GRANDPRÉ$NEWLINE$What are you waiting for, lords of France? Those island-bred skeletons, terrified for their bones, are an offensive sight on the morning field. Their ragged banners hang in shreds and the very air of France makes them shiver as it blows by. The god of war looks like a pathetic bankrupt in this miserable army, peeking timidly through a rusty visor. The horsemen stand frozen like candlesticks, torches in their hands. The poor

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The horsemen sit like fixèd candlesticks$NEWLINE$With torch staves in their hand, and their poor jades$NEWLINE$Lob down their heads, dropping the hides and hips,$NEWLINE$The gum down-roping from their pale-dead eyes,$NEWLINE$And in their pale dull mouths the gemeled bit$NEWLINE$Lies foul with chawed grass, still and motionless.$NEWLINE$And their executors, the knavish crows,$NEWLINE$Fly o'er them all, impatient for their hour.$NEWLINE$Description cannot suit itself in words$NEWLINE$To demonstrate the life of such a battle$NEWLINE$In life so lifeless, as it shows itself.
paragraphs.translated:
horses droop their heads, their flanks and hips sagging, pus seeping from eyes as pale as death, and in their colorless mouths, the motionless bit is smeared with chewed grass. Meanwhile, their
executors, malicious crows, fly over them, impatient for their moment. It’s beyond the power of words to describe an army so bereft of life.$NEWLINE$executors$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$They’ve said their prayers, and now they wait for death.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits,$NEWLINE$And give their fasting horses provender,$NEWLINE$And after fight with them?
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Shall we go send them food and fresh clothing and feed their starving horses before we fight them?

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I stay but for my guard. On, to the field!$NEWLINE$I will the banner from a trumpet take$NEWLINE$And use it for my haste. Come, come away.$NEWLINE$The sun is high, and we outwear the day.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$I’m just waiting for my flag-bearer. But, never mind, I can’t wait. To the field! I’ll take the banner from a trumpeter and use that. Come, let’s be off! The sun is up and we’re wasting the day!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, ERPINGHAM, with all his host, SALISBURY, and WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$SALISBURY$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER, BEDFORD, EXETER, ERPINGHAM, with his troops, SALISBURY, and WESTMORELAND enter.$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$ERPINGHAM$NEWLINE$SALISBURY$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Where is the king?
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$Where is the king?

paragraphs.original: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$The king himself is rode to view their battle.
paragraphs.translated: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$The king rode out alone to view their troops.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Of fighting men they have full threescore thousand.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$They have fully sixty thousand fighting men.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$There’s five to one. Besides, they all are fresh.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$That’s five to one. Besides, they’re fresh.

paragraphs.original: SALISBURY$NEWLINE$God’s arm strike with us! 'Tis a fearful odds.$NEWLINE$God be wi' you, princes all. I’ll to my charge.$NEWLINE$If we no more meet till we meet in heaven,$NEWLINE$Then joyfully, my noble Lord of Bedford,$NEWLINE$My dear Lord Gloucester, and my good Lord Exeter,$NEWLINE$And my kind kinsman, warriors all, adieu.
paragraphs.translated: SALISBURY$NEWLINE$May God’s arm strike on our side! These are frightening odds. God be with all of you, princes. I’ll go and join my men. If we don’t meet again before we meet in heaven, still we’ll meet joyfully. My noble Lord of Bedford, my dear Lord Gloucester, and my good Lord Exeter, and my kind kinsmen, warriors all, adieu.

paragraphs.original: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$Farewell, good Salisbury, and good luck go with thee.
paragraphs.translated: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$Farewell, good Salisbury; and may good luck go with you.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Farewell, kind lord. Fight valiantly today.$NEWLINE$And yet I do thee wrong to mind thee of it,$NEWLINE$For thou art framed of the firm truth of valor.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Farewell, kind lord. Fight valiantly today. But then I do you wrong to say as much, since you are the very embodiment of bravery.

paragraphs.original: Exit SALISBURY$NEWLINE$SALISBURY
paragraphs.translated: SALISBURY exits.$NEWLINE$SALISBURY

paragraphs.original: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$He is as full of valor as of kindness,$NEWLINE$Princely in both.
paragraphs.translated: BEDFORD$NEWLINE$He is as full of courage as of kindness, princely in both.

paragraphs.original: Enter KING HENRY$NEWLINE$KING HENRY
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRYenters.$NEWLINE$KING HENRY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Oh, that we now had here$NEWLINE$But one ten thousand of those men in England$NEWLINE$That do no work today.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Oh, if only we had with us here ten thousand of those men back home in England who aren’t working today.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What’s he that wishes so?$NEWLINE$My cousin Westmoreland? No, my fair cousin.$NEWLINE$If we are marked to die, we are enough$NEWLINE$To do our country loss; and if to live,$NEWLINE$The fewer men, the greater share of honor.$NEWLINE$God’s will, I pray thee wish not one man more.$NEWLINE$By Jove, I am not covetous for gold$NEWLINE$Nor care I who doth feed upon my cost;$NEWLINE$It yearns me not if men my garments wear;$NEWLINE$Such outward things dwell not in my desires.$NEWLINE$But if it be a sin to covet honor,$NEWLINE$I am the most offending soul alive.$NEWLINE$No, faith, my coz, wish not a man from England.$NEWLINE$God’s peace, I would not lose so great an honor$NEWLINE$As one man more, methinks, would share from me,$NEWLINE$For the best hope I have. Oh, do not wish one more!$NEWLINE$Rather proclaim it, Westmoreland, through my host,$NEWLINE$That he which hath no stomach to this fight,$NEWLINE$Let him depart. His passport shall be made,$NEWLINE$And crowns for convoy put into his purse.$NEWLINE$We would not die in that man’s company$NEWLINE$That fears his fellowship to die with us.$NEWLINE$This day is called the feast of Crispian.$NEWLINE$He that outlives this day and comes safe home,$NEWLINE$Will stand o' tiptoe when the day is named$NEWLINE$And rouse him at the name of Crispian.$NEWLINE$He that shall see this day, and live old age,$NEWLINE$Will yearly on the vigil feast his neighbors$NEWLINE$And say, “Tomorrow is Saint Crispian.”$NEWLINE$Then will he strip his sleeve and show his scars,$NEWLINE$And say, “These wounds I had on Crispin’s day.”
paragraphs.translated:
KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Who wishes that? My cousin Westmoreland? No, my dear cousin. If we are slated to die, the fewer, the better for our country, and if we’re slated to live, the fewer men, the greater the share of honor for each of us. In God’s name, I beg you not to wish for one more man. By God, I am not selfish when it comes to money: I don’t care who eats at my expense. It doesn’t bother me when people borrow my clothing—I don’t care about these concrete things. But if it is a sin to be selfish about honor, I am the most guilty soul alive. No, my cousin, don’t wish that even one man who is now in England were here instead. By God, I wouldn’t lose as much honor as a single man more would cost me, I think—not even if it meant giving up my best hope for victory. Oh, do not wish one more! Instead, make this known throughout the army: whoever has no spirit for this fight, let him depart. He will be given safe conduct and money for his passage home. We would not want to die in the company of a man who fears to die with us. This day is called the Feast of Saint Crispian: he who lives to see this day out and comes home safe will stand tall when this day is named and raise himself up at the mention of Crispian. He who survives this day and lives to see old age shall yearly entertain his neighbors on the eve, saying, “Tomorrow is
Saint Crispin’s Day.” He’ll roll up his sleeve and show his scars, saying, “I got these wounds on St. Crispin’s Day.” Old men forget. But these men will remember every detail of what they did today long after they’ve forgotten everything else. And as the wine flows, our names, familiar as household words, will be invoked again: Harry the King, Bedford and Exeter, Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester. Good men will tell their sons this story and the Feast of St. Crispin will never$NEWLINE$Saint Crispin’s Day$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Old men forget; yet all shall be forgot$NEWLINE$But he’ll remember with advantages$NEWLINE$What feats he did that day. Then shall our names,$NEWLINE$Familiar in his mouth as household words,$NEWLINE$Harry the King, Bedford and Exeter,$NEWLINE$Warwick and Talbot, Salisbury and Gloucester,$NEWLINE$Be in their flowing cups freshly remembered.$NEWLINE$This story shall the good man teach his son,$NEWLINE$And Crispin Crispian shall ne'er go by,$NEWLINE$From this day to the ending of the world,$NEWLINE$But we in it shall be rememberèd—$NEWLINE$We few, we happy few, we band of brothers;$NEWLINE$For he today that sheds his blood with me$NEWLINE$Shall be my brother; be he ne'er so vile,$NEWLINE$This day shall gentle his condition;$NEWLINE$And gentlemen in England now abed$NEWLINE$Shall think themselves accursed they were not here,$NEWLINE$And hold their manhoods cheap whiles any speaks$NEWLINE$That fought with us upon Saint Crispin’s day.
paragraphs.translated: go by, from this day to the end of time, without our being remembered: we few, we happy few, we band of brothers—for whoever sheds his blood with me today shall be my brother. However humble his birth, this day shall grant him nobility. And men back in English now safe in their beds will curse themselves for not having been here, and think less of their own manhood when they listen to the stories of those who fought with us here on St. Crispin’s Day.

paragraphs.original: Enter SALISBURY$NEWLINE$SALISBURY
paragraphs.translated: SALISBURY enters.$NEWLINE$SALISBURY

paragraphs.original: SALISBURY$NEWLINE$My sovereign lord, bestow yourself with speed.$NEWLINE$The French are bravely in their battles set,$NEWLINE$And will with all expedience charge on us.
paragraphs.translated: SALISBURY$NEWLINE$My sovereign lord, join us quickly: the French are all arrayed in battle formation and will charge us at any moment.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$All things are ready if our minds be so.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We’re ready if our minds are ready.

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Perish the man whose mind is backward now!
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$Let any man perish who isn’t ready now!

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Thou dost not wish more help from England, coz?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$You don’t wish we had more help from England anymore, cousin?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$God’s will, my liege, would you and I alone,$NEWLINE$Without more help, could fight this royal battle!
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$God Almighty, my liege, I wish that you and I could fight this royal battle all alone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Why, now thou hast unwished five thousand men,$NEWLINE$Which likes me better than to wish us one.$NEWLINE$—You know your places. God be with you all.$NEWLINE$Tucket
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$There! Now you’ve unwished five thousand men, which I prefer to your wishing for one more.—You know your places. God be with you all.

paragraphs.original: Enter MONTJOY$NEWLINE$MONTJOY
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds.MONTJOY enters.$NEWLINE$MONTJOY

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$Once more I come to know of thee, King Harry,$NEWLINE$If for thy ransom thou wilt now compound,$NEWLINE$Before thy most assurèd overthrow.$NEWLINE$For certainly thou art so near the gulf$NEWLINE$Thou needs must be englutted. Besides, in mercy,$NEWLINE$The constable desires thee thou wilt mind$NEWLINE$Thy followers of repentance, that their souls$NEWLINE$May make a peaceful and a sweet retire$NEWLINE$From off these fields where, wretches, their poor bodies$NEWLINE$Must lie and fester.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$Once more I come to ask you, King Harry, if you’re ready to negotiate your ransom before your certain defeat. For assuredly, you are so near the abyss that you’re bound to be swallowed up. Moreover, out of mercy, the Constable urges you to remind your men to make their peace with God and repent, so that their souls may depart sweetly and peacefully from these fields where, poor wretches, their bodies will likely fall and fester.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Who hath sent thee now?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Who sent you this time?

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$The constable of France.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$The Constable of France.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I pray thee, bear my former answer back.$NEWLINE$Bid them achieve me and then sell my bones.$NEWLINE$Good God, why should they mock poor fellows thus?$NEWLINE$The man that once did sell the lion’s skin$NEWLINE$While the beast lived was killed with hunting him.$NEWLINE$A many of our bodies shall no doubt$NEWLINE$Find native graves, upon the which, I trust,$NEWLINE$Shall witness live in brass of this day’s work.$NEWLINE$And those that leave their valiant bones in France,$NEWLINE$Dying like men though buried in your dunghills,$NEWLINE$They shall be famed; for there the sun shall greet them$NEWLINE$And draw their honors reeking up to heaven,$NEWLINE$Leaving their earthly parts to choke your clime,
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Be good enough to take back the same answer I gave before. Tell them to capture me, then sell my bones. Good God! Why do they mock poor fellows this way? The man that once sold the skin of a lion while the beast still lived died hunting him. A good many of our bodies, I imagine, will end up in English soil. And on their graves, I trust, the story of this day’s work will be written in brass. And those who leave their valiant bones in France, dying like men though buried in your dunghills—they’ll be remembered, too. The sun will rise on them here and draw their glory up to heaven, leaving their mortal remains to choke your land: the smell of rotting flesh will breed a plague in France.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The smell whereof shall breed a plague in France.$NEWLINE$Mark, then, abounding valor in our English,$NEWLINE$That being dead, like to the bullet’s crazing,$NEWLINE$Break out into a second course of mischief,$NEWLINE$Killing in relapse of mortality.$NEWLINE$Let me speak proudly: tell the constable$NEWLINE$We are but warriors for the working day;$NEWLINE$Our gayness and our gilt are all besmirched$NEWLINE$With rainy marching in the painful field.$NEWLINE$There’s not a piece of feather in our host—$NEWLINE$Good argument, I hope, we will not fly—$NEWLINE$And time hath worn us into slovenry.$NEWLINE$But, by the Mass, our hearts are in the trim,$NEWLINE$And my poor soldiers tell me, yet ere night$NEWLINE$They’ll be in fresher robes, or they will pluck$NEWLINE$The gay new coats o'er the French soldiers' heads$NEWLINE$And turn them out of service. If they do this,$NEWLINE$As, if God please, they shall, my ransom then$NEWLINE$Will soon be levied. Herald, save thou thy labor.$NEWLINE$Come thou no more for ransom, gentle herald.$NEWLINE$They shall have none, I swear, but these my joints,$NEWLINE$Which, if they have, as I will leave 'em them,$NEWLINE$Shall yield them little. Tell the constable.
paragraphs.translated: Then will you notice the abundant valor of our Englishmen, who will embark on a second round of mischief like a ricocheting bullet, killing again as they fall to their deaths. Let me speak proudly: tell the Constable we’re only workaday soldiers. Our finery and shining metal are all rusty from long, painful marches in the rain. There’s not a strand of feather left in our whole army—a good sign, I hope, that we won’t fly away like birds—and time on the field has made us slovenly. But, by God, our hearts are in good shape. And my poor soldiers tell me that before night they’ll be in cleaner clothes. If not, they’ll pull the bright new coats of the French over their heads and send them on their way. If they do this, as they will, God willing, my ransom will soon be raised. Herald, spare yourself. Don’t come again to ask for my ransom, good messenger. I swear the only ransom will be these bones of mine. And if the French get them in the state in which I intend to leave them, they won’t be worth much use to anyone. Tell the constable that.

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$I shall, King Harry. And so fare thee well.$NEWLINE$Thou never shalt hear herald anymore.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$I shall, King Harry. And so farewell. You’ll never hear from the herald again.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I fear thou wilt once more come again for a ransom.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’m afraid you’ll come to me again for ransom.

paragraphs.original: Enter YORK$NEWLINE$YORK
paragraphs.translated: YORK enters.$NEWLINE$YORK

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$My lord, most humbly on my knee I beg$NEWLINE$The leading of the vaward.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$My lord, most humbly on bended knee I beg you to grant me the leading of the vanguard.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Take it, brave York. Now, soldiers, march away,$NEWLINE$And how Thou pleasest, God, dispose the day.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Take it, brave York. Now, soldiers, advance. And you, God, bestow today’s victory however it pleases You.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarm, excursions. Enter PISTOL, FRENCH SOLDIER, and BOY$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$BOY
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. PISTOL, a FRENCH SOLDIER, and the BOY enter.$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$FRENCH$NEWLINE$SOLDIER$NEWLINE$BOY

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Yield, cur.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Surrender, dog!

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Je pense que vous êtes gentilhomme de bonne qualité.$NEWLINE$Je pense que vous êtes gentilhomme de bonne qualité.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) You seem like a gentleman of high rank.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Qualtitie calmie custure me. Art thou a gentleman? What is thy name? Discuss.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$Qualtitie calmie
custure me! Are you a gentleman? What is your name? Expound.$NEWLINE$custure$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Ô Seigneur Dieu!$NEWLINE$Ô Seigneur Dieu!
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Oh, God above!$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$O Seigneur Dew should be a gentleman. Perpend my words, O Seigneur Dew, and mark: O Seigneur Dew, thou diest on point of fox, except, O Seigneur, thou do give to me egregious ransom.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$This man, one
O. Signieur Dew, must be a gentleman. Consider my words, O. Signieur Dew, and take note: O. Signieur Dew, you’ll be killed with my sword unless you pay me an absurd amount of money for your ransom.$NEWLINE$O. Signieur Dew$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Ô, prenez miséricorde! Ayez pitié de moi!$NEWLINE$Ô, prenez miséricorde! Ayez pitié de moi!
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Oh, have mercy! Take pity on me!$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Moy shall not serve. I will have forty moys, or I will fetch thy rim out at thy throat in drops of crimson blood.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$(mistaking moi, the French word for “me,” as a unit of money) One moy is not enough. I must have forty moys, or I will reach into your throat and pull out some moys, along with a lot of blood.$NEWLINE$mistaking$NEWLINE$, the French word for “me,” as a unit of money$NEWLINE$moy$NEWLINE$moy$NEWLINE$moy

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Est-il impossible d'Échapper la force de ton bras?$NEWLINE$Est-il impossible d'Échapper la force de ton bras?
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Is it impossible to escape your mighty arm?$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Brass, cur? Thou damned and luxurious mountain goat, offer’st me brass?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$(mishearing bras, the French word for “arm,” as “brass”) Brass, you dog! You damned lazy mountain goat, do you offer me brass?$NEWLINE$mishearing$NEWLINE$the French word for “arm,” as “brass”

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Ô, pardonnez-moi!$NEWLINE$Ô, pardonnez-moi!
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Oh, spare me!$NEWLINE$speaking in French

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Say’st thou me so? Is that a ton of moys?—Come hither, boy. Ask me this slave in French what is his name.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Really? Is that a lot of moys? Come over here, boy and ask this slave in French what his name is.$NEWLINE$moy

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Écoutez. Comment êtes-vous appelé?$NEWLINE$Écoutez. Comment êtes-vous appelé?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Look, what’s your name?$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Monsieur le Fer.$NEWLINE$Monsieur le Fer.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Monsieur le Fer.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$He says his name is Master Fer.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$He says his name is Master Fer.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Master Fer. I’ll fer him, and firk him, and ferret him.$NEWLINE$Discuss the same in French unto him.
paragraphs.translated:
PISTOL$NEWLINE$Master Fer! I’ll fer him, and
firk him, and
ferret him: expound as much to him in French.$NEWLINE$firk$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$ferret$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$I do not know the French for “fer,” and “ferret,” and “firk.”
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$I do not know the French for “fer,” and “ferret,” and “firk.”

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Bid him prepare, for I will cut his throat.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Tell him to prepare himself for death, for I’m going to cut his throat.

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(to the BOY) Que dit-il, monsieur?$NEWLINE$(to the BOY) Que dit-il, monsieur?
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French, to the BOY) What is he saying, sir?$NEWLINE$(speaking in French, to the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Il me commande à vous dire que vous faites vous prêt, car ce soldat ici est disposé tout à cette heure de couper votre gorge.$NEWLINE$Il me commande à vous dire que vous faites vous prêt, car ce soldat ici est disposé tout à cette heure de couper votre gorge.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) He told me to tell you to prepare to die, for this soldier here is of a mind to cut your throat without delay.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Owy, cuppele gorge, permafoy, peasant, unless thou give me crowns, brave crowns, or mangled shalt thou be by this my sword.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$(trying to speak French) Yes, cut your throat, by God, you peasant, unless you give me gold coins, good gold coins. If not, you’ll be mangled by this sword of mine.$NEWLINE$trying to speak French

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Ô, je vous supplie, pour l'amour de Dieu, me pardoner. Je suis gentilhomme de bonne maison. Gardez ma vie, et je vous donnerai deux cents écus$NEWLINE$Ô, je vous supplie, pour l'amour de Dieu, me pardoner. Je suis gentilhomme de bonne maison. Gardez ma vie, et je vous donnerai deux cents écus
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Oh, I beseech you, for the love of God, spare me! I am a gentleman of good family: spare me and I will give you two hundred écus.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)$NEWLINE$écus

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$What are his words?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$What does he say?

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$He prays you to save his life. He is a gentleman of a good house, and for his ransom he will give you two hundred crowns.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$He begs you to spare his life. He is a gentleman of a good family, and for his ransom, he will give you two hundred crowns.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Tell him my fury shall abate, and I the crowns will take.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Tell him my fury will abate, and I’ll take the crowns.

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Petit monsieur, que dit-il?$NEWLINE$Petit monsieur, que dit-il?
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Young sir, what does he say?$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Encore qu'il est contre son jurement de pardoner aucun prisonnier; néanmoins, pour les écus que vous lui avez promis, il est content à vous donner la liberté, le franchisement.$NEWLINE$Encore qu'il est contre son jurement de pardoner aucun prisonnier; néanmoins, pour les écus que vous lui avez promis, il est content à vous donner la liberté, le franchisement.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Once again, that it would be breaking his oath to pardon any prisoner. Nevertheless, for the crowns that you’ve promised him, he is willing to give you freedom, liberty.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$Sur mes genoux je vous donne mille remercîments, et je m'estime heureux que j'ai tombé entre les mains d'un chevalier, je pense, le plus brave, vaillant, et très distingué seigneur d'Angleterre.$NEWLINE$Sur mes genoux je vous donne mille remercîments, et je m'estime heureux que j'ai tombé entre les mains d'un chevalier, je pense, le plus brave, vaillant, et très distingué seigneur d'Angleterre.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) On my knees I thank you again and again. And I consider myself fortunate to have fallen into the hands of a knight—to my mind, the noblest, most valiant, and most distinguished gentleman of England.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Expound unto me, boy.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Explain, boy.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$He gives you upon his knees a thousand thanks, and he esteems himself happy that he hath fall'n into the hands of one, as he thinks, the most brave, valorous, and thrice- worthy seigneur of England.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$He thanks you on his knees many times and considers himself fortunate to have fallen into the hands of one, as he thinks, who is the bravest, most valorous, and thrice-worthy gentleman of England.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$As I suck blood, I will some mercy show. Follow me.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$As I get to leech him, I will show some mercy. Follow me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Suivez-vous le grand capitaine.$NEWLINE$Suivez-vous le grand capitaine.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(speaking in French) Follow the mighty captain.$NEWLINE$(speaking in French)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PISTOL and FRENCH SOLDIER$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$FRENCH$NEWLINE$SOLDIER
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL and the FRENCH SOLDIER exit.$NEWLINE$PISTOL$NEWLINE$FRENCH$NEWLINE$SOLDIER

paragraphs.original: I did never know so full a voice issue from so empty a heart. But the saying is true: “The empty vessel makes the greatest sound.” Bardolph and Nym had ten times more valor than this roaring devil i' th' old play, that everyone may pare his nails with a wooden dagger, and they are both hanged, and so would this be if he durst steal any thing adventurously. I must stay with the lackeys with the luggage of our camp. The French might have a good prey of us if he knew of it, for there is none to guard it but boys.
paragraphs.translated: I never heard so loud a voice issue from such an empty heart. It’s true what they say: “The empty vessel makes the greatest sound.” Bardolph and Nym had ten times more courage than this roaring stage villain, whose nails any Joe could cut with a wooden dagger, but they are both hanged. So would this man if he had the nerve to steal anything bravely. I have to stay with the servants, who are with our camp’s luggage. We’re sitting ducks for the French, if they only knew it, for there is no one guarding it but boys.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CONSTABLE, ORLÉANS, BOURBON, DAUPHIN, and RAMBURES$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$BOURBON$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$RAMBURES
paragraphs.translated: The CONSTABLE enters, with the Dukes of ORLÉANS, BOURBON, the DAUPHIN, and RAMBURES.$NEWLINE$CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$BOURBON$NEWLINE$DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$RAMBURES

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Ô diable!$NEWLINE$Ô diable!
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$O, hell!

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Ô seigneur! Le jour est perdu, tout est erdu!$NEWLINE$Ô seigneur! Le jour est perdu, tout est erdu!
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$O Lord, the day is lost! All is lost!

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Mort de ma vie, all is confounded, all!$NEWLINE$Mort de ma vie,$NEWLINE$Reproach and everlasting shame$NEWLINE$Sits mocking in our plumes.
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$Dear God! All is lost, all! Regret and everlasting shame sit on our helmets, mocking us.

paragraphs.original: A short alarum
paragraphs.translated: A brief blast of battle noises.

paragraphs.original: Ô méchante Fortune!$NEWLINE$Ô méchante Fortune!$NEWLINE$Do not run away.
paragraphs.translated: What stinking luck! Do not run away.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Why, all our ranks are broke.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Our men have all broken ranks.

paragraphs.original: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$O perdurable shame! Let’s stab ourselves.$NEWLINE$Be these the wretches that we played at dice for?
paragraphs.translated: DAUPHIN$NEWLINE$O, everlasting shame! Let’s fall on our swords. Are these the wretches that we threw dice for?

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Is this the king we sent to for his ransom?
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$Is this the king we offered to ransom?

paragraphs.original: BOURBON$NEWLINE$Shame, and eternal shame, nothing but shame!$NEWLINE$Let us die. In once more! Back again!$NEWLINE$And he that will not follow Bourbon now,$NEWLINE$Let him go hence, and with his cap in hand$NEWLINE$Like a base pander hold the chamber door,$NEWLINE$Whilst by a slave, no gentler than my dog,$NEWLINE$His fairest daughter is contaminate.
paragraphs.translated: BOURBON$NEWLINE$Shame, eternal shame, and nothing but shame! Let us die honorably. Back into the fray once again! He who will not follow me now, let him depart and stand in the doorway like a pimp, cap in hand, while some slave, no nobler than my dog, violates his daughter.

paragraphs.original: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Disorder, that hath spoiled us, friend us now.$NEWLINE$Let us on heaps go offer up our lives.
paragraphs.translated: CONSTABLE$NEWLINE$Maybe we can benefit from the same chaos that has defeated us. Let’s go offer up our lives en masse.$NEWLINE$en masse

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$We are enough yet living in the field$NEWLINE$To smother up the English in our throngs,$NEWLINE$If any order might be thought upon.
paragraphs.translated: ORLÉANS$NEWLINE$There are enough of us still alive in the field to overcome the English with our numbers if we could just restore some kind of order.

paragraphs.original: BOURBON$NEWLINE$The devil take order now! I’ll to the throng.$NEWLINE$Let life be short, else shame will be too long.
paragraphs.translated: BOURBON$NEWLINE$The hell with order! I’m going back into battle. Let life be short so that shame won’t last too long.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum Enter KING HENRY and forces, EXETER, and others$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. KING HENRY enters with soldiers, EXETER, and others.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well have we done, thrice-valiant countrymen,$NEWLINE$But all’s not done. Yet keep the French the field.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We have done well, my valiant countrymen. But it’s not over. The French are still fighting.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$The duke of York commends him to your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$The duke of York sends your Majesty his respects.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Lives he, good uncle? Thrice within this hour$NEWLINE$I saw him down, thrice up again and fighting.$NEWLINE$From helmet to the spur, all blood he was.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Is he still alive, good uncle? Three times in an hour I saw him down, and three times up again and fighting. He was covered with blood from his helmet to his spurs.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$In which array, brave soldier, doth he lie,$NEWLINE$Larding the plain, and by his bloody side,$NEWLINE$Yoke-fellow to his honor-owing wounds,$NEWLINE$The noble earl of Suffolk also lies.$NEWLINE$Suffolk first died, and York, all haggled over,$NEWLINE$Comes to him where in gore he lay insteeped$NEWLINE$And takes him by the beard, kisses the gashes$NEWLINE$That bloodily did yawn upon his face.$NEWLINE$And cries aloud, “Tarry, my cousin Suffolk.$NEWLINE$My soul shall thine keep company to heaven.$NEWLINE$Tarry, sweet soul, for mine; then fly abreast,$NEWLINE$As in this glorious and well-foughten field$NEWLINE$We kept together in our chivalry.”$NEWLINE$Upon these words I came and cheered him up.$NEWLINE$He smiled me in the face, raught me his hand,$NEWLINE$And with a feeble grip, says “Dear my lord,$NEWLINE$Commend my service to my sovereign.”$NEWLINE$So did he turn, and over Suffolk’s neck
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$The valiant soldier is still dressed like that, lying on the ground, drenching the field with his blood. By his side lies the noble earl of Suffolk, York’s comrade and equal in brave wounds. Suffolk died first, and York, cut to pieces, came to him where he lay in his blood and took him by the face, kissing his gashes. He cried out, “Wait for me, dear cousin. My soul will keep yours company on the way to heaven. Wait for mine, sweet soul. We’ll fly there side by side, just as we stood together as brother-knights in this glorious and well-fought battle!” At this, I went to comfort him. He smiled at me close, gave me his hand, gripping me feebly, and said, “My dear lord, commend my service to my king.” With that, he turned and threw his wounded arm around Suffolk’s neck and kissed his lips. And so,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He threw his wounded arm and kissed his lips,$NEWLINE$And so, espoused to death, with blood he sealed$NEWLINE$A testament of noble-ending love.$NEWLINE$The pretty and sweet manner of it forced$NEWLINE$Those waters from me which I would have stopped,$NEWLINE$But I had not so much of man in me,$NEWLINE$And all my mother came into mine eyes$NEWLINE$And gave me up to tears.
paragraphs.translated: married to death, he sealed a testament of love that even ended in nobility. The fineness of the moment moved me to tears. I tried to hold them back, but wept like a mother.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I blame you not,$NEWLINE$For, hearing this, I must perforce compound$NEWLINE$With mistful eyes, or they will issue too.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I don’t blame you. Just listening, I have to school my misty eyes, or they will brim over.

paragraphs.original: Alarum
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle.

paragraphs.original: But hark, what new alarum is this same?$NEWLINE$The French have reinforced their scattered men.$NEWLINE$Then every soldier kill his prisoners.$NEWLINE$Give the word through.
paragraphs.translated: But listen! What new battle is this? The French have reinforced their scattered men. Then every soldier must kill his prisoners. Spread the word.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN and GOWER enter.$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Kill the poys and the luggage! 'Tis expressly against the law of arms. 'Tis as arrant a piece of knavery, mark you now, as can be offert, in your conscience now, is it not?
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$To kill the boys with the luggage! It’s expressly against the rules of combat. It’s as complete a work of villainy as any that could be thought up. Tell me, don’t you think so?

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$'Tis certain there’s not a boy left alive, and the cowardly rascals that ran from the battle ha' done this slaughter. Besides, they have burned and carried away all that was in the king’s tent, wherefore the king, most worthily, hath caused every soldier to cut his prisoner’s throat. Oh, ’tis a gallant king!
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$There’s certainly not a boy left alive, and it was done by the cowardly rascals who were running from the battle. On top of this, they’ve either burned or carried away everything that was in the king’s tent. So the king has quite rightly ordered that every prisoner’s throat be cut. Oh, he’s a gallant king!

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Ay, he was porn at Monmouth, Captain Gower. What call you the town’s name where Alexander the Pig was born?
paragraphs.translated:
FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, he was born at Monmouth, Captain Gower. What is the name of the town where Alexander the
Pig was born?$NEWLINE$Pig$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Alexander the Great.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Alexander the Great.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Why, I pray you, is not “pig” great? The pig, or the great, or the mighty, or the huge, or the magnanimous are all one reckonings, save the phrase is a little variations.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$And is “pig” not the same as “great,” may I ask? The pig or the mighty or the huge or the magnanimous—they all mean the same thing, with some variation.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon. His father was called Philip of Macedon, as I take it.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$I think Alexander the Great was born in Macedon. His father was Philip of Macedon, as I remember.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I think it is in Macedon where Alexander is porn. I tell you, Captain, if you look in the maps of the 'orld, I warrant you shall find, in the comparisons between Macedon and Monmouth, that the situations, look you, is both alike.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I think that Macedon is indeed where Alexander was born. I tell you, Captain, if you look at a map of the world, I’ll bet you will find, comparing Macedon and Monmouth, that the situations, see, are very similar.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: There is a river in Macedon, and there is also, moreover, a river at Monmouth. It is called Wye at Monmouth, but it is out of my prains what is the name of the other river. But ’tis all one; ’tis alike as my fingers is to my fingers, and there is salmons in both. If you mark Alexander’s life well, Harry of Monmouth’s life is come after it indifferent well, for there is figures in all things. Alexander, God knows and you know, in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his cholers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations, and also being a little intoxicates in his prains, did, in his ales and his angers, look you, kill his best friend, Cleitus.
paragraphs.translated: There is a river in Macedon, and there is likewise a river in Monmouth. The river in Monmouth is called Wye, but the name of the other river has gone out of my head. Nevertheless, it’s all one—the two rivers are as alike as my fingers are to my fingers, and there are salmon in both. If you look closely at Alexander’s life, Harry of Monmouth’s stands up fairly well by comparison—for there are analogies in everything. Alexander, God knows and you know, in his rages and his furies and his wraths and his angers and his moods and his displeasures and his indignations, and also being a little the worse for drink, killed his best friend Cleitus in a drunken rage, see.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Our king is not like him in that. He never killed any of his friends.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Our king is not like him in that respect: he never killed any of his friends.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It is not well done, mark you now, to take the tales out of my mouth ere it is made and finished. I speak but in the figures and comparisons of it. As Alexander killed his friend Cleitus, being in his ales and his cups, so also Harry Monmouth, being in his right wits and his good judgments, turned away the fat knight with the great-belly doublet; he was full of jests, and gipes and knaveries, and mocks—I have forgot his name.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It is not courteous, you know, to assume you know my meaning before I’ve finished talking. I’m speaking purely in analogies and comparisons. Just as Alexander killed his friend Cleitus when he was drinking, so Harry Monmouth, having come to his senses and acquired good judgment, turned away the fat knight in the oversized doublet: the man was full of jests and japes and pranks and mocks. I have forgotten his name.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Sir John Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Sir John Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$That is he. I’ll tell you, there is good men porn at$NEWLINE$Monmouth.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$That’s the one. I tell you, there are good men born at Monmouth.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Here comes his Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Here comes his Majesty.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum Enter KING HENRY, WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, EXETER, and others$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EXETER
paragraphs.translated: Sounds of battle. KING HENRY enters with WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, EXETER, and others.$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$EXETER

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I was not angry since I came to France$NEWLINE$Until this instant. Take a trumpet, herald.$NEWLINE$Ride thou unto the horsemen on yond hill.$NEWLINE$If they will fight with us, bid them come down,$NEWLINE$Or void the field. They do offend our sight.$NEWLINE$If they’ll do neither, we will come to them$NEWLINE$And make them skirr away as swift as stones$NEWLINE$Enforcèd from the old Assyrian slings.$NEWLINE$Besides, we’ll cut the throats of those we have,$NEWLINE$And not a man of them that we shall take$NEWLINE$Shall taste our mercy. Go and tell them so.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I was not angry since I came to France until this instant. Take a trumpet, herald. Ride out to the horsemen on that hill. If they seek battle with us, have them come down or else clear the field. The sight of them is offensive. If they’ll do neither, we’ll come to them and make them fly like stones shot from powerful slings. We’ll also cut the throats of any prisoners we have. Not a man of them that we shall take shall know our mercy. Go and tell them this.

paragraphs.original: Enter MONTJOY$NEWLINE$MONTJOY
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY enters.$NEWLINE$MONTJOY

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Here comes the herald of the French, my liege.

paragraphs.original: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$His eyes are humbler than they used to be.
paragraphs.translated: GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$He looks humbler than he used to.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How now, what means this, herald? Know’st thou not$NEWLINE$That I have fined these bones of mine for ransom?$NEWLINE$Com’st thou again for ransom?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well? What is the meaning of this, herald? Don’t you know that I have offered these bones of mine for ransom? Are you coming again for ransom?

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$No, great king.$NEWLINE$I come to thee for charitable license,$NEWLINE$That we may wander o'er this bloody field$NEWLINE$To book our dead and then to bury them;$NEWLINE$To sort our nobles from our common men,$NEWLINE$For many of our princes—woe the while!—$NEWLINE$Lie drowned and soaked in mercenary blood.$NEWLINE$So do our vulgar drench their peasant limbs$NEWLINE$In blood of princes, and the wounded steeds$NEWLINE$Fret fetlock deep in gore, and with wild rage$NEWLINE$Yerk out their armèd heels at their dead masters,$NEWLINE$Killing them twice. Oh, give us leave, great king,$NEWLINE$To view the field in safety and dispose$NEWLINE$Of their dead bodies.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$No, great king. I come to ask you out of charity to let us wander over this bloody field to record the numbers of our dead and bury them, separating our nobles from the common men, for many of our princes—alas!—lie drowned and soaked in the blood of mercenary soldiers. Likewise, our common men lie drenched in the blood of princes, and their wounded steeds, ankle-deep in gore, struggle and, raging wildly, stamp on their dead masters with their hooves, killing them a second time. Oh, give us permission, great king, to search the field in safety and dispose of our dead bodies.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I tell thee truly, herald,$NEWLINE$I know not if the day be ours or no,$NEWLINE$For yet a many of your horsemen peer$NEWLINE$And gallop o'er the field.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I’ll be honest with you, herald: I don’t even know who won the battle. I still see many of your horsemen galloping across the field.

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$The day is yours.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$You won it.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Praised be God, and not our strength, for it!$NEWLINE$What is this castle called that stands hard by?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$God, not our strength, be praised! What is the name of the castle that stands over there?

paragraphs.original: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$They call it Agincourt.
paragraphs.translated: MONTJOY$NEWLINE$Agincourt.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then call we this the field of Agincourt,$NEWLINE$Fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then we’ll call this the Battle of Agincourt, fought on the day of Crispin Crispianus.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your grandfather of famous memory, an’t please your Majesty, and your great-uncle Edward the Plack Prince of Wales, as I have read in the chronicles, fought a most prave pattle here in France.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If I may say so, your Majesty, your famous grandfather and your great-uncle Edward, the Black Prince of Wales—or so I’ve read in the history books—fought a very brave battle here in France.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$They did, Fluellen.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$They did, Fluellen.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your Majesty says very true. If your Majesties is remembered of it, the Welshmen did good service in a garden where leeks did grow, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps, which, your Majesty know, to this hour is an honorable badge of the service. And I do believe your Majesty takes no scorn to wear the leek upon Saint Tavy’s day.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your Majesty is quite right. If your Majesties recall it, the Welsh fought very valiantly in a garden where there were leeks growing, wearing leeks in their Monmouth caps which, your Majesty knows, is to this day a badge of honorable military service. I do believe your Majesty takes no shame in wearing the leek on Saint Davy’s Day.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I wear it for a memorable honor,$NEWLINE$For I am Welsh, you know, good countryman.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I wear it with pride, for I am Welsh you know, good countryman.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$All the water in Wye cannot wash your Majesty’s Welsh plood out of your pody, I can tell you that: God pless it and preserve it as long as it pleases his Grace and his Majesty too.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$All the water in Wye cannot wash your Majesty’s Welsh blood out of your body. I can tell you that. God bless it and preserve it, as long as it pleases his Grace, and his Majesty, too!

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Thanks, good my countryman.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Thanks, my good countryman.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$By Jeshu, I am your Majesty’s countryman, I care not who know it. I will confess it to all the 'orld. I need not to be ashamed of your Majesty, praised be God, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$By Jesus, I am your Majesty’s countryman, and I don’t care who knows it. I will confess it to all the world. I needn’t be ashamed of your Majesty, God be praised, so long as your Majesty is an honest man.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$God keep me so.—Our heralds go with him.$NEWLINE$Bring me just notice of the numbers dead$NEWLINE$On both our parts. (points to WILLIAMS)$NEWLINE$(points to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Call yonder fellow hither.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$God keep me so.—Heralds, go with him. Bring me an exact report of the number of dead on both sides. (pointing to WILLIAMS) Tell that fellow over there to come here.$NEWLINE$(pointing to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt heralds with MONTJOY$NEWLINE$MONTJOY
paragraphs.translated: English messengers exit with MONTJOY.$NEWLINE$MONTJOY

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Soldier, you must come to the king.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Soldier, you must come to the king.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Soldier, why wear’st thou that glove in thy cap?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Soldier, why are you wearing that glove in your cap?

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$An’t please your Majesty, ’tis the gage of one that I should fight withal, if he be alive.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$If it pleases your Majesty, it is the token of a man I must fight with, if he’s still alive.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$An Englishman?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$An Englishman?

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$An ’t please your Majesty, a rascal that swaggered with me last night, who, if alive and ever dare to challenge this glove, I have sworn to take him a box o' th' ear, or if I can see my glove in his cap, which he swore, as he was a soldier, he would wear if alive, I will strike it out soundly.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$If I may say so, your Majesty, he is a rascal who quarreled with me last night, and who, if he lives and ever dares to challenge this glove, will get a box on the ear from me. Or, if I see him wearing my glove in his cap, which he swore as a soldier he would wear if he lived, I will knock it off his head.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What think you, Captain Fluellen, is it fit this soldier keep his oath?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What do you say, Captain Fluellen? Should this soldier keep his oath?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$He is a craven and a villain else, an ’t please your Majesty, in my conscience.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If I may say so, your Majesty, as I see it he would be a coward and a villain not to.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It may be his enemy is a gentleman of great sort, quite from the answer of his degree.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It may be that his antagonist is a gentleman of very high degree, quite outside of his own sphere.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Though he be as good a gentleman as the devil is, as Lucifer and Beelzebub himself, it is necessary, look your Grace, that he keep his vow and his oath. If he be perjured, see you now, his reputation is as arrant a villain and a Jack Sauce as ever his black shoe trod upon God’s ground and His earth, in my conscience, la.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Even if he were as important a man as the devil—as Lucifer or Beelzebub himself—he’s required, see, your Grace, to keep his vow. If he backs down, he’ll become as notorious a villain and as saucy a Jack as ever walked on God’s earth, in my opinion.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then keep thy vow, sirrah, when thou meet’st the fellow.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then keep your vow, fellow, when you meet the man.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$So I will, my liege, as I live.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$So I will, my liege. I swear on my life.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Who serv’st thou under?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Whom do you serve under?

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Under Captain Gower, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Under Captain Gower, my liege.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Gower is a good captain, and is good knowledge and literatured in the wars.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Gower is a good captain, and is well versed and well read in the wars.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Call him hither to me, soldier.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Have him come to me here, soldier.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I will, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I will, my liege.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Here, Fluellen, wear thou this favor for me and stick it in thy cap. (gives WILLIAMS's glove to FLUELLEN) When Alençon and myself were down together, I plucked this glove from his helm. If any man challenge this, he is a friend to Alençon and an enemy to our person. If thou encounter any such, apprehend him, an thou dost me love.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$s glove to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Here, Fluellen, stick this in your cap. (gives WILLIAMS's glove to FLUELLEN) When Alençon and I went down together, I plucked this glove from his helmet. If any man challenges it, he is a friend to Alençon and an enemy to me. If you encounter such a man, arrest him and prove your loyalty to me.$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$s glove to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your Grace does me as great honors as can be desired in the hearts of his subjects. I would fain see the man that has but two legs that shall find himself aggrieved at this glove, that is all; but I would fain see it once, an please God of his Grace that I might see.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your Grace does me as great an honor as could be wished by any of his subjects. I’d like to see the man with two legs who takes offense at this glove, that’s all! Just once I’d like to see it, if it please God to grant me that.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Know’st thou Gower?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Do you know Captain Gower?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$He is my dear friend, an please you.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$He is my dear friend, your Majesty.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Pray thee, go seek him, and bring him to my tent.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Go find him, please, and bring him to my tent.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I will fetch him.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I’ll fetch him.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester,$NEWLINE$Follow Fluellen closely at the heels.$NEWLINE$The glove which I have given him for a favor$NEWLINE$May haply purchase him a box o' th' ear.$NEWLINE$It is the soldier’s. I by bargain should$NEWLINE$Wear it myself. Follow, good cousin Warwick.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$My Lord of Warwick and my brother Gloucester, follow Fluellen at a close distance. The glove which I have given him to wear may possibly win him a box on the ear. It belongs to the soldier I was just talking to. According to an agreement, I should wear it myself. Follow Fluellen, cousin Warwick, and if the soldier strikes him—and I would think from his forthright manner that he’ll keep his word—some mischief may arise as a result. I know Fluellen to be very conscious of his honor and quick to anger, hot as gunpowder and

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If that the soldier strike him, as I judge$NEWLINE$By his blunt bearing he will keep his word,$NEWLINE$Some sudden mischief may arise of it,$NEWLINE$For I do know Fluellen valiant$NEWLINE$And, touched with choler, hot as gunpowder,$NEWLINE$And quickly will return an injury.$NEWLINE$Follow, and see there be no harm between them.$NEWLINE$—Go you with me, uncle of Exeter.
paragraphs.translated: likely to return any injury promptly. Follow and see to it that nothing serious happens between them. You come with me, uncle of Exeter.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter GOWER and WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$GOWER$NEWLINE$WILLIAMS
paragraphs.translated: GOWER and WILLIAMS enter.$NEWLINE$GOWER$NEWLINE$WILLIAMS

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I warrant it is to knight you, Captain.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I’m sure it is to knight you, Captain.

paragraphs.original: Enter FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN enters, wearing WILLIAMS’s glove.$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$WILLIAMS

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$God’s will and His pleasure, Captain, I beseech you now, come apace to the king. There is more good toward you peradventure than is in your knowledge to dream of.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$As it is God’s will and pleasure, Captain, I entreat you to come quickly to the king. There is more good fortune in store for you than you could ever imagine.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Sir, know you this glove?
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Sir, do you recognize this glove?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Know the glove! I know the glove is a glove.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Know the glove! I know the glove is a glove.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I know this, and thus I challenge it. (strikes him)$NEWLINE$(strikes him)
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Well, I recognize this one (indicates the glove FLUELLEN wears in his cap), and I hereby challenge you. (strikes him)$NEWLINE$(indicates the glove$NEWLINE$wears in his cap)$NEWLINE$(strikes him)

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$'Sblood, an arrant traitor as any ’s in the universal world, or in France, or in England!
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Good God! As absolute a traitor as any in the whole entire world—or even France or England!

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$How now, sir? You villain!
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$What is this, you villain!

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Do you think I’ll be forsworn?
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Do you think I’d break my oath?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Stand away, Captain Gower. I will give treason his payment into plows, I warrant you.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Stand aside, Captain Gower. I’ll reward treason with blows, I promise you.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I am no traitor.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I’m not a traitor.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$That’s a lie in thy throat.—I charge you in his Majesty’s name, apprehend him. He’s a friend of the Duke Alençon’s.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$An infamous lie! I accuse you in the name of the king. Arrest him: he’s a friend of the duke of Alençon’s.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and GLOUCESTER enter.$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER

paragraphs.original: WARWICK$NEWLINE$How now, how now, what’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK$NEWLINE$Now, now! What’s all this? What’s going on?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$My Lord of Warwick, here is, praised be God for it, a most contagious treason come to light, look you, as you shall desire in a summer’s day.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$My Lord of Warwick, a most corrupt treason—God be praised for it!—has been discovered, as plain as any you’d hope to see on a summer’s day.

paragraphs.original: Enter KING HENRY and EXETER$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY and EXETER enter.$NEWLINE$EXETER

paragraphs.original: Here is his Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: Here is his Majesty.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How now, what’s the matter?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, now! What’s the matter?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$My liege, here is a villain and a traitor, that, look your Grace, has struck the glove which your Majesty is take out of the helmet of Alençon.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$My liege, this man is a villain and a traitor, who—see, your Grace—has struck the glove which your Majesty took from Alençon’s helmet.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$My liege, this was my glove; here is the fellow of it. And he that I gave it to in change promised to wear it in his cap. I promised to strike him if he did. I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$My liege, this was my glove. Here is its mate, and the man I gave it to promised to wear it in his cap, and I promised to strike him if he did. I met this man with my glove in his cap, and I have been as good as my word.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your Majesty, hear now, saving your Majesty’s manhood, what an arrant, rascally, beggarly, lousy knave it is. I hope your Majesty is pear me testimony and witness, and will avouchment that this is the glove of Alençon that your Majesty is give me, in your conscience now.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Your Majesty, see here—if it won’t offend your Grace—what a complete, rascally, beggarly, lousy rat this is. I hope your Majesty will, in all good conscience, bear me out and vouch for the fact that this is the glove of Alençon and that your Majesty gave it to me.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Give me thy glove, soldier. Look, here is the fellow of it.$NEWLINE$'Twas I indeed thou promised’st to strike,$NEWLINE$And thou hast given me most bitter terms.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Give me your glove, soldier: look, here is its mate. It was I, in fact, whom you promised to strike. And you spoke of me in the harshest terms.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$An please your Majesty, let his neck answer for it, if there is any martial law in the world.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If it pleases your Majesty, let his neck pay the price, if there is any martial law in the world.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How canst thou make me satisfaction?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How can you square things with me?

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$All offenses, my lord, come from the heart. Never came any from mine that might offend your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$All offenses come from the heart, my lord, and nothing intended to offend your Majesty ever came from mine.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It was ourself thou didst abuse.
