paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$You abused me to my face.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Your Majesty came not like yourself. You appeared to me but as a common man. Witness the night, your garments, your lowliness. And what your Highness suffered under that shape, I beseech you take it for your own fault and not mine, for, had you been as I took you for, I made no offense. Therefore, I beseech your Highness pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$Your Majesty didn’t present yourself as the king. You represented yourself as just a common man. Consider the time of night, what you were wearing, and how ordinary you looked. Anything your Highness suffered in that disguise, I beg you to see it as your own fault and not mine, because if you’d been what I took you for, there would have been no offense. Therefore, I beg your Highness, pardon me.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Here, uncle Exeter, fill this glove with crowns$NEWLINE$And give it to this fellow.—Keep it, fellow,$NEWLINE$And wear it for an honor in thy cap$NEWLINE$Till I do challenge it.—Give him the crowns.$NEWLINE$—And, captain, you must needs be friends with him.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Here, uncle Exeter, fill this glove with gold coins and give it to this fellow. Keep it, my friend, and wear it as a badge of honor in your cap until I challenge it.—Give him the money.—And you, Captain, must make it up with him.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$By this day and this light, the fellow has mettle enough in his belly.—Hold, there is twelve pence for you, and I pray you to serve God and keep you out of prawls and prabbles and quarrels and dissensions, and I warrant you it is the better for you.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$By this day and this light, the fellow is certainly brave. Here, twelve pence for you. I urge you to serve God and stay out of brawls and dust-ups and quarrels and disputes. I promise it will be better for you if you do.

paragraphs.original: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I will none of your money.
paragraphs.translated: WILLIAMS$NEWLINE$I’ll have none of your money.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It is with a good will. I can tell you it will serve you to mend your shoes. Come, wherefore should you be so pashful? Your shoes is not so good. 'Tis a good silling, I warrant you, or I will change it.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$It’s meant in good will. I tell you, you can use it to get your shoes fixed. Come, why be so hesitant? Your shoes are in pretty bad shape. It’s a good shilling, I promise you. If not, I’ll get another one for you.

paragraphs.original: Enter an English HERALD$NEWLINE$HERALD
paragraphs.translated: An English HERALD nters.$NEWLINE$HERALD

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, herald, are the dead numbered?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, herald, have the dead been counted?

paragraphs.original: HERALD$NEWLINE$Here is the number of the slaughtered French.
paragraphs.translated: HERALD$NEWLINE$Here is the count of the slaughtered French.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What prisoners of good sort are taken, uncle?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What prisoners of rank have been taken, uncle?

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Charles, duke of Orléans, nephew to the king;$NEWLINE$John, duke of Bourbon, and Lord Bouciqualt.$NEWLINE$Of other lords and barons, knights and squires,$NEWLINE$Full fifteen hundred, besides common men.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$Charles duke of Orléans, nephew to the king; John duke of Bourbon, and Lord Bouciqualt: of other lords and barons, knights and squires, a full fifteen hundred, besides common men.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$This note doth tell me of ten thousand French$NEWLINE$That in the field lie slain. Of princes in this number$NEWLINE$And nobles bearing banners, there lie dead$NEWLINE$One hundred twenty-six. Added to these,$NEWLINE$Of knights, esquires, and gallant gentlemen,$NEWLINE$Eight thousand and four hundred, of the which,$NEWLINE$Five hundred were but yesterday dubbed knights.$NEWLINE$So that in these ten thousand they have lost,$NEWLINE$There are but sixteen hundred mercenaries.$NEWLINE$The rest are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires,$NEWLINE$And gentlemen of blood and quality.$NEWLINE$The names of those their nobles that lie dead:$NEWLINE$Charles Delabreth, high constable of France;$NEWLINE$Jaques of Chatillon, admiral of France;$NEWLINE$The Master of the Crossbows, Lord Rambures;
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$This paper tells me of ten thousand Frenchmen who lie dead on the battlefield. Among them are one hundred twenty-six princes and standard-bearing nobles. Add to these eight thousand four hundred knights, squires, and brave gentlemen, five hundred of whom were given the title of knight only yesterday. Among the ten thousand the French have lost only sixteen hundred are mercenaries. The rest of the dead are princes, barons, lords, knights, squires, and gentlemen of birth and rank. The names of those of their nobles that lie dead: Charles Delabreth, high constable of France; Jaques of Chatillon, admiral of France; the master of the crossbows, Lord Rambures; Great Master of France, the brave Sir Guichard Dolphin, John duke of Alençon, Anthony duke of Brabant, the brother of the duke of Burgundy, and Edward duke of Bar. Of brave earls, Grandpré and Roussi, Fauconberg and Foix, Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale. Here was a

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Great Master of France, the brave Sir Guichard Dauphin;$NEWLINE$John, duke of Alençon; Anthony, duke of Brabant,$NEWLINE$The brother of the duke of Burgundy,$NEWLINE$And Edward, duke of Bar. Of lusty earls:$NEWLINE$Grandpré and Roussi, Faulconbridge and Foix,$NEWLINE$Beaumont and Marle, Vaudemont and Lestrale.$NEWLINE$Here was a royal fellowship of death.$NEWLINE$Where is the number of our English dead?
paragraphs.translated: royal fellowship of death! Where is the number of our English dead?

paragraphs.original: HERALD shows him another paper$NEWLINE$HERALD
paragraphs.translated: The HERALD shows him another aper.$NEWLINE$HERALD

paragraphs.original: Edward the duke of York, the earl of Suffolk,$NEWLINE$Sir Richard Ketly, Davy Gam, esquire;$NEWLINE$None else of name, and of all other men$NEWLINE$But five and twenty. O God, thy arm was here,$NEWLINE$And not to us but to thy arm alone$NEWLINE$Ascribe we all! When, without stratagem,$NEWLINE$But in plain shock and even play of battle,$NEWLINE$Was ever known so great and little loss$NEWLINE$On one part and on th' other? Take it, God,$NEWLINE$For it is none but thine.
paragraphs.translated: Edward the duke of York, the earl of Suffolk, Sir Richard Ketly, Davy Gam, esquire. No one else of name, and only twenty-five other men. Oh, God, your power was with us. What happened here is your doing alone, not ours. When was there ever before so great a loss on one side and so little on the other, in the ordinary and equal clash of battle? Take credit, God, for it is no one’s doing but yours.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$'Tis wonderful.
paragraphs.translated: EXETER$NEWLINE$It’s unbelievable.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Come, go we in procession to the village,$NEWLINE$And be it death proclaimèd through our host$NEWLINE$To boast of this or take that praise from God$NEWLINE$Which is His only.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Come, let’s make a solemn procession to the village. And let it be proclaimed throughout our army that it shall be a hanging offense for anyone to boast of this or take from God the credit that belongs to Him alone.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Is it not lawful, an please your Majesty, to tell how many is killed?
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If it pleases your Majesty, isn’t it permissible to mention the number of casualties?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement:$NEWLINE$That God fought for us.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yes, Captain, but with this acknowledgement—that God fought for us.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, my conscience, He did us great good.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, I truly think He did great good.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Do we all holy rites.$NEWLINE$Let there be sung Non nobis and Te Deum,$NEWLINE$Non nobis$NEWLINE$Te Deum,$NEWLINE$The dead with charity enclosed in clay,$NEWLINE$And then to Calais, and to England then,$NEWLINE$Where ne'er from France arrived more happy men.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We’ll perform all the holy rites. Let Non nobis and Te Deum be sung, and let the dead be buried properly. Then on to Calais and from there to England. There have never been more fortunate men than we to return from France.$NEWLINE$Non nobis$NEWLINE$Te Deum

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Vouchsafe to those that have not read the story$NEWLINE$That I may prompt them; and of such as have,$NEWLINE$I humbly pray them to admit th' excuse$NEWLINE$Of time, of numbers, and due course of things,$NEWLINE$Which cannot in their huge and proper life$NEWLINE$Be here presented. Now we bear the king$NEWLINE$Toward Calais. Grant him there. There seen,$NEWLINE$Heave him away upon your wingèd thoughts$NEWLINE$Athwart the sea. Behold, the English beach$NEWLINE$Pales in the flood with men, with wives and boys,$NEWLINE$Whose shouts and claps outvoice the deep-mouthed sea,$NEWLINE$Which like a mighty whiffler 'fore the king$NEWLINE$Seems to prepare his way. So let him land,$NEWLINE$And solemnly see him set on to London.$NEWLINE$So swift a pace hath thought that even now$NEWLINE$You may imagine him upon Blackheath,$NEWLINE$Where that his lords desire him to have borne$NEWLINE$His bruisèd helmet and his bended sword$NEWLINE$Before him through the city. He forbids it,$NEWLINE$Being free from vainness and self-glorious pride,$NEWLINE$Giving full trophy, signal, and ostent$NEWLINE$Quite from himself, to God. But now behold,$NEWLINE$In the quick forge and workinghouse of thought,$NEWLINE$How London doth pour out her citizens.$NEWLINE$The Mayor and all his brethren in best sort,$NEWLINE$Like to the senators of th' antique Rome,$NEWLINE$With the plebeians swarming at their heels,$NEWLINE$Go forth and fetch their conquering Caesar in—$NEWLINE$As, by a lower but loving likelihood,
paragraphs.translated: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Allow me to fill in the gaps for those of you who have not read this story. As for those who have, I beg you to excuse the gaps in time, and the many people and things that cannot be represented here in all their magnitude and proper form. Let’s bring the king now to Calais. Imagine him there and, having seen him there, haul him back across the sea on the wings of your imagination. There’s the coast of England: see how the sea seems to be fenced in by the men and wives and boys who line the shore, their shouts and wild applause drowning out the deep roar of the surf. As the king’s ship draws near, the very ocean is like a man running before the king, preparing his way. Let’s have him land and solemnly proceed to London. Thoughts work so quickly that even now you can imagine him on Blackheath, where his lords suggest that he should carry his battle-scarred sword and helmet on a procession through the city. He refuses, as he is free of vanity and self-serving pride and ascribes all the glory and responsibility for victory to God. Now in the factory of thought, create the image of all London pouring forth into the streets. Picture the mayor and all his brother citizens dressed in their best as they go forth like senators of ancient Rome to welcome home their conquering Caesar. Imagine if our own queen’s general returned from Ireland, having stamped out the rebellion there, as we hope he does very soon, how many people would leave the city to come welcome him. Even more people than that welcomed Harry home,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Were now the general of our gracious empress,$NEWLINE$As in good time he may, from Ireland coming,$NEWLINE$Bringing rebellion broached on his sword,$NEWLINE$How many would the peaceful city quit$NEWLINE$To welcome him! Much more, and much more cause,$NEWLINE$Did they this Harry. Now in London place him$NEWLINE$(As yet the lamentation of the French$NEWLINE$Invites the king of England’s stay at home;$NEWLINE$The emperor’s coming in behalf of France$NEWLINE$To order peace between them) and omit$NEWLINE$All the occurrences, whatever chanced,$NEWLINE$Till Harry’s back return again to France.$NEWLINE$There must we bring him, and myself have played$NEWLINE$The interim, by remembering you ’tis past.$NEWLINE$Then brook abridgment, and your eyes advance$NEWLINE$After your thoughts, straight back again to France.
paragraphs.translated: and they had even more reason. Let’s put him now in London, since France’s period of mourning requires the king of England to stay home. Imagine a visit of the Holy Roman Emperor, working on France’s behalf. He wants to bring about a peace between the two countries. Skip over all the particularities between then and Harry’s return to France. There we must place him, and I myself have covered the interim period by reminding you that it has taken place. So, keeping this omission in mind, immediately return to France, your eyes following the path of your thoughts.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter FLUELLEN and GOWER$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN and GOWER enter.$NEWLINE$FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$GOWER

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Nay, that’s right. But why wear you your leek today? Saint$NEWLINE$Davy’s day is past.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s true, but why are you wearing your leek today? Saint Davy’s Day has passed.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$There is occasions and causes why and wherefore in all things. I will tell you as my friend, Captain Gower. The rascally, scald, beggarly, lousy, pragging knave, Pistol, which you and yourself and all the world know to be no petter than a fellow, look you now, of no merits, he is come to me and prings me pread and salt yesterday, look you, and bid me eat my leek. It was in place where I could not breed no contention with him, but I will be so bold as to wear it in my cap till I see him once again, and then I will tell him a little piece of my desires.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$There are reasons and causes why and how in everything. I’ll tell you as my friend, Captain Gower: that rascally, mean, beggarly, lousy, bragging Pistol, whom you and yourself and all the world know to be no better than a peasant—see—with no good qualities at all: he came to me yesterday and brought me bread and salt and told me to eat my leek. We were somewhere where I couldn’t pick a fight with him, but I’ve decided to wear it in my cap until I see him again, whereupon I’ll give him a little piece of my mind.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL$NEWLINE$PISTOL
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL enters.$NEWLINE$PISTOL

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Why, here he comes, swelling like a turkey-cock.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$And here he comes, puffing himself up like a turkey.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$'Tis no matter for his swellings, nor his turkey-cocks.—$NEWLINE$God pless you, Aunchient Pistol, you scurvy, lousy knave,$NEWLINE$God pless you.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Never mind his puffings and his turkeys. God bless you, Ensign Pistol! You lousy, rotten, villain, God bless you!

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Ha, art thou bedlam? Dost thou thirst, base Trojan, to have me fold up Parca’s fatal web? Hence. I am qualmish at the smell of leek.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Are you mad? Do you want me to cut your life short, you deceiving lowlife? Away! The smell of leek turns my stomach.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I peseech you heartily, scurvy, lousy knave, at my desires, and my requests, and my petitions, to eat, look you, this leek. Because, look you, you do not love it, nor your affections and your appetites and your digestions does not agree with it, I would desire you to eat it.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I wonder if you’d be so good, you lousy, rotten villain, to grant my wish and my request and gratify me, see, by eating this leek. I’d like you to, see, because you don’t like it, and because it isn’t to your taste, and because it doesn’t agree with you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Not for Cadwallader and all his goats.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$There is one goat for you. (strikes him) Will you be so good, scald knave, as eat it?
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Here’s a goat for you. (strikes him with a club) Will you be good enough to eat it, mangy rascal?$NEWLINE$strikes him with a club

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Base Trojan, thou shalt die.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Dissolute lowlife, you shall die.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$You say very true, scald knave, when God’s will is. I will desire you to live in the meantime and eat your victuals. Come, there is sauce for it. (strikes him) You called me yesterday “mountain squire,” but I will make you today a squire of low degree. I pray you, fall to. If you can mock a leek, you can eat a leek.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$That’s very true, mangy rascal, when it pleases God. Meanwhile, I’d be gratified if you’d live and eat your food. Come, here’s some sauce to go with it. (strikes him with his club) Yesterday you called me “mountain squire.” Today I’ll make you squire of the low ground. Go on, eat up. If you can mock a leek, you can eat a leek.$NEWLINE$strikes him with his club

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Enough, Captain. You have astonished him.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Enough, Captain. You’ve stunned him.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I say I will make him eat some part of my leek, or I will peat his pate four days.—Bite, I pray you. It is good for your green wound and your ploody coxcomb.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I tell you, I’ll either make him eat some part of this leek or give him a four-day head-bashing.—Go on, bite. It’s good for your fresh wound and your bloody noggin.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Must I bite?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Must I bite?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, certainly, and out of doubt and out of question, too, and ambiguities.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, absolutely, no question or ambiguity about it.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$By this leek, I will most horribly revenge. I eat and eat, I swear—
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$By this leek, I swear I’ll make you pay for this. (FLUELLEN threatens to strike him) Okay, okay, I’m eating it—$NEWLINE$threatens to strike him

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Eat, I pray you. Will you have some more sauce to your leek? There is not enough leek to swear by.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Please do. Would you like some more sauce to go with it? There isn’t enough leek left for you to swear on.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Quiet thy cudgel. Thou dost see I eat.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Lay off, already! Can’t you see I’m eating?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Much good do you, scald knave, heartily. Nay, pray you throw none away. The skin is good for your broken coxcomb. When you take occasions to see leeks hereafter, I pray you, mock at 'em, that is all.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$I sincerely hope it does you good, mangy rascal. No, don’t throw any of it away. The skin is good for your cracked head. When you see leeks in the future, I hope you keep mocking them. That’s all.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Good.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Good.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Ay, leeks is good. Hold you, there is a groat to heal your pate.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, leeks are good. Wait, here’s a penny to heal your head.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Me, a groat?
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Me, a penny?

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, verily, and in truth you shall take it, or I have another leek in my pocket, which you shall eat.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$Yes, and you’ll take it. If not, I have another leek in my pocket that you can eat.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I take thy groat in earnest of revenge.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$I’ll take this penny as a token that you’ll pay for this.

paragraphs.original: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If I owe you anything, I will pay you in cudgels. You shall be a woodmonger and buy nothing of me but cudgels. God be wi' you and keep you and heal your pate.
paragraphs.translated: FLUELLEN$NEWLINE$If I owe you anything, I’ll pay you in clubbings. You’ll become a wood salesman and buy nothing but clubs from me. God be with you and keep you, and may he heal your head.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$All hell shall stir for this.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$There’ll be hell to pay for this.

paragraphs.original: GOWER$NEWLINE$Go, go. You are a counterfeit cowardly knave. Will you mock at an ancient tradition begun upon an honorable respect and worn as a memorable trophy of predeceased valor, and dare not avouch in your deeds any of your words? I have seen you gleeking and galling at this gentleman twice or thrice. You thought because he could not speak English in the native garb, he could not therefore handle an English cudgel. You find it otherwise, and henceforth let a Welsh correction teach you a good English condition. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: GOWER$NEWLINE$Go on, get out of here. You’re a lying, cowardly wretch. You mock an ancient tradition, born of reverence and worn in honor of brave men who have died, and then have the gall not to stand by your words. I’ve seen you bait and mock this man more than once. You thought because he didn’t speak English like a native he couldn’t handle an English club. You’ve learned otherwise. Let this be a Welsh lesson to you to behave with English manners in the future. Farewell.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Doth Fortune play the huswife with me now?$NEWLINE$News have I that my Nell is dead i' th' spital$NEWLINE$Of a malady of France,$NEWLINE$And there my rendezvous is quite cut off.$NEWLINE$Old I do wax, and from my weary limbs$NEWLINE$Honor is cudgeled. Well, bawd I’ll turn,$NEWLINE$And something lean to cutpurse of quick hand.$NEWLINE$To England will I steal, and there I’ll steal.$NEWLINE$And patches will I get unto these cudgeled scars,$NEWLINE$And swear I got them in the Gallia wars.
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL$NEWLINE$Has Fortune turned on me, like the whore she is? I’ve had news that my Nell died of the pox in a hospice. There went my last refuge. I grow old, and all dignity has been thrashed out of me. Well, I’ll turn pimp and do some occasional pickpocketing. I’ll steal away to England, and I’ll steal some more when I get there. I’ll bandage up these wounds and swear I got them in the French wars.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter at one door KING HENRY, EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, WESTMORELAND, and other lords; at another, the FRENCH KING, QUEEN ISABEL, the princess KATHERINE, ALICE and other ladies; the Duke of BURGUNDY, and his train$NEWLINE$KING HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$FRENCH$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$KATHERINE$NEWLINE$ALICE$NEWLINE$BURGUNDY
paragraphs.translated: Through one door KING HENRY, EXETER, BEDFORD, GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, WESTMORELAND, and other lords enter. Through another door, the FRENCH KING, QUEEN ISABEL, the princess KATHERINE, ALICE, and other ladies enter with the DUKE OF BURGUNDY and his train.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$EXETER$NEWLINE$BEDFORD$NEWLINE$GLOUCESTER$NEWLINE$WARWICK$NEWLINE$WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$FRENCH$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$QUEEN$NEWLINE$ISABEL$NEWLINE$KATHERINE$NEWLINE$ALICE$NEWLINE$DUKE$NEWLINE$OF BURGUNDY

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Unto our brother France and to our sister,$NEWLINE$Health and fair time of day.—Joy and good wishes$NEWLINE$To our most fair and princely cousin Katherine.—$NEWLINE$And, as a branch and member of this royalty,$NEWLINE$By whom this great assembly is contrived,$NEWLINE$We do salute you, Duke of Burgundy.—$NEWLINE$And princes French, and peers, health to you all.$NEWLINE$Peace to this meeting wherefore we are met.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Peace to this occasion that’s brought us all together. Health and good day to our brother the king of France and to our sister the queen. Joy and good wishes to our lovely royal cousin, Katherine. And you, Duke of Burgundy, who brought this great assembly together, we salute you as descendent and member of this royal family. And a health to all you lords and princes of France.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$Right joyous are we to behold your face,$NEWLINE$Most worthy brother England. Fairly met.$NEWLINE$—So are you, princes English, every one.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$We rejoice to see you, most worthy brother of England. You are welcome here, as are all of you English princes.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$So happy be the issue, brother England,$NEWLINE$Of this good day and of this gracious meeting,$NEWLINE$As we are now glad to behold your eyes—$NEWLINE$Your eyes which hitherto have borne in them$NEWLINE$Against the French that met them in their bent$NEWLINE$The fatal balls of murdering basilisks.$NEWLINE$The venom of such looks, we fairly hope,$NEWLINE$Have lost their quality, and that this day$NEWLINE$Shall change all griefs and quarrels into love.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$Brother of England, may this meeting prove as fruitful as it is joyous. We are glad to look upon your face—a face whose eyes have until now carried in them a glance as deadly, for any Frenchman they alighted on, as the poisonous eyes of those mythical lizards, the basilisks. We hope your poison has worn off and this day shall transform all grievances and quarrels into friendship.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$To cry “Amen” to that, thus we appear.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$We’re here to say “amen” to that.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$You English princes all, I do salute you.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$All you English princes, I salute you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$My duty to you both, on equal love,$NEWLINE$Great kings of France and England. That I have labored$NEWLINE$With all my wits, my pains, and strong endeavors,$NEWLINE$To bring your most imperial Majesties$NEWLINE$Unto this bar and royal interview,$NEWLINE$Your mightiness on both parts best can witness.$NEWLINE$Since, then, my office hath so far prevailed$NEWLINE$That face to face and royal eye to eye$NEWLINE$You have congreeted. Let it not disgrace me$NEWLINE$If I demand before this royal view$NEWLINE$What rub or what impediment there is$NEWLINE$Why that the naked, poor, and mangled peace,$NEWLINE$Dear nurse of arts, plenties, and joyful births,$NEWLINE$Should not in this best garden of the world,$NEWLINE$Our fertile France, put up her lovely visage?$NEWLINE$Alas, she hath from France too long been chased,$NEWLINE$And all her husbandry doth lie on heaps,$NEWLINE$Corrupting in its own fertility.$NEWLINE$Her vine, the merry cheerer of the heart,$NEWLINE$Unprunèd, dies. Her hedges, even-pleached,$NEWLINE$Like prisoners wildly overgrown with hair,$NEWLINE$Put forth disordered twigs. Her fallow leas$NEWLINE$The darnel, hemlock, and rank fumitory$NEWLINE$Doth root upon, while that the coulter rusts$NEWLINE$That should deracinate such savagery.$NEWLINE$The even mead, that erst brought sweetly forth$NEWLINE$The freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover,$NEWLINE$Wanting the scythe, withal uncorrected, rank,$NEWLINE$Conceives by idleness, and nothing teems$NEWLINE$But hateful docks, rough thistles, kecksies, burrs,$NEWLINE$Losing both beauty and utility.$NEWLINE$And as our vineyards, fallows, meads, and hedges,$NEWLINE$Defective in their natures, grow to wildness,$NEWLINE$Even so our houses and ourselves and children$NEWLINE$Have lost, or do not learn for want of time,$NEWLINE$The sciences that should become our country,$NEWLINE$But grow like savages, as soldiers will
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Great kings of France and England, I owe you both equal service and loyalty. Your Highnesses can both attest to the fact that I’ve strived mightily, with all my wits and energy, to bring about this royal meeting between you two imperial Majesties. Since I have succeeded to the point of bringing you face to face and eye to eye, don’t take it ill if I formally demand to know, before this royal congregation, what obstacle or impediment prevents the poor fragile, mangled peace, the mother of arts and joyous births, from showing her lovely face in this most fertile garden of the world, our fair France? Alas, she has been too long exiled from France, whose crops all lie in heaps, rotting with ripeness. Her grapes, which make the wine that cheers our hearts, die unpruned on the vines. Her once-trimmed hedges, like prisoners with wild, untended hair, put forth unruly twigs. Her fallow fields are overgrown with weeds, while the blade that should uproot such wilderness lies rusting. The level meadow, where the freckled cowslip, burnet, and green clover once grew, has become useless: unmowed, it grows to seed, so that nothing springs up but weeds, rough thistles, barren plants, and burs.$NEWLINE$And just as our vineyards, fallow fields, meadows, and hedges, which grow improperly if left to themselves, run riot, so our families and ourselves and our

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: That nothing do but meditate on blood,$NEWLINE$To swearing and stern looks, diffused attire,$NEWLINE$And everything that seems unnatural.$NEWLINE$Which to reduce into our former favor$NEWLINE$You are assembled, and my speech entreats$NEWLINE$That I may know the let why gentle peace$NEWLINE$Should not expel these inconveniences$NEWLINE$And bless us with her former qualities.
paragraphs.translated: children have lost—or no longer have time to learn—skills that should be a credit to our country. They grow like savages—like soldiers who meditate on nothing but blood—surrounded by swearing and stern looks, ragged clothing and everything unnatural. It’s to reverse all this, so we can once again become as we were, that you have all been brought together; therefore I demand to know why gentle peace should not banish these troubles and bless us with her former qualities.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$If, Duke of Burgundy, you would the peace,$NEWLINE$Whose want gives growth to th' imperfections$NEWLINE$Which you have cited, you must buy that peace$NEWLINE$With full accord to all our just demands,$NEWLINE$Whose tenors and particular effects$NEWLINE$You have, enscheduled briefly, in your hands.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Duke of Burgundy, if you want peace, the lack of which creates these misfortunes you describe, you must purchase it buy agreeing across-the-board to all our very just demands. You hold the details and particulars of our terms, briefly enumerated, before you in your hands.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$The king hath heard them, to the which as yet$NEWLINE$There is no answer made.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$The king has heard them, but as yet has made no answer.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well then, the peace which you before so urged$NEWLINE$Lies in his answer.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Well, the peace you pleaded for so eloquently just now lies in his answer.

paragraphs.original: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$I have but with a cursitory eye$NEWLINE$O'erglanced the articles. Pleaseth your Grace$NEWLINE$To appoint some of your council presently$NEWLINE$To sit with us once more with better heed$NEWLINE$To resurvey them, we will suddenly$NEWLINE$Pass our accept and peremptory answer.
paragraphs.translated: KING OF FRANCE$NEWLINE$I’ve only given the articles a cursory glance. If your Grace would kindly appoint some members of your council to sit with me once more and go over them more carefully, I will give my answer and acceptance right away.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Brother, we shall.—Go, uncle Exeter,$NEWLINE$And brother Clarence, and you, brother Gloucester,$NEWLINE$Warwick and Huntingdon, go with the king$NEWLINE$And take with you free power to ratify,$NEWLINE$Augment, or alter, as your wisdoms best$NEWLINE$Shall see advantageable for our dignity,$NEWLINE$Anything in or out of our demands,
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Brother, I shall. Go, uncle Exeter, and brother Clarence, and you, brother Gloucester, Warwick and Huntingdon, go with the king. You have full power to confirm, change, or add to any of my demands in any

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And we’ll consign thereto.—Will you, fair sister,$NEWLINE$Go with the princes or stay here with us?
paragraphs.translated: way that you judge advantageous to my rule, and I’ll undertake to agree to it. Fair sister, will you go with the princes or stay here with me?

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$Our gracious brother, I will go with them.$NEWLINE$Haply a woman’s voice may do some good,$NEWLINE$When articles too nicely urged be stood on.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$Gracious brother, I will go with them. Perhaps a woman’s voice may do some good when some small detail proves to be holding things up.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yet leave our cousin Katherine here with us.$NEWLINE$She is our capital demand, comprised$NEWLINE$Within the forerank of our articles.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$In that case, leave our cousin Katherine here with us. She is our principal demand—one of the first points of the treaty.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$She hath good leave.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$She is welcome to stay.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all except KING HENRY, KATHERINE, and ALICE$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$KATHERINE$NEWLINE$ALICE
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except KING HENRY, KATHERINE, and ALICE exits.$NEWLINE$KING$NEWLINE$HENRY$NEWLINE$KATHERINE$NEWLINE$ALICE

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Fair Katherine, and most fair,$NEWLINE$Will you vouchsafe to teach a soldier terms$NEWLINE$Such as will enter at a lady’s ear$NEWLINE$And plead his love suit to her gentle heart?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Lovely, most lovely Katherine, will you agree to teach a soldier the words that would recommend his love-suit to a gentle heart like yours?

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Your Majesty shall mock at me. I cannot speak your$NEWLINE$England.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Your Majesty shall mock at me. I cannot speak your England.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$O fair Katherine, if you will love me soundly with your French heart, I will be glad to hear you confess it brokenly with your English tongue. Do you like me, Kate?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Lovely Katherine, if you will love me well with your French heart, I’m happy to hear you confess it in broken English. Do you like me, Kate?

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Pardonnez-moi, I cannot tell what is “like me.”$NEWLINE$Pardonnez-moi,
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Pardon me but I do not know what is “like me.”

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$An angel is like you, Kate, and you are like an angel.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$(to ALICE) Que dit-il? Que je suis semblable à les anges?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$) Que dit-il? Que je suis semblable à les anges?
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$(to ALICE, in French) What does he say? That I am like an angel?$NEWLINE$to$NEWLINE$, in French

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Oui, vraiment, sauf votre Grâce, ainsi dit-il.$NEWLINE$Oui, vraiment, sauf votre Grâce, ainsi dit-il.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$(in French) Yes, your Grace, that’s what he says.$NEWLINE$in French

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I said so, dear Katherine; and I must not blush to affirm it.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I said so, dear Katherine, and I’m not ashamed to repeat it.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Ô bon Dieu! Les langues des hommes sont pleines de tromperies.$NEWLINE$Ô bon Dieu! Les langues des hommes sont pleines de tromperies.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$(in French) Oh, Lord! The tongues of men are full of deceit.$NEWLINE$in French

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What says she, fair one? That the tongues of men are full of deceits?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$(to ALICE) What does she say, pretty one? That the tongues of men are full of deceits?$NEWLINE$to

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits; dat is de princess.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Oui, dat de tongues of de mans is be full of deceits: dere’s de princess for you.$NEWLINE$Oui

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$The princess is the better Englishwoman.—I' faith, Kate, my wooing is fit for thy understanding. I am glad thou canst speak no better English, for if thou couldst, thou wouldst find me such a plain king that thou wouldst think I had sold my farm to buy my crown. I know no ways to mince it in love, but directly to say, “I love you.” Then if you urge me farther than to say, “Do you, in faith?” I wear out my suit. Give me your answer, i' faith, do; and so clap hands and a bargain. How say you, lady?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$How very English of her. Kate, my wooing is fit for your understanding: I am glad your English isn’t better. If it were, you would find me such an ordinary king that you would think I’d sold my farm to buy my crown. I don’t know any fancy ways of talking about love, only to say right out, “I love you.” If you press me any further than with the question, “Do you really?” my love scene is over. So give me your answer, and we’ll shake on it. Deal?

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Sauf votre honneur, me understand vell.$NEWLINE$Sauf votre honneur,
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$With all due respect, me understand well.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Marry, if you would put me to verses or to dance for your sake, Kate, why you undid me. For the one, I have neither words nor measure; and for the other, I have no strength in measure, yet a reasonable measure in strength. If I could win a lady at leapfrog or by vaulting into my saddle with my armor on my back, under the correction of bragging be it spoken, I should quickly leap into a wife. Or if I might buffet for my love or bound my horse for her favors, I could lay on like a butcher and sit like a jackanapes, never off. But, before God, Kate, I cannot look greenly nor gasp out my eloquence, nor I have no cunning in protestation, only
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Really, if you were thinking of having me write poetry or dance for you, Kate, you’ve defeated me already. I have no gift for the one and no strength for the other, though I have the gift of strength. If I could win a lady by playing leapfrog or vaulting into my saddle with my armor on my back—though you may accuse me of boasting—I could easily get myself a wife. I can fight with my fists and rear my horse up without falling off him, if either of those things could win me love. But,

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: downright oaths, which I never use till urged, nor never break for urging. If thou canst love a fellow of this temper, Kate, whose face is not worth sunburning, that never looks in his glass for love of anything he sees there, let thine eye be thy cook. I speak to thee plain soldier. If thou canst love me for this, take me. If not, to say to thee that I shall die is true, but for thy love, by the Lord, no. Yet I love thee too. And while thou liv’st, dear Kate, take a fellow of plain and uncoined constancy, for he perforce must do thee right because he hath not the gift to woo in other places. For these fellows of infinite tongue, that can rhyme themselves into ladies' favors, they do always reason themselves out again. What? A speaker is but a prater, a rhyme is but a ballad, a good leg will fall, a straight back will stoop, a black beard will turn white, a curled pate will grow bald, a fair face will wither, a full eye will wax hollow, but a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or rather the sun and not the moon, for it shines bright and never changes but keeps his course truly. If thou would have such a one, take me. And take me, take a soldier. Take a soldier, take a king. And what say’st thou then to my love? Speak, my fair, and fairly, I pray thee.
paragraphs.translated: before God, Kate, I cannot turn pale on purpose or gasp out fancy phrases, and I have no gift for clever declarations, only blunt oaths, which I never use till I’m asked and never break no matter who asks me. If you can love a man of this temperament, Kate, whose face a sunburn wouldn’t make any worse and who never looks in the mirror to admire himself, let your eye improve me. I speak to you as a plain soldier. If you can love me for this, take me. If not, to tell you I will die is true, but not for love, by God. And yet I do love you. So take for life a fellow of pure and plain faithfulness. He’s bound to be true to you as he won’t be up to flirting with other women. These chatty fellows who can rhyme their way into a lady’s good graces always reason themselves out again. Look, a talker is just a gabber; a poem is just a rhyme. A good leg will shrink, a straight back stoop, a black beard turn white, a curly head grow bald, an attractive face grow wrinkled and a pretty eye hollow. But a good heart, Kate, is the sun and the moon, or, rather, the sun, and not the moon, for it goes on shining brightly forever. If you would have such a man, take me. Take me and get a soldier; take a soldier and get a king. So what do you say to my suit? Speak, my fair one, and speak fairly, I beg you.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France?
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Is it possible dat I sould love de enemy of France?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, it is not possible you should love the enemy of France, Kate. But, in loving me, you should love the friend of France, for I love France so well that I will not part with a village of it. I will have it all mine. And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then yours is France and you are mine.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, it is not possible you should love the enemy of France, Kate. But in loving me, you would love the friend of France, for I love France so much that I will not part with a single village of it. I will have it all mine. And, Kate, when France is mine and I am yours, then France is yours and you are mine.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I cannot tell wat is dat.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I don’t understand all dat.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, Kate? I will tell thee in French, which I am sure will hang upon my tongue like a new-married wife about her husband’s neck, hardly to be shook off. Je quand sur le possession de France, et quand vous avez le possession de moi—let me see, what then? Saint Denis be my speed!— donc vôtre est France et vous êtes mienne. It is as easy for me, Kate, to conquer the kingdom as to speak so much more French. I shall never move thee in French, unless it be to laugh at me.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, Kate? I will tell you in French, which I am sure will hang as heavily on my tongue as a newly married wife around her husband’s neck, impossible to shake off. (in stilted French) I, when, on the possession of France, and when you have the possession of me—(in English) let me see, what then? help me, Saint Denis!—(French again) then yours is France and you are mine. (in English) It would be as easy for me to reconquer the kingdom, Kate, as it would be for me to speak that much French again. I’ll never move you in French, except to laugh at me.$NEWLINE$in stilted French$NEWLINE$in English$NEWLINE$French again$NEWLINE$in English

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Sauf votre honneur, le français que vous parlez, il est meilleur que l'anglais lequel je parle.$NEWLINE$Sauf votre honneur, le français que vous parlez, il est meilleur que l'anglais lequel je parle.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Your French, sir, is better than my English.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, faith, is ’t not, Kate, but thy speaking of my tongue, and I thine, most truly-falsely must needs be granted to be much at one. But, Kate, dost thou understand thus much English? Canst thou love me?
paragraphs.translated:
KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, really, it’s not, Kate. But your speaking my language, and I yours
truly-falsely comes to pretty much the same thing. Can you understand this much English though, Kate? Could you love me?$NEWLINE$truly-falsely$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I cannot tell.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I cannot tell.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate? I’ll ask them. Come, I know thou lovest me; and at night, when you come into your closet, you’ll question this gentlewoman about me, and, I know, Kate, you will to her dispraise those parts in me that you love with your heart. But, good Kate, mock me mercifully, the rather, gentle princess, because I love thee cruelly. If ever thou beest mine, Kate, as I have a saving faith within me tells me thou shalt, I get thee with scambling, and thou must therefore needs prove a good soldier-breeder. Shall not thou and I, between Saint Denis
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Can any of your neighbors tell, Kate? I’ll ask them. Come, I know you love me. And at night, when you go to your bedroom, you’ll question this gentlewoman about me and, I know, Kate, you’ll criticize those qualities of mine that you secretly love. But mock me gently, dear Kate, because I love you terribly. If I ever win you, Kate, as I have an inkling I will, it won’t be without a skirmish—and that suggests you’d make a good mother of soldiers. Shall not you and I together, then, between Saint Denis and Saint George, make a boy, half French, half English, who will go to Constantinople

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: and Saint George, compound a boy, half French, half English, that shall go to Constantinople and take the Turk by the beard? Shall we not? What say’st thou, my fair flower de luce?
paragraphs.translated: and grab the Turk by the beard? Shall we not? What do you say, my fair fleur-de-lys?$NEWLINE$fleur-de-lys

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I do not know dat.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$I do not know dat.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, ’tis hereafter to know, but now to promise. Do but now promise, Kate, you will endeavor for your French part of such a boy; and for my English moiety take the word of a king and a bachelor. How answer you, la plus belle Katherine du monde, mon très cher et divin déesse?$NEWLINE$Katherine du monde, mon très cher et divin déesse?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$No, of course you don’t. It lies in the future, along with certainty. Now there can only be the promise. Do promise, Kate, that you’ll do your French part to bring forth such a boy; and for my English half, take the word of a king and a bachelor. What’s your answer, (speaking in French) oh loveliest of Katherines, my most precious and divine goddess?$NEWLINE$speaking in French

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Your Majestée ave fausse French enough to deceive de most sage demoiselle dat is en France.$NEWLINE$demoiselle$NEWLINE$en
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Your Majesty has false French enough to deceive de wisest lady in France.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now fie upon my false French. By mine honor, in true English, I love thee, Kate. By which honor I dare not swear thou lovest me, yet my blood begins to flatter me that thou dost, notwithstanding the poor and untempering effect of my visage. Now, beshrew my father’s ambition! He was thinking of civil wars when he got me; therefore was I created with a stubborn outside, with an aspect of iron, that when I come to woo ladies, I fright them. But, in faith, Kate, the elder I wax, the better I shall appear. My comfort is that old age, that ill layer-up of beauty, can do no more spoil upon my face. Thou hast me, if thou hast me, at the worst, and thou shalt wear me, if thou wear me, better and better. And therefore tell me, most fair Katherine, will you have me? Put off your maiden blushes, avouch the thoughts of your heart with the looks of an empress, take me by the hand, and say “Harry of England, I am thine,” which word thou shalt no sooner bless mine ear withal, but I will tell
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Damn my false French. I tell you truly, in true English: I love you, Kate. And though I wouldn’t dare to swear that you love me, still my blood begins to flatter me that you do, despite the ill effects of my face. Curse my father’s ambition! He was thinking of civil wars when he conceived me, and consequently my outward appearance is harsh and steely. I intimidate ladies when I come to woo them. But I promise you, Kate: the older I grow the better I’ll look. My comfort is that old age, that poor preserver of beauty, can’t make my face any worse than it already is. If you have me, you have me now at my worst; and if you have me, you’ll appreciate me better and better. Therefore tell me, fairest Katherine, will you have me? Put aside your maiden blushes and speak your true feelings with the bearing of an empress. Take me by the hand and say, “Harry of England, I am yours.” No sooner shall I hear that word than I will tell you straight out, “England is yours, Ireland is yours, France is yours, and Harry Plantagenet

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: thee aloud “England is thine, Ireland is thine, France is thine, and Harry Plantagenet is thine,” who, though I speak it before his face, if he be not fellow with the best king, thou shalt find the best king of good fellows. Come, your answer in broken music, for thy voice is music and thy English broken. Therefore, queen of all, Katherine, break thy mind to me in broken English. Wilt thou have me?
paragraphs.translated: is yours.” And, though I say so in his presence, if he’s not a friend of the best kings, you’ll find him king of the best friends. Come on, tell me in broken music—for your voice is music and your English broken. Come, Katherine Queen of All, reveal your heart to me in broken English. Will you have me?

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Dat is as it sall please de roi mon père.$NEWLINE$roi mon père.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Dat is as it shall please de king my father.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Nay, it will please him well, Kate; it shall please him, Kate.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, it will please him, Kate. It will please him very well.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Den it sall also content me.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Den it shall also content me.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Upon that I kiss your hand, and I call you my queen.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$With that I kiss your hand and call you my queen.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Laissez, mon seigneur, laissez, laissez! Ma foi, je ne veux point que vous abaissiez votre grandeur en baisant la main d'une—Notre Seigneur!—indigne serviteur. Excusez-moi, je vous supplie, mon très puissant eigneur.$NEWLINE$Laissez, mon seigneur, laissez, laissez! Ma foi, je ne veux point que vous abaissiez votre grandeur en baisant la main d'une—Notre Seigneur!—indigne serviteur. Excusez-moi, je vous supplie, mon très puissant eigneur.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$(in French) No, sir! Stop, stop! Heavens, I can’t allow you to lower yourself by kissing the hand of one of your humble servants. I hope you’ll pardon me, mighty king.$NEWLINE$in French

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then I will kiss your lips, Kate.

paragraphs.original: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$Les dames et demoiselles pour être baisées devant leur noces, il n'est pas la coutume de France.$NEWLINE$Les dames et demoiselles pour être baisées devant leur noces, il n'est pas la coutume de France.
paragraphs.translated: KATHERINE$NEWLINE$(in French) It is not the custom for French maidens to kiss before they are married.$NEWLINE$in French

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Madam my interpreter, what says she?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$What does she say, madam interpreter?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Dat it is not be de fashion pour les ladies of France—I cannot tell wat is baiser en Anglish.$NEWLINE$baiser en
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Dat it not be de custom pour les ladies of France—I cannot tell vat is baiser en Anglish.$NEWLINE$baiser

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$To kiss.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$To kiss.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Your Majesté entendre bettre que moi.$NEWLINE$Majesté entendre$NEWLINE$que moi.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Your Majesty understand bettre den me.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It is not a fashion for the maids in France to kiss before they are married, would she say?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It is not the custom for the maids in France to kiss before they are married, is that what she says?

paragraphs.original: ALICE$NEWLINE$Oui, vraiment.$NEWLINE$Oui, vraiment.
paragraphs.translated: ALICE$NEWLINE$Yes, exactly.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$O Kate, nice customs curtsy to great kings. Dear Kate, you and I cannot be confined within the weak list of a country’s fashion. We are the makers of manners, Kate, and the liberty that follows our places stops the mouth of all find- faults, as I will do yours for upholding the nice fashion of your country in denying me a kiss. Therefore, patiently and yielding. (kissing her) You have witchcraft in your lips, Kate. There is more eloquence in a sugar touch of them than in the tongues of the French council, and they should sooner persuade Harry of England than a general petition of monarchs. Here comes your father.$NEWLINE$(kissing her)
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Oh, Kate, prudish customs bow before great kings. You and I cannot be held within the confines of a country’s arbitrary customs, dear Kate. You and I, Kate, we are the makers of custom, and the freedom that goes with our position silences all who would criticize, as I will silence you for upholding the prudish custom of your country in refusing me a kiss. Therefore, willingly and yielding. (kisses her) You have witchcraft in your lips, Kate. There is more eloquence in a sweet touch of them than in the tongues of the whole French council. They would persuade Harry of England sooner than a whole assembly of monarchs. Here comes your father.$NEWLINE$kisses her

paragraphs.original: Enter the FRENCH KING, QUEEN ISABEL, BURGUNDY, and other LORDS$NEWLINE$FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$LORDS
paragraphs.translated: The FRENCH KING and QUEEN, BURGUNDY, and other LORDS enter.$NEWLINE$FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$QUEEN$NEWLINE$BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$LORDS

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$God save your Majesty. My royal cousin, teach you our princess English?
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$God save your Majesty. My royal kinsman, are you teaching our princess English?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I would have her learn, my fair cousin, how perfectly I love her, and that is good English.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I wanted to teach her how perfectly I love her, kinsman, and that’s good English.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Is she not apt?
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$She picks it up quick, doesn’t she?

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Our tongue is rough, coz, and my condition is not smooth, so that, having neither the voice nor the heart of flattery about me, I cannot so conjure up the spirit of love in her that he will appear in his true likeness.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Our language is rough, friend, and it’s not in my nature to speak smoothly. So, possessing neither a voice nor a heart for flattery, I can’t awaken the spirit of love in her so as to make him appear in his true likeness.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Pardon the frankness of my mirth if I answer you for that. If you would conjure in her, you must make a circle; if conjure up Love in her in his true likeness, he must appear naked and blind. Can you blame her then, being a maid yet rosed over with the virgin crimson of modesty, if she deny the appearance of a naked blind boy in her naked seeing self? It were, my lord, a hard condition for a maid to consign to.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Forgive my boldness if I take you up on your words about making magic. For love to appear in his true likeness, he would have to be as Cupid is: naked and blind. How can you blame her, a tender young maiden still given to virgin blushes, for objecting to having a blind, naked boy appear before her? It’s a lot to ask of a maiden.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Yet they do wink and yield, as love is blind and enforces.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$But virgins close their eyes and submit all the time, and blind love has his way.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$They are then excused, my lord, when they see not what they do.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$They’re forgiven, then, if they don’t see what they’re doing.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then, good my lord, teach your cousin to consent winking.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Then teach your cousin to also be willing to close her eyes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$I will wink on her to consent, my lord, if you will teach her to know my meaning, for maids, well summered and warm kept, are like flies at Bartholomew-tide: blind, though they have their eyes; and then they will endure handling, which before would not abide looking on.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$I will signal her with a wink to consent, my lord, if you will teach her what that means. Maidens who are well fed and well taken care of are like August flies, blind though they can see. They’ll let you handle them then, though they’d scarcely let you look at them before.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$This moral ties me over to time and a hot summer. And so I shall catch the fly, your cousin, in the latter end and she must be blind too.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$So you’re telling me to give it time and wait for summer. And even then, in order for me to catch the fly your cousin, she must be blind?

paragraphs.original: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$As love is, my lord, before it loves.
paragraphs.translated: BURGUNDY$NEWLINE$Like love, my lord, before it learns to love.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$It is so. And you may, some of you, thank love for my blindness, who cannot see many a fair French city for one fair French maid that stands in my way.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Fair enough. Some of you may, thank love for my blindness. There’s many a French town that I can’t see because one pretty French maid stands in front of me.

paragraphs.original: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord, you see them perspectively, the cities turned into a maid, for they are all girdled with maiden walls that war hath never entered.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$Oh yes, my lord, you see them, but you see them metaphorically. The cities appear to you like a maiden because virgin walls, which war has never invaded, surround them.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Shall Kate be my wife?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Shall Kate be my wife?

paragraphs.original: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$So please you.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$If you wish.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I am content, so the maiden cities you talk of may wait on her. So the maid that stood in the way for my wish shall show me the way to my will.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I am satisfied, as long as the maiden cities you talk of come with her. That way, the maiden that stood between me and them shall be the means of my achieving my desire.

paragraphs.original: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$We have consented to all terms of reason.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$We have consented to all reasonable terms.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Is ’t so, my lords of England?
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Is that true, my lords of England?

paragraphs.original: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The king hath granted every article,$NEWLINE$His daughter first, and, in sequel, all,$NEWLINE$According to their firm proposed natures.
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND$NEWLINE$The king has agreed to every point: first his daughter, then everything else, as you strictly proposed.

paragraphs.original: EXETER$NEWLINE$Only he hath not yet subscribèd this:$NEWLINE$Where your Majesty demands that the king of France, having any occasion to write for matter of grant, shall name your Highness in this form and with this addition, in French: Notre très cher fils Henri, roi d'Angleterre, héritier de France; and thus in Latin: Praeclarissimus filius noster Henricus, rex Angliae, et haeres Franciae.$NEWLINE$Notre très cher fils Henri, roi d'Angleterre, héritier de France$NEWLINE$Praeclarissimus filius noster Henricus, rex Angliae, et haeres Franciae.
paragraphs.translated:
EXETER$NEWLINE$Except that he has not yet agreed to address you in this form and with this title—in French, Notre tres cher fils Henri, Roi d'Angleterre, Heritier de France; and in Latin, Praeclarissimus filius noster
Henricus, Rex Angliae, et Haeres Franciae.$NEWLINE$Notre tres cher fils Henri, Roi d'Angleterre, Heritier de France$NEWLINE$Praeclarissimus filius noster$NEWLINE$Henricus$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Rex Angliae, et Haeres Franciae.

paragraphs.original: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$Nor this I have not, brother, so denied$NEWLINE$But your request shall make me let it pass.
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$And even this I’m willing to grant if you request it.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$I pray you, then, in love and dear alliance,$NEWLINE$Let that one article rank with the rest,$NEWLINE$And thereupon give me your daughter.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$In that case, I ask that for the sake of friendship and alliance you let that one item stand with the rest, and bestow your daughter on me.

paragraphs.original: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$Take her, fair son, and from her blood raise up$NEWLINE$Issue to me, that the contending kingdoms$NEWLINE$Of France and England, whose very shores look pale$NEWLINE$With envy of each other’s happiness,
paragraphs.translated: FRENCH KING$NEWLINE$Take her, my son, and give me children by her, so that the warring kingdoms of France and England, whose very shores have paled in envy at each other’s happiness, may finally end their mutual hostility. May this

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: May cease their hatred, and this dear conjunction$NEWLINE$Plant neighborhood and Christian-like accord$NEWLINE$In their sweet bosoms, that never war advance$NEWLINE$His bleeding sword ’twixt England and fair France.
paragraphs.translated: precious marriage cause friendship and alliance between them and war never again threaten England or fair France with his bloody sword.

paragraphs.original: LORDS$NEWLINE$Amen.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Amen.

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now welcome, Kate, and bear me witness all$NEWLINE$That here I kiss her as my sovereign queen.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Now, welcome, Kate.—And let everyone bear witness that here I kiss her as my sovereign queen.

paragraphs.original: Flourish
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$God, the best maker of all marriages,$NEWLINE$Combine your hearts in one, your realms in one.$NEWLINE$As man and wife, being two, are one in love,$NEWLINE$So be there ’twixt your kingdoms such a spousal$NEWLINE$That never may ill office or fell jealousy,$NEWLINE$Which troubles oft the bed of blessèd marriage,$NEWLINE$Thrust in between the paction of these kingdoms$NEWLINE$To make divorce of their incorporate league,$NEWLINE$That English may as French, French Englishmen,$NEWLINE$Receive each other. God speak this “amen”!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ISABEL$NEWLINE$May God, who is the best matchmaker, join your hearts and realms in one. As man and wife, though two, are one in love, so let there be between your kingdoms such a marriage that neither wrongdoing nor fierce jealousy, which often trouble the sacred state of marriage, ever sever them. And let Englishmen be French and Frenchmen English. God say, “Amen”!

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Amen.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Amen!

paragraphs.original: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Prepare we for our marriage; on which day,$NEWLINE$My Lord of Burgundy, we’ll take your oath,$NEWLINE$And all the peers', for surety of our leagues.$NEWLINE$Then shall I swear to Kate, and you to me,$NEWLINE$And may our oaths well kept and prosp'rous be.
paragraphs.translated: KING HENRY$NEWLINE$Let us prepare for our wedding.—On that day, I’ll take your oath of loyalty, my Lord of Burgundy and all my peers, to guarantee my treaty. Then I will swear to Kate and you to me, and may our oaths be faithfully kept and prove fortunate.

paragraphs.original: Sennet
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CHORUS$NEWLINE$CHORUS
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS enters.$NEWLINE$CHORUS

paragraphs.original: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Thus far with rough and all-unable pen$NEWLINE$Our bending author hath pursued the story,$NEWLINE$In little room confining mighty men,$NEWLINE$Mangling by starts the full course of their glory.$NEWLINE$Small time, but in that small most greatly lived$NEWLINE$This star of England. Fortune made his sword,$NEWLINE$By which the world’s best garden be achieved$NEWLINE$And of it left his son imperial lord.$NEWLINE$Henry the Sixth, in infant bands crowned king$NEWLINE$Of France and England, did this king succeed,$NEWLINE$Whose state so many had the managing$NEWLINE$That they lost France and made his England bleed,$NEWLINE$Which oft our stage hath shown. And for their sake,$NEWLINE$In your fair minds let this acceptance take.
paragraphs.translated: CHORUS$NEWLINE$Thus far has our straining author pursued the story with his crude, inadequate writing, keeping important people penned up in this little room while he mangled history’s full glory with his uneven telling. The lifespan of our English hero was brief, but in that brief time he achieved greatness. He had good luck as a warrior, and with it he created the world’s greatest garden, France, leaving his son as its imperial ruler. Henry the Sixth, crowned king of France and England while still in his infancy, succeeded him. But so many people had a hand in managing the child’s kingdom that France was lost and civil war came to England—a story we’ve acted out many times on this stage. With those plays in mind, we hope you’ll receive this one kindly.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: The CHORUS exits.$NEWLINE$CHORUS
